No. 1454 Page 1 STATE OKLAHOMA 1st Session 59th Legislature (2023) SENATE BILL 878 By: Jett INTRODUCED Act relating health care; creating Oklahoma Save Adolescents Experimentation (SAFE) Act; providing short title; defining terms; prohibiting provision referral gender transition procedures; providing exceptions; prohibiting certain uses public funds, public facilities, public employees, state Medicaid program; providing administrative civil enforcement; authorizing certain civil actions relief; providing certain construction; providing codification; declaring emergency. ENACTED PEOPLE STATE OKLAHOMA: SECTION 1. NEW LAW new section law codified Oklahoma Statutes Section 2607.1 Title 63, unless created duplication numbering, reads follows: act shall known may cited “Oklahoma Save Adolescents Experimentation (SAFE) Act”. SECTION 2. NEW LAW new section law codified Oklahoma Statutes Section 2607.2 Title 63, unless created duplication numbering, reads follows: used act: 1. “Biological sex” means biological indication male female context reproductive potential capacity, Req. No. 1454 Page 2 sex chromosomes, naturally occurring sex hormones, gonads, nonambiguous internal external genitalia present birth, without regard individual’s psychological, chosen, subjective experience gender; 2. “Cross-sex hormones” means: a. testosterone androgens given biological females amounts larger potent would normally occur naturally healthy biological sex females, b. estrogen given biological males amounts larger potent would normally occur naturally healthy biological sex males; 3. “Gender” means psychological, behavioral, social, cultural aspects male female; 4. “Gender reassignment surgery” means medical surgical service seeks surgically alter remove healthy physical anatomical characteristics features typical individual’s biological sex, order instill create physiological anatomical characteristics resemble sex different individual’s biological sex, including limited genital nongenital gender reassignment surgery performed purpose assisting individual gender transition; Req. No. 1454 Page 3 5. “Gender transition” means process person goes identifying living gender corresponds biological sex identifying living gender different biological sex, may involve social, legal, physical changes; 6. a. “Gender transition procedures” means medical surgical service, including limited physician’s services, inpatient outpatient hospital services, prescribed drugs related gender transition seeks to: (1) alter remove physical anatomical characteristics features typical individual’s biological sex, (2) instill create physiological anatomical characteristics resemble sex different individual’s biological sex, including limited medical services provide puberty-blocking drugs, cross-sex hormones, mechanisms promote development feminizing masculinizing features opposite biological sex, genital nongenital gender reassignment surgery performed purpose assisting individual gender transition. Req. No. 1454 Page 4 b. Gender transition procedures include: (1) services persons born medically verifiable disorder sex development, including person external biological sex characteristics irresolvably ambiguous, born 46 XX chromosomes virilization, 46 XY chromosomes undervirilization, ovarian testicular tissue, (2) services provided physician otherwise diagnosed disorder sexual development physician determined genetic biochemical testing person normal sex chromosome structure, sex steroid hormone production, sex steroid hormone action, (3) treatment infection, injury, disease, disorder caused exacerbated performance gender transition procedures, whether gender transition procedure performed accordance state federal law, (4) procedure undertaken individual suffers physical disorder, physical Req. No. 1454 Page 5 injury, physical illness would, certified physician, place individual imminent danger death impairment major bodily function unless surgery performed; 7. “Genital gender reassignment surgery” means medical procedure performed purpose assisting individual gender transition, including limited to: a. surgical procedures penectomy, orchiectomy, vaginoplasty, clitoroplasty, vulvoplasty biologically male patients hysterectomy oophorectomy biologically female patients, b. reconstruction fixed part urethra without metoidioplasty, c. phalloplasty, vaginectomy, scrotoplasty, implantation erection testicular prostheses biologically female patients; 8. “Healthcare professional” means person licensed, certified, otherwise authorized laws state administer health care ordinary course practice profession; 9. “Nongenital gender reassignment surgery” means medical procedures performed purpose assisting individual gender transition including limited to: Req. No. 1454 Page 6 a. surgical procedures biologically male patients, augmentation mammoplasty, facial feminization surgery, liposuction, lipofilling, voice surgery, thyroid cartilage reduction, gluteal augmentation, hair reconstruction, various aesthetic procedures, b. surgical procedures biologically female patients, subcutaneous mastectomy, voice surgery, liposuction, lipofilling, pectoral implants, various aesthetic procedures; 10. “Physician” means person licensed practice medicine state; 11. “Puberty-blocking drugs” means gonadotropin-releasing hormone analogues synthetic drugs used biological males stop luteinizing hormone secretion therefore testosterone secretion, synthetic drugs used biological females stop production estrogens progesterone, used delay suppress pubertal development children purpose assisting individual gender transition; 12. “Public funds” means state, county, local government monies, addition department, agency, instrumentality authorized appropriated state law derived fund moneys deposited. reference group differences within given setting along cultural, ethnic, gender, gender identity, national origin, race, religion, sexual orientation lines; promulgating policies, practices, procedures designed implemented reference group differences; (5) "Healthcare-related academic program" means healthcare-related area study designed prepare students employment healthcare provider conferring degree certification, including, limited to, nursing, pre-medical school majors, medical doctor degrees, psychiatry, clinical social work, dentistry, dental hygiene, physical occupational therapy, chiropractic care, medical equipment technicians, related fields; SENATE BILL NO.1016 (2023) - Contractors, facilities, bio sex LEGISLATURE STATE IDAHO Sixty-seventh Legislature First Regular Session - 2023 SENATE SENATE BILL NO. 1016 STATE AFFAIRS COMMITTEE ACT1 RELATING PURCHASING POLITICAL SUBDIVISIONS; AMENDING SECTION2 67-2802A, IDAHO CODE, PROVIDE PUBLIC WORKS CONTRACTOR SHALL3 REQUIRED PROVIDE ACCESS MULTIPLE-OCCUPANCY RESTROOM,4 SHOWER FACILITY, CHANGING ROOM BASIS BIOLOGICAL5 SEX; DECLARING EMERGENCY PROVIDING EFFECTIVE DATE.6 Enacted Legislature State Idaho:7 SECTION 1. Section 67-2802A, Idaho Code, be, hereby amended read follows:9 67-2802A. DISCRIMINATION PROCUREMENT PROHIBITED. Puberty-blocking medication stop normal puberty; b. Supraphysiologic doses testosterone females; c. Supraphysiologic doses estrogen males. SECTION 8. NEW LAW new section law codified Oklahoma Statutes reads follows: Legislature hereby recognizes following findings: 1. United States Constitution silent state shall respond react lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, questioning (LGBTQ) issues sexual orientation orthodoxy matters addressed exclusively Establishment Clause Free Exercise Clause First Amendment United States Constitution, substantive Due Process Req. No. 1625 Page 18 Clause Equal Protection Clause Fourteenth Amendment United States Constitution, applicability; 2. Establishment Clause First Amendment United States Constitution states government “shall make law respecting establishment religion,” Article II, Section 5 Oklahoma Constitution states, “Public money property - Use sectarian purposes. public money property shall ever appropriated, applied, donated, used, directly indirectly, use, benefit, support sect, church, denomination, system religion, use, benefit, support priest, preacher, minister, religious teacher dignitary, sectarian institution such”; 3. Free Exercise Clause First Amendment United States Constitution states government “shall make law...prohibiting free exercise [of religion]”; 4. Establishment Clause First Amendment United States Constitution applies state Fourteenth Amendment, United States Supreme Court held Hein v. Freedom Religion Foundation Inc., 551 U.S. 587 (2007) Establishment Clause applies executive branch, includes Oklahoma’s public schools; 5. Establishment Clause United States Constitution never solely designed prohibit government respecting Req. No. 1625 Page 19 recognizing doctrines institutionalized religions non-institutionalized religions, secular humanism; 6. SUMMARY following summary prepared sponsors measure part body thereof subject consideration Legislative Assembly. editor’s brief statement essential features measure introduced. Requires school districts designate athletic competitions extracurricular sports according biological sex. Prohibits biological males participating athletic competitions extracur- ricular sports designated biological females. Provides causes action students school districts. BILL ACT Relating participation athletic competitions according biological sex. Enacted People State Oregon: SECTION 1. (1) school district shall require every athletic competition ex- tracurricular sport expressly designated biological sex students partic- ipate competition sport follows: (a) “Males,” “Men” “Boys”; (b) “Females,” “Women” “Girls”; (c) “Coed.” (2) Students biologically male sex may participate athletic competition extracurricular sport designated “Females,” “Women” “Girls” sub- section (1) section. (3) Nothing subsection (2) section restricts prohibits student par- ticipating athletic competition extracurricular sport designated “Males,” “Men,” “Boys” “Coed.” (4) public body, defined ORS 174.109, licensing accrediting organization voluntary organization administers interscholastic activities facilitates scheduling programming interscholastic activities may entertain complaint, open investigation take adverse action school district main- taining separate athletic competitions extracurricular sports accordance sub- section (2) section. (5) student deprived opportunity suffers direct indirect harm result school district knowingly violating section may bring claim school district injunctive relief, damages relief available law. (6) student subject retaliation adverse action school district athletic association organization result reporting violation section employee school district athletic association organization, public body oversight school districts state, may bring claim school district athletic association organization injunctive relief, damages relief available law. Session 2023 SENATE BILL No. 224 Committee Federal State Affairs 2-9 ACT concerning environmental, social governance standards involving contracts, investments business practices; relating ideological boycotts discriminatory conduct; enacting Kansas protection pensions businesses ideological interference act; directing board trustees Kansas public employees retirement system divest investments entities engaged ideological boycotts; establishing conditions procedures divestment; requiring state treasurer publish list financial companies financial institutions engaged ideological boycotts; authorizing state treasurer disqualify listed financial institutions receiving deposit state moneys; prohibiting governmental contracts without written verification contractor engaged ideological boycotts; directing fiduciaries governmental plans provide retirement benefits, defer employee income invest taxpayer moneys act financial interest plans; requiring registered investment advisers make certain disclosures clients obtain written consent clients prior investing client funds investments engaged ideological boycotts; providing civil criminal penalties; amending K.S.A. 75-4208 K.S.A. 2022 Supp. 40-2404 repealing existing sections. enacted Legislature State Kansas: New Section 1. Sec. 30. K.S.A. 40-2404 hereby amended read follows: 40- 2404. following hereby defined unfair methods competition unfair deceptive acts practices business insurance: (1) Misrepresentations false advertising insurance policies. Making, issuing, circulating causing made, issued circulated, estimate, illustration, circular, statement, sales presentation, omission comparison that: (a) Misrepresents benefits, advantages, conditions terms insurance policy; (b) misrepresents dividends share surplus received insurance policy; (c) makes false misleading statements dividends share surplus previously paid insurance policy; (d) misleading misrepresentation financial condition person, legal reserve system upon life insurer operates; (e) uses name title insurance policy class insurance policies misrepresenting true nature thereof; (f) misrepresentation purpose inducing tending induce lapse, forfeiture, exchange, conversion surrender insurance policy; (g) misrepresentation purpose effecting pledge assignment effecting loan insurance policy; (h) misrepresents insurance policy shares stock. (2) False information advertising generally. Making, publishing, disseminating, circulating placing public, causing, directly indirectly, made, published, disseminated, circulated placed public, newspaper, magazine publication, form notice, circular, pamphlet, letter poster, radio SB 224 18 television station, way, advertisement, announcement statement containing assertion, misrepresentation statement respect business insurance respect person conduct person's insurance business, untrue, deceptive misleading. (3) Defamation. Making, publishing, disseminating circulating, directly indirectly, aiding, abetting encouraging making, publishing, disseminating circulating oral written statement pamphlet, circular, article literature false, maliciously critical derogatory financial condition person, calculated injure person. (4) Boycott, coercion intimidation. Entering agreement commit, concerted action committing, act boycott, coercion intimidation resulting tending result unreasonable restraint business insurance, act boycott, coercion intimidation monopolizing attempting monopolize part business insurance. (5) False statements entries. (a) Knowingly filing supervisory public official, knowingly making, publishing, disseminating, circulating delivering person, placing public, knowingly causing directly indirectly, made, published, disseminated, circulated, delivered person, placed public, false material statement fact financial condition person. (b) Knowingly making false entry material fact book, report statement person knowingly omitting make true entry material fact pertaining business person book, report statement person. (6) Stock operations advisory board contracts. Issuing delivering permitting agents, officers employees issue deliver, agency company stock capital stock, benefit certificates shares common-law corporation, securities special advisory board contracts contracts kind promising returns profits inducement insurance. Synopsis: Gender transition procedures minors. Prohibits specified health care professionals providing gender transition procedures minor intended alter gender minor delay puberty. Provides certain medical exceptions. Prohibits public funds, Medicaid, health carrier providing reimbursement coverage gender transition procedures minor. Creates civil cause action. Makes conforming changes. Effective: July 1, 2023. Gender Transition Procedures Minors 14 Sec. 1. used chapter, "biological sex" means 15 biological indication male female context 16 reproductive potential capacity, including sex chromosomes, 17 naturally occurring sex hormones, gonads, nonambiguous 18 internal external genitalia present birth, without regard 19 individual's psychological, chosen, subjective experience 20 gender. 21 Sec. 2. used chapter, "cross sex hormones" means 22 following: 23 (1) Testosterone androgens given biological sex 24 females amounts larger potent would 25 normally occur naturally healthy biological sex females. 26 (2) Estrogen given biological sex males amounts 27 larger potent would normally occur naturally 28 healthy biological sex males. 29 Sec. 3. used chapter, "gender" means 30 psychological, behavioral, social, cultural aspects male 31 female. 32 Sec. 4. used chapter, "gender reassignment surgery" 33 means medical surgical service seeks surgically alter 34 remove healthy physical anatomical characteristics 35 features typical individual's biological sex, order 36 instill create physiological anatomical characteristics 37 resemble sex different individual's biological sex, 38 including genital gender reassignment surgery nongenital 39 gender reassignment surgery performed purpose 40 assisting individual gender transition. 41 Sec. 5. used chapter, "gender transition" means 42 process individual shifts identifying 2023 1231—LS 7276/DI 147 4 1 living gender corresponds biological sex 2 identifying living gender different 3 biological sex, may involve social, legal, physical changes. 4 Sec. 6. (a) used chapter, "gender transition 5 procedures" means medical surgical service, including 6 physician's services, inpatient outpatient hospital services, 7 prescribed drugs related gender transition seeks to: 8 (1) alter remove physical anatomical characteristics 9 features typical individual's biological sex; 10 (2) instill create physiological anatomical characteristics 11 resemble sex different individual's biological 12 sex, including medical services provide puberty blocking 13 drugs, cross sex hormones, mechanisms promote 14 development feminizing masculinizing features 15 opposite biological sex, genital gender reassignment 16 surgery nongenital gender reassignment surgery 17 performed purpose assisting individual 18 gender transition. 19 (b) term include following: 20 (1) Services individual born medically verifiable 21 disorder sex development, including individual with: 22 (A) external biological sex characteristics 23 irresolvably ambiguous; 24 (B) forty-six surgery" means medical procedures performed 30 purpose assisting individual gender transition, 31 including following: 32 (1) Surgical procedures biological sex male patients, 33 including procedures. 37 (2) Surgical procedures biological sex female patients, 38 including subcutaneous mastectomy, voice surgery, 39 liposuction, lipofilling, pectoral implants, associated 40 aesthetic procedures. 41 Sec. 12. used chapter, "puberty blocking drugs" 42 means: 2023 1231—LS 7276/DI 147 6 1 (1) gonadotropin releasing hormone analogs 2 synthetic drugs used biological sex males stop luteinizing 3 hormone secretion testosterone secretion; 4 (2) synthetic drugs used biological sex females stop 5 production estrogens progesterone; 6 used delay suppress pubertal development minor 7 Virginia, 518 U.S. 515, 533 (1996); 4 (2) "inherent differences" range chromosomal hormonal differences physiological differences; 6 (3) Men generally "denser, stronger bones, tendons, ligaments" "larger hearts, greater lung volume per body mass, higher red blood cell count, higher hemoglobin," Neel 8 Burton, Battle Sexes, Psychology Today (July 2, 2012); 9 (4) Men also higher natural levels testosterone, affects traits hemoglobin levels, body fat content, storage use carbohydrates, development type 2 muscle fibers, result men able generate higher speed power physical activity, Doriane Lambelet Coleman, Sex Sport, Law Contemporary 13 Problems 63, 74 (2017) (quoting Gina Kolata, Men, Women Speed. 2 Words: Got 14 Testosterone?, N.Y. Times (Aug. 21, 2008)); 15 (5) biological differences females males, especially relates natural levels testosterone, "explain male female secondary sex characteristics develop puberty lifelong effects, including important success sport: categorically different strength, speed, endurance," Doriane Lambelet Coleman Wickliffe 19 LC001518 - Page 2 5 Shreve, "Comparing Athletic Performances: Best Elite Women Boys Men," Duke Law 1 Center Sports Law Policy; 2 (6) classifications based sex generally disfavored, Supreme Court recognized "sex classifications may used compensate women particular economic disabilities [they have] suffered, promote equal employment opportunity, [and] advance full development talent capacities Nation's people," United States v. Virginia, 518 6 U.S. 515, 533 (1996); 7 (7) One place sex classifications allow "full development talent capacities Nation's people" context sports athletics; 9 (8) Courts recognized inherent, physiological differences males females result different athletic capabilities. See e.g. Kleczek v. Rhode Island Interscholastic 11 League, Inc., 612 A.2d 734, 738 (R.I. 1992) ("Because innate physiological differences, boys girls similarly situated enter athletic competition.");Petrie v. Ill. High Sch. Ass'n, 13 394 N.E.2d 855, 861 (Ill. App. Ct. 1979) (noting "high school boys [generally possess physiological advantages over] girl counterparts" advantages give unfair lead girls sports like "high school track"); 16 (9) recent study female male Olympic performances since 1983 found that, although athletes sexes improved time span, "gender gap" female male performances remained stable. "These suggest women's performances high level never match men." Valerie Thibault et al., Women men sport performance: 20 gender gap evolved since 1983, 9 Journal Sports Science Medicine 214, 219 21 (2010); 22 (10) Duke law professor All-American track athlete Doriane Coleman, tennis champion Martina Navratilova, Olympic track gold medalist Sanya Richards-Ross recently wrote: "The evidence unequivocal starting puberty, every sport except sailing, shooting, riding, always significant numbers boys men would beat best girls women head-to-head competition. Claims contrary simply denial science," 27 Doriane Coleman, Martina Navratilova, et al., Pass Equality Act, Abandon Title IX, 28 Washington Post (Apr. 29, 2019); 29 (11) benefits natural testosterone provides male athletes diminished use puberty blockers cross-sex hormones. recent study impact treatments found even "after twelve (12) months hormonal therapy," man identifies woman taking cross-sex hormones "had absolute advantage" female athletes 33 "will still likely performance benefits" women, Tommy Lundberg et al., "Muscle 34 LC001518 - Page 3 strength, size composition following twelve (12) months gender-affirming treatment transgender individuals: retained advantage transwomen," Karolinksa Institutet (Sept. 26, 2 2019); 3 (12) separate sex-specific teams furthers efforts promote sex equality. Sex-4 specific teams accomplish providing opportunities female athletes demonstrate skill, strength, athletic abilities also providing opportunities obtain recognition accolades, college scholarships, numerous long-term benefits flow success athletic endeavors. 8 SECTION 2. Virginia, 518 U.S. 515, 533 (1996); 4 (2) "inherent differences" range chromosomal hormonal differences physiological differences; 6 (3) Men generally "denser, stronger bones, tendons, ligaments" "larger hearts, greater lung volume per body mass, higher red blood cell count, higher hemoglobin," Neel 8 Burton, Battle Sexes, Psychology Today (July 2, 2012); 9 (4) Men also higher natural levels testosterone, affects traits hemoglobin levels, body fat content, storage use carbohydrates, development type 2 muscle fibers, result men able generate higher speed power physical activity, Doriane Lambelet Coleman, Sex Sport, Law Contemporary 13 Problems 63, 74 (2017) (quoting Gina Kolata, Men, Women Speed. 2 Words: Got 14 Testosterone?, N.Y. Times (Aug. 21, 2008)); 15 (5) biological differences females males, especially relates natural levels testosterone, "explain male female secondary sex characteristics develop puberty lifelong effects, including important success sport: categorically different strength, speed, endurance," Doriane Lambelet Coleman Wickliffe 19 LC001518 - Page 2 5 Shreve, "Comparing Athletic Performances: Best Elite Women Boys Men," Duke Law 1 Center Sports Law Policy; 2 (6) classifications based sex generally disfavored, Supreme Court recognized "sex classifications may used compensate women particular economic disabilities [they have] suffered, promote equal employment opportunity, [and] advance full development talent capacities Nation's people," United States v. Virginia, 518 6 U.S. 515, 533 (1996); 7 (7) One place sex classifications allow "full development talent capacities Nation's people" context sports athletics; 9 (8) Courts recognized inherent, physiological differences males females result different athletic capabilities. See e.g. Kleczek v. Rhode Island Interscholastic 11 League, Inc., 612 A.2d 734, 738 (R.I. 1992) ("Because innate physiological differences, boys girls similarly situated enter athletic competition.");Petrie v. Ill. High Sch. Ass'n, 13 394 N.E.2d 855, 861 (Ill. App. Ct. 1979) (noting "high school boys [generally possess physiological advantages over] girl counterparts" advantages give unfair lead girls sports like "high school track"); 16 (9) recent study female male Olympic performances since 1983 found that, although athletes sexes improved time span, "gender gap" female male performances remained stable. "These suggest women's performances high level never match men." Valerie Thibault et al., Women men sport performance: 20 gender gap evolved since 1983, 9 Journal Sports Science Medicine 214, 219 21 (2010); 22 (10) Duke law professor All-American track athlete Doriane Coleman, tennis champion Martina Navratilova, Olympic track gold medalist Sanya Richards-Ross recently wrote: "The evidence unequivocal starting puberty, every sport except sailing, shooting, riding, always significant numbers boys men would beat best girls women head-to-head competition. Claims contrary simply denial science," 27 Doriane Coleman, Martina Navratilova, et al., Pass Equality Act, Abandon Title IX, 28 Washington Post (Apr. 29, 2019); 29 (11) benefits natural testosterone provides male athletes diminished use puberty blockers cross-sex hormones. recent study impact treatments found even "after twelve (12) months hormonal therapy," man identifies woman taking cross-sex hormones "had absolute advantage" female athletes 33 "will still likely performance benefits" women, Tommy Lundberg et al., "Muscle 34 LC001518 - Page 3 strength, size composition following twelve (12) months gender-affirming treatment transgender individuals: retained advantage transwomen," Karolinksa Institutet (Sept. 26, 2 2019); 3 (12) separate sex-specific teams furthers efforts promote sex equality. Sex-4 specific teams accomplish providing opportunities female athletes demonstrate skill, strength, athletic abilities also providing opportunities obtain recognition accolades, college scholarships, numerous long-term benefits flow success athletic endeavors. 8 SECTION 2. Synopsis: Malpractice regarding gender therapeutics. Allows claimant bring medical malpractice claim regarding gender transition treatment within 15 years individual becomes 21 years age. Effective: July 1, 2023. McGuire January 19, 2023, read first time referred Committee Public Health. 2023 1589—LS 7226/DI 149 Introduced First Regular Session 123rd General Assembly (2023) PRINTING CODE. Virginia, 518 U.S. 515, 533 (1996); 4 (2) "inherent differences" range chromosomal hormonal differences physiological differences; 6 (3) Men generally "denser, stronger bones, tendons, ligaments" "larger hearts, greater lung volume per body mass, higher red blood cell count, higher hemoglobin," Neel 8 Burton, Battle Sexes, Psychology Today (July 2, 2012); 9 (4) Men also higher natural levels testosterone, affects traits hemoglobin levels, body fat content, storage use carbohydrates, development type 2 muscle fibers, result men able generate higher speed power physical activity, Doriane Lambelet Coleman, Sex Sport, Law Contemporary 13 Problems 63, 74 (2017) (quoting Gina Kolata, Men, Women Speed. 2 Words: Got 14 Testosterone?, N.Y. Times (Aug. 21, 2008)); 15 (5) biological differences females males, especially relates natural levels testosterone, "explain male female secondary sex characteristics develop puberty lifelong effects, including important success sport: categorically different strength, speed, endurance," Doriane Lambelet Coleman Wickliffe 19 LC001518 - Page 2 5 Shreve, "Comparing Athletic Performances: Best Elite Women Boys Men," Duke Law 1 Center Sports Law Policy; 2 (6) classifications based sex generally disfavored, Supreme Court recognized "sex classifications may used compensate women particular economic disabilities [they have] suffered, promote equal employment opportunity, [and] advance full development talent capacities Nation's people," United States v. Virginia, 518 6 U.S. 515, 533 (1996); 7 (7) One place sex classifications allow "full development talent capacities Nation's people" context sports athletics; 9 (8) Courts recognized inherent, physiological differences males females result different athletic capabilities. See e.g. Kleczek v. Rhode Island Interscholastic 11 League, Inc., 612 A.2d 734, 738 (R.I. 1992) ("Because innate physiological differences, boys girls similarly situated enter athletic competition.");Petrie v. Ill. High Sch. Ass'n, 13 394 N.E.2d 855, 861 (Ill. App. Ct. 1979) (noting "high school boys [generally possess physiological advantages over] girl counterparts" advantages give unfair lead girls sports like "high school track"); 16 (9) recent study female male Olympic performances since 1983 found that, although athletes sexes improved time span, "gender gap" female male performances remained stable. "These suggest women's performances high level never match men." Valerie Thibault et al., Women men sport performance: 20 gender gap evolved since 1983, 9 Journal Sports Science Medicine 214, 219 21 (2010); 22 (10) Duke law professor All-American track athlete Doriane Coleman, tennis champion Martina Navratilova, Olympic track gold medalist Sanya Richards-Ross recently wrote: "The evidence unequivocal starting puberty, every sport except sailing, shooting, riding, always significant numbers boys men would beat best girls women head-to-head competition. Claims contrary simply denial science," 27 Doriane Coleman, Martina Navratilova, et al., Pass Equality Act, Abandon Title IX, 28 Washington Post (Apr. 29, 2019); 29 (11) benefits natural testosterone provides male athletes diminished use puberty blockers cross-sex hormones. recent study impact treatments found even "after twelve (12) months hormonal therapy," man identifies woman taking cross-sex hormones "had absolute advantage" female athletes 33 "will still likely performance benefits" women, Tommy Lundberg et al., "Muscle 34 LC001518 - Page 3 strength, size composition following twelve (12) months gender-affirming treatment transgender individuals: retained advantage transwomen," Karolinksa Institutet (Sept. 26, 2 2019); 3 (12) separate sex-specific teams furthers efforts promote sex equality. Sex-4 specific teams accomplish providing opportunities female athletes demonstrate skill, strength, athletic abilities also providing opportunities obtain recognition accolades, college scholarships, numerous long-term benefits flow success athletic endeavors. 8 SECTION 2. ENACTED GENERAL ASSEMBLY STATE TENNESSEE: SECTION 1. Tennessee Code Annotated, Title 63, Chapter 1, amended adding following new part: 63-1-801. Short title. part known may cited "Youth Health Protection Act." 63-1-802. Part definitions. used part: (1) "Facility" meaning defined § 68-11-201; (2) "Government agent" means agent, employee, volunteer, contractor public child services agency, private child placing agency, court, local education agency; (3) "Healthcare provider" means medical professional facility; (4) "Medical professional" means individual licensed, certified, registered, permitted engage delivery health care state title title 68, regulated department health health-related board attached department health; (5) "Mental healthcare professional counselor" means medical professional, including intern, trainee, volunteer, individual engaged delivery mental healthcare counseling services; (6) "Minor" means individual reached later of: - 2 - 000297 (A) Eighteen (18) years age; (B) Completion Tanner stage 5 development; (7) "Political subdivision" means local governmental entity, including, limited to, municipality, metropolitan government, county, utility district, school district, public building authority, development district created existing pursuant laws state, instrumentality government created one (1) local governmental entities; (8) "Sex" means biological state female male, based sex organs, chromosomes, endogenous hormone profiles. 63-1-803. Prohibition certain practices healthcare services. (a) Notwithstanding another law, except provided subsection (c), unlawful individual engage following practices upon minor, cause practices performed, facilitate minor's desire present appear manner inconsistent minor's sex: (1) Surgery sterilizes minor, including castration, vasectomy, hysterectomy, oophorectomy, metoidioplasty, orchiectomy, penectomy, phalloplasty, vaginoplasty; (2) mastectomy; (3) Administering supplying following medications induce transient permanent infertility: (A) Puberty-blocking medication stop delay normal puberty; (B) Supraphysiologic doses testosterone androgens members female sex; (C) Supraphysiologic doses estrogen synthetic compounds estrogenic activity members male sex; - 3 - 000297 (4) Removing otherwise healthy non-diseased body part tissue. (b) medical professional engages practice identified subsection (a), causes practice performed, commits unprofessional conduct subject revocation licensure appropriate discipline medical professional's licensing authority. medical professional subject civil penalty one thousand dollars ($1,000) per occurrence. SECTION 5. act takes effect July 1, 2023, public welfare requiring it. Introduced Version SENATE BILL No. 413 _____ DIGEST INTRODUCED BILL Citations Affected: IC 20-26-21. Synopsis: Parental rights education. Requires governing body school corporation adopt procedures require schools notify parent unemancipated minor student regarding the: (1) student's services, support, monitoring related student's social emotional, behavioral, mental, physical health; (2) school's ability provide safe supportive learning environment student. Establishes requirements restrictions regarding procedures. Prohibits school corporation personnel third party vendor contracts school corporation providing instruction sexual orientation gender identity: (1) students school corporation enrolled kindergarten grade 12; (2) manner age appropriate developmentally appropriate students accordance state law. Establishes requirements regarding: (1) student support services training; (2) notifying parents social emotional, behavioral, mental, physical health services support offered school corporation parent's option withhold consent decline health services support; (3) administering social emotional, behavioral, mental, physical health personal analysis evaluation, questionnaire, screening, survey, assessment unemancipated minor student enrolled kindergarten grade 12. Requires school corporation notify parent student enrolled school maintained school corporation school corporation permits student school use multiple occupancy restroom locker room designated sex student's biological sex. Requires school corporation to: (1) establish grievance procedure violation (Continued next page) Effective: July 1, 2023. Byrne January 19, 2023, read first time referred Committee Education Career Development. 2023 413—LS 7266/DI 110 Digest Continued provisions; (2) post grievance procedure school corporation's website. Provides parent satisfied decision school principal principal's designee regarding complaint parent may request department education (department) review complaint decision. Provides parent student may bring civil action school corporation violation provisions. Requires, later May 30, 2024, department adopt update, necessary approved state board education, certain student services, personnel guidelines, standards, frameworks, practices, principles. 2023 413—LS 7266/DI 1102023 413—LS 7266/DI 110 Introduced First Regular Session 123rd General Assembly (2023) PRINTING CODE. BILL ACT Relating sex-specific athletic activities. Enacted People State Oregon: SECTION 1. (1) used section: (a) “Athletic organization” means private, interscholastic intercollegiate organ- ization, association entity whose activities include administration operation following: (A) Sports teams leagues. (B) Athletic programs. (C) Athletic competitions contests. (b) “Biological sex” means person’s sex determined birth. (2) athletic organization may designate, classify, name, categorize otherwise indicate specific females, athletic activity, sports team, sports league, athletic program, athletic competition contests athletic organization permits par- ticipation persons whose biological sex male. Virginia, 518 U.S. 515, 533 (1996); 4 (2) "inherent differences" range chromosomal hormonal differences physiological differences; 6 (3) Men generally "denser, stronger bones, tendons, ligaments" "larger hearts, greater lung volume per body mass, higher red blood cell count, higher hemoglobin," Neel 8 Burton, Battle Sexes, Psychology Today (July 2, 2012); 9 (4) Men also higher natural levels testosterone, affects traits hemoglobin levels, body fat content, storage use carbohydrates, development type 2 muscle fibers, result men able generate higher speed power physical activity, Doriane Lambelet Coleman, Sex Sport, Law Contemporary 13 Problems 63, 74 (2017) (quoting Gina Kolata, Men, Women Speed. 2 Words: Got 14 Testosterone?, N.Y. Times (Aug. 21, 2008)); 15 (5) biological differences females males, especially relates natural levels testosterone, "explain male female secondary sex characteristics develop puberty lifelong effects, including important success sport: categorically different strength, speed, endurance," Doriane Lambelet Coleman Wickliffe 19 LC001518 - Page 2 5 Shreve, "Comparing Athletic Performances: Best Elite Women Boys Men," Duke Law 1 Center Sports Law Policy; 2 (6) classifications based sex generally disfavored, Supreme Court recognized "sex classifications may used compensate women particular economic disabilities [they have] suffered, promote equal employment opportunity, [and] advance full development talent capacities Nation's people," United States v. Virginia, 518 6 U.S. 515, 533 (1996); 7 (7) One place sex classifications allow "full development talent capacities Nation's people" context sports athletics; 9 (8) Courts recognized inherent, physiological differences males females result different athletic capabilities. See e.g. Kleczek v. Rhode Island Interscholastic 11 League, Inc., 612 A.2d 734, 738 (R.I. 1992) ("Because innate physiological differences, boys girls similarly situated enter athletic competition.");Petrie v. Ill. High Sch. Ass'n, 13 394 N.E.2d 855, 861 (Ill. App. Ct. 1979) (noting "high school boys [generally possess physiological advantages over] girl counterparts" advantages give unfair lead girls sports like "high school track"); 16 (9) recent study female male Olympic performances since 1983 found that, although athletes sexes improved time span, "gender gap" female male performances remained stable. "These suggest women's performances high level never match men." Valerie Thibault et al., Women men sport performance: 20 gender gap evolved since 1983, 9 Journal Sports Science Medicine 214, 219 21 (2010); 22 (10) Duke law professor All-American track athlete Doriane Coleman, tennis champion Martina Navratilova, Olympic track gold medalist Sanya Richards-Ross recently wrote: "The evidence unequivocal starting puberty, every sport except sailing, shooting, riding, always significant numbers boys men would beat best girls women head-to-head competition. Claims contrary simply denial science," 27 Doriane Coleman, Martina Navratilova, et al., Pass Equality Act, Abandon Title IX, 28 Washington Post (Apr. 29, 2019); 29 (11) benefits natural testosterone provides male athletes diminished use puberty blockers cross-sex hormones. recent study impact treatments found even "after twelve (12) months hormonal therapy," man identifies woman taking cross-sex hormones "had absolute advantage" female athletes 33 "will still likely performance benefits" women, Tommy Lundberg et al., "Muscle 34 LC001518 - Page 3 strength, size composition following twelve (12) months gender-affirming treatment transgender individuals: retained advantage transwomen," Karolinksa Institutet (Sept. 26, 2 2019); 3 (12) separate sex-specific teams furthers efforts promote sex equality. Sex-4 specific teams accomplish providing opportunities female athletes demonstrate skill, strength, athletic abilities also providing opportunities obtain recognition accolades, college scholarships, numerous long-term benefits flow success athletic endeavors. 8 SECTION 2. Title 33, Idaho Code, be, hereby amended addition thereto NEW CHAPTER, known designated Chap-12 ter 66, Title 33, Idaho Code, read follows:13 CHAPTER 6614 PROTECTING PRIVACY SAFETY STUDENTS PUBLIC SCHOOLS15 33-6601. LEGISLATIVE FINDINGS. legislature finds that:16 (1) real inherent physical differences men women;18 (2) Every person natural right privacy safety restrooms changing facilities person might partial full state undress presence others;21 (3) natural right especially applies students using public school restrooms changing facilities student privacy safety essential providing safe learning environment students;24 (4) Requiring students share restrooms changing facilities members opposite biological sex generates potential embarrassment,26 shame, psychological injury students, well increasing like-27 lihood sexual assault, molestation, rape, voyeurism, exhibitionism;28 (5) Providing separate public school restrooms changing facilities different biological sexes long-standing widespread prac-30 tice protected federal law, state law, case law;31 (6) Federal legislative action, federal executive action, fed-32 eral court judgments prevent public schools maintaining separate restrooms changing facilities different biological sexes in-34 consistent United States constitution violate privacy safety rights students; and36 (7) statewide policy ensuring separate school restrooms chang-37 ing facilities basis biological sex substantially related important governmental interest protecting privacy safety students.40 2 33-6602. DEFINITIONS. purposes chapter:1 (1) "Changing facility" means facility person may state undress presence others, including locker room, changing room, shower room.4 (2) "Public school" means public school teaching K-12 students within Idaho school district charter school.6 (3) "Sex" means immutable biological physiological character-7 istics, specifically chromosomes internal external reproductive anatomy, genetically determined conception generally recognizable birth, define individual male female.10 33-6603. SCHOOL RESTROOMS. (1) Every public school restroom chang-11 ing facility accessible multiple persons time must be:12 (a) Designated use male persons female persons only; and13 (b) Used members sex.14 (2) person shall enter multi-occupancy restroom changing facil-15 ity designated one sex unless person member sex.16 public school authority building shall ensure re-17 strooms changing facilities provide users privacy members opposite sex.19 (3) public school setting person may state undress presence others, school personnel must provide separate private areas designated use persons based sex, person may enter private areas unless person member designated sex.24 (4) school authorized activity event persons share overnight lodging, school personnel must provide separate sleeping quar-26 ters members sex. person shall share sleeping quarters, restroom, changing facility person opposite sex, unless persons members family.29 33-6604. EXEMPTIONS. chapter shall apply:30 (1) single-occupancy restrooms changing facilities restrooms changing facilities conspicuously designated unisex fam-32 ily use;33 (2) restrooms changing facilities temporarily designated use person's biological sex;35 (3) person one sex uses single-sex facility designated opposite sex, single-sex facility facility reason-37 ably available time person's use facility;38 (4) person employed clean, maintain, inspect restroom single-sex facility;40 (5) person enters restroom facility render medical as-41 sistance;42 (6) person need assistance and, purposes receiving assistance, accompanied family member, legal guardian, person's designee member designated sex single-sex restroom changing facility; or46 (7) ongoing natural disaster emergency, necessary prevent serious threat good order student safety.48 3 33-6605. REASONABLE ACCOMMODATION. (1) public school shall provide reasonable accommodation student who:2 (a) reason, unwilling unable use multi-occupancy re-3 stroom changing facility designated person's sex located within public school building, multi-occupancy sleeping quarters attending public school-sponsored activity; and6 (b) Provides written request reasonable accommodation pub-7 lic school.8 (2) reasonable accommodation include access restroom,9 changing facility, sleeping quarter designated use members opposite sex persons opposite sex present could present.12 33-6606. CIVIL CAUSE ACTION. (1) student who, accessing public school restroom, changing facility, sleeping quarters designated use student's sex, encounters person opposite sex private cause action school if:16 (a) school gave person permission use facilities op-17 posite sex; or18 (b) school failed take reasonable steps prohibit person using facilities opposite sex.20 (2) civil action arising chapter must commenced within four (4) years cause action occurred.22 (3) student prevails action brought chapter may recover defendant public school five thousand dollars ($5,000) instance student encountered person opposite sex accessing public school restroom, changing facility, sleeping quarters designated use aggrieved student's sex. student may also recover monetary damages defendant public school psychological,28 emotional, physical harm suffered.29 (4) student prevails action brought chapter en-30 titled recover reasonable attorney's fees costs defendant public school.32 (5) Nothing chapter limits remedies law equity available aggrieved student school.34 33-6607. PREEMPTION. chapter preempts law, regulation, pol-35 icy, decree enacted adopted city, county, municipality, political subdivision within state purports permit require public schools allow persons use facilities designated sex.39 SECTION 2. remaining portions section.2 (10) legislature finds declares that:3 (a) Biological sex objectively defined category obvious,4 immutable, distinguishable characteristics.5 (b) Gender dysphoria among pubescent children notwithstanding scientific evidence therapies cause irreversible sterility likely increase risks medical conditions, including cancer, cardiovascular disease,19 blood clots, osteoporosis, obesity.20 (e) healthcare providers refer pubescent adolescents sex reassignment surgeries permanently mutilate healthy reproductive organs body parts.23 (f) world professional association transgender health, pro-24 fessional organization publishes standards care treat-25 ing gender dysphoria, altogether removed age recommendations adolescent sex reassignment surgeries, including limited surgical castration, mastectomies, hysterectomies, genital recon-28 struction, despite known harms experimental nature perform-29 ing surgeries gender dysphoric children.30 (g) Recent science suggests medical interventions like surgeries cross-sex hormones significantly improve long-term health outcomes patients struggling gender dysphoria suicide rates, psychiatric morbidities, mortality rates remain markedly elevated background population inpatient gender reas-35 signment procedures performed.36 (h) long-term randomized studies evaluate efficacy safety use Synopsis: Malpractice regarding gender therapeutics. Allows claimant bring medical malpractice claim regarding gender transition treatment within 15 years individual becomes 21 years age. Effective: July 1, 2023. McGuire January 19, 2023, read first time referred Committee Public Health. 2023 1589—LS 7226/DI 149 Introduced First Regular Session 123rd General Assembly (2023) PRINTING CODE. No. 1637 Page 4 declared exist, reason whereof act shall take effect full force passage approval. 59-1-1637 EB 1/19/2023 11:54:09 IV 118TH CONGRESS 1ST SESSION H. RES. 115 Establishing Women’s Bill Rights reaffirm legal protections afforded women Federal law. HOUSE REPRESENTATIVES FEBRUARY 9, 2023 Mrs. LESKO (for herself, Mrs. HARSHBARGER, Mrs. MILLER Illinois, Mr. HERN, Ms. TENNEY, Mr. ADERHOLT, Mr. BIGGS, Mr. CLYDE, Mr. WEBER Texas, Mr. GUEST, Mr. SANTOS, Mr. OGLES, Ms. FOXX, Mr. NORMAN, Mr. OWENS, Mr. JACKSON Texas, Ms. HAGEMAN, Mr. DUNCAN) submitted following resolution; referred Committee Judiciary RESOLUTION Establishing Women’s Bill Rights reaffirm legal protections afforded women Federal law. Whereas males females possess unique immutable bi- ological differences manifest prior birth in- crease age experience puberty; Whereas biological differences sexes mean females may get pregnant, give birth, breastfeed children; Whereas biological differences sexes mean males are, average, larger size possess greater body strength females; VerDate Sep 11 2014 00:29 Feb 10, 2023 Jkt 039200 PO 00000 Frm 00001 Fmt 6652 Sfmt 6300 E:\BILLS\HR115.IH HR115pb n n K JL V W 7 X 2 P R w ith $ $ _ JO B 2 •HRES 115 IH Whereas biological differences sexes expose females harm males specific forms violence, including sexual violence; Whereas women achieved inspirational significant accomplishments education, athletics, employment; Whereas recent misguided court rulings related defini- tion ‘‘sex’’ led endangerment spaces re- sources dedicated women, thereby necessitating clari- fication certain terms: Now, therefore, Resolved, House Representatives reaf-1 firms that— 2 (1) purposes Federal law, person’s ‘‘sex’’ means biological sex (either male female) birth; 5 (2) purposes Federal law addressing sex, 6 terms ‘‘woman’’ ‘‘girl’’ refer human fe-7 males, terms ‘‘man’’ ‘‘boy’’ refer human males; 9 (3) purposes Federal law, word ‘‘mother’’ means parent female sex ‘‘fa-11 ther’’ defined parent male sex; No. 437 Page 1 STATE OKLAHOMA 1st Session 59th Legislature (2023) SENATE BILL 252 By: Dahm INTRODUCED Act relating health care; prohibiting certain medical treatment minors; providing penalty; defining term; providing codification; providing effective date. ENACTED PEOPLE STATE OKLAHOMA: SECTION 1. NEW LAW new section law codified Oklahoma Statutes Section 2607 Title 63, unless created duplication numbering, reads follows: A. person age eighteen (18) years prohibited undergoing gender reassignment medical treatment state. B. health care professional intentionally performs gender reassignment medical treatment person age eighteen (18) years subject professional discipline State Board Medical Licensure Supervision, State Board Osteopathic Examiners, applicable health care professional licensing board, including suspension revocation license certification required practice. Req. No. 437 Page 2 C. “Gender reassignment medical treatment” means health care facilitate transitioning patient’s assigned gender identity patient’s birth certificate, gender identity experienced defined patient. term shall include, limited to: 1. Interventions suppress development endogenous secondary sex characteristics; 2. Interventions align patient’s appearance physical body patient’s gender identity; 3. Interventions alleviate symptoms clinically significant distress resulting gender dysphoria, defined Diagnostic Statistical Manual Mental Disorders, 5th Edition. term include behavioral health care services, mental health counseling medications treat depression, anxiety, similar disorders, provided medication long-term altering effects gender minor. Synopsis: Gender transition procedures minors. Prohibits physician practitioner knowingly providing gender transition procedures individual less 18 years age (minor) intended alter gender minor delay puberty. Provides certain medical exceptions. Establishes civil enforcement actions. Effective: July 1, 2023. A.D. 2023 ____________ N C RELATING EDUCATION -- FAIRNESS WOMEN'S SPORTS ACT Introduced By: Senator E Morgan Date Introduced: February 16, 2023 Referred To: Senate Judiciary enacted General Assembly follows: SECTION 1. general assembly hereby finds that: 1 (1) "inherent differences men women," differences 2 "remain cause celebration, denigration members either sex artificial constraints individual's opportunity," United States v. Virginia, 518 U.S. 515, 533 (1996); 4 (2) "inherent differences" range chromosomal hormonal differences physiological differences; 6 (3) Men generally "denser, stronger bones, tendons, ligaments" "larger hearts, greater lung volume per body mass, higher red blood cell count, higher hemoglobin," Neel 8 Burton, Battle Sexes, Psychology Today (July 2, 2012); 9 (4) Men also higher natural levels testosterone, affects traits hemoglobin levels, body fat content, storage use carbohydrates, development type 2 muscle fibers, result men able generate higher speed power physical activity, Doriane Lambelet Coleman, Sex Sport, Law Contemporary 13 Problems 63, 74 (2017) (quoting Gina Kolata, Men, Women Speed. 2 Words: Got 14 Testosterone?, N.Y. Times (Aug. 21, 2008)); 15 (5) biological differences females males, especially relates natural levels testosterone, "explain male female secondary sex characteristics develop puberty lifelong effects, including important success sport: categorically different strength, speed, endurance," Doriane Lambelet Coleman Wickliffe 19 LC001518 - Page 2 5 Shreve, "Comparing Athletic Performances: Best Elite Women Boys Men," Duke Law 1 Center Sports Law Policy; 2 (6) classifications based sex generally disfavored, Supreme Court recognized "sex classifications may used compensate women particular economic disabilities [they have] suffered, promote equal employment opportunity, [and] advance full development talent capacities Nation's people," United States v. Virginia, 518 6 U.S. 515, 533 (1996); 7 (7) One place sex classifications allow "full development talent capacities Nation's people" context sports athletics; 9 (8) Courts recognized inherent, physiological differences males females result different athletic capabilities. See e.g. Kleczek v. Rhode Island Interscholastic 11 League, Inc., 612 A.2d 734, 738 (R.I. 1992) ("Because innate physiological differences, boys girls similarly situated enter athletic competition.");Petrie v. Ill. High Sch. Ass'n, 13 394 N.E.2d 855, 861 (Ill. App. Ct. 1979) (noting "high school boys [generally possess physiological advantages over] girl counterparts" advantages give unfair lead girls sports like "high school track"); 16 (9) recent study female male Olympic performances since 1983 found that, although athletes sexes improved time span, "gender gap" female male performances remained stable. "These suggest women's performances high level never match men." Valerie Thibault et al., Women men sport performance: 20 gender gap evolved since 1983, 9 Journal Sports Science Medicine 214, 219 21 (2010); 22 (10) Duke law professor All-American track athlete Doriane Coleman, tennis champion Martina Navratilova, Olympic track gold medalist Sanya Richards-Ross recently wrote: "The evidence unequivocal starting puberty, every sport except sailing, shooting, riding, always significant numbers boys men would beat best girls women head-to-head competition. Claims contrary simply denial science," 27 Doriane Coleman, Martina Navratilova, et al., Pass Equality Act, Abandon Title IX, 28 Washington Post (Apr. 29, 2019); 29 (11) benefits natural testosterone provides male athletes diminished use puberty blockers cross-sex hormones. recent study impact treatments found even "after twelve (12) months hormonal therapy," man identifies woman taking cross-sex hormones "had absolute advantage" female athletes 33 "will still likely performance benefits" women, Tommy Lundberg et al., "Muscle 34 LC001518 - Page 3 strength, size composition following twelve (12) months gender-affirming treatment transgender individuals: retained advantage transwomen," Karolinksa Institutet (Sept. 26, 2 2019); 3 (12) separate sex-specific teams furthers efforts promote sex equality. Sex-4 specific teams accomplish providing opportunities female athletes demonstrate skill, strength, athletic abilities also providing opportunities obtain recognition accolades, college scholarships, numerous long-term benefits flow success athletic endeavors. 8 SECTION 2. WHEREAS, Male female individuals possess unique immutable biological differences manifest prior birth increase individuals age experience puberty; WHEREAS, Biological differences sexes mean female individuals able become pregnant, give birth breastfeed children; WHEREAS, Biological differences sexes mean male individuals are, average, bigger, stronger faster female individuals; WHEREAS, Biological differences sexes leave female individuals physically vulnerable male individuals specific forms violence, including sexual violence; WHEREAS, Female individuals historically suffered discrimination education, athletics employment; WHEREAS, Biological differences sexes enduring may, circumstances, warrant creation separate social, educational, athletics spaces order ensure safety allow members sex succeed thrive; WHEREAS, Inconsistencies court rulings policy initiatives respect definitions "sex," "male," "female," "man" "woman" led endangerment single-sex spaces resources thereby necessitating clarification certain terms. Now, therefore: enacted Legislature State Kansas: Section 1. (a) Notwithstanding provision state law contrary, respect application individual's biological sex pursuant state law rules regulations, following shall apply: (1) individual's "sex" means individual's biological sex, either male female, birth; (2) "female" individual whose biological reproductive system developed produce ova, "male" individual whose biological reproductive system developed fertilize ova SB 180 2 female; (3) terms "woman" "girl" refer human females, terms "man" "boy" refer human males; (4) term "mother" means parent female sex, term "father" means parent male sex; (5) respect biological sex, term "equal" mean "same" "identical"; (6) respect biological sex, separate accommodations inherently unequal. (b) Laws rules regulations distinguish sexes subject intermediate constitutional scrutiny. Intermediate constitutional scrutiny forbids unfair discrimination similarly situated male female individuals allows law distinguish sexes distinctions substantially related important governmental objectives. Notwithstanding provision state law contrary, distinctions sexes respect athletics, prisons detention facilities, domestic violence shelters, rape crisis centers, locker rooms, restrooms areas biology, safety privacy implicated result separate accommodations substantially related important governmental objectives protecting health, safety privacy individuals circumstances. (c) school district, public school thereof, state agency, department office political subdivision collects vital statistics purpose complying anti-discrimination laws purpose gathering accurate public health, crime, economic data shall identify individual part collected data set either male female birth. Original section 38-179, Revised Statutes Cumulative2 Supplement, 2022, repealed.3 LB574 2023 LB574 2023 -8- Session 2023 HOUSE BILL No. 2404 Committee Federal State Affairs 2-10 ACT concerning environmental, social governance standards involving contracts, investments business practices; relating ideological boycotts discriminatory conduct; enacting Kansas protection pensions businesses ideological interference act; directing board trustees Kansas public employees retirement system divest investments entities engaged ideological boycotts; establishing conditions procedures divestment; requiring state treasurer publish list financial companies financial institutions engaged ideological boycotts; authorizing state treasurer disqualify listed financial institutions receiving deposit state moneys; prohibiting governmental contracts without written verification contractor engaged ideological boycotts; directing fiduciaries governmental plans provide retirement benefits, defer employee income invest taxpayer moneys act financial interest plans; requiring registered investment advisers make certain disclosures clients obtain written consent clients prior investing client funds investments engaged ideological boycotts; providing civil criminal penalties; amending K.S.A. 75-4208 K.S.A. 2022 Supp. 40-2404 repealing existing sections. enacted Legislature State Kansas: New Section 1. (a) provisions sections 1 29, amendments thereto, shall known may cited Kansas protection pensions businesses ideological interference act. (b) used act: (1) "Act" means Kansas protection pensions businesses ideological interference act. (2) "Banking contract" means contract entered treasurer pooled money investment board financial institution pursuant article 42 chapter 75 Kansas Statutes Annotated, amendments thereto, receive deposit state moneys operating accounts investment accounts. (3) "Board" means board trustees Kansas public employees retirement system. (4) "Company" means organization, association, corporation, HB 2404 2 partnership, joint venture, limited partnership, limited liability partnership, limited liability company entity business association, including wholly owned subsidiary, majority-owned subsidiary, parent company affiliate entities business associations exists purpose making profit. (5) "Direct holdings" means, respect financial company, securities financial company held directly system account fund system owns shares interests. (6) "Financial company" means publicly traded financial services, banking investment company. (7) "Financial institution" means bank, national banking association, trust company, savings loan association, building loan association, mutual savings bank, credit union, payment processor savings bank. (8) "Financial services company" means financial institution, insurance company company provides investment services. (9) "Fossil fuels" means coal, natural gas oil. (10) "Governmental entity" means: (A) state Kansas political subdivision thereof, including, limited to, county, city, municipality, agency, airport authority, community mental health center, drainage district, groundwater management district, hospital district, housing authority, metropolitan transit authority, port authority, public building commission, rural water district, school district township; (B) school, college, university, administration, authority enterprise operated state political subdivision thereof. (11) "Governmental plan" means plan, fund program established, provided maintained governmental entity to: (A) Provide retirement income retirement benefits employees former employees; (B) defer income employees period time extending termination covered employment beyond; (C) invest taxpayer money purpose. (12) "Ideological boycott" means, without ordinary business purpose, refusing deal with, refusing limiting investment in, terminating business activities otherwise taking commercial action intended penalize, inflict economic harm on, limit commercial relations change limit activities company company, without violating controlling state federal law: (A) Engages exploration, production, utilization, transportation, sale manufacturing fossil fuel-based energy commit pledge meet environmental standards beyond applicable federal state law; HB 2404 3 (B) engages exploration, production, utilization, transportation, sale manufacturing nuclear energy commit pledge meet environmental standards beyond applicable federal state law; (C) engages production agriculture; (D) engages production lumber; (E) engages mining; (F) engages exploration, production, utilization, transportation, sale manufacturing natural resource; (G) emits greenhouse gases disclose offset greenhouse gas emissions; (H) engages, facilitates supports manufacture, import, distribution, marketing, advertising, lawful use sale firearms, ammunition component parts accessories firearms ammunition; (I) meet, expected meet commit meet environmental standards disclosure criteria, particular eliminate, reduce, offset disclose greenhouse gas emissions; (J) governed corporate board officers whose race, ethnicity, sex sexual orientation meets meet criterion; (K) facilitate assist employees obtaining abortions, assisted suicide gender reassignment services; (L) engages with, facilitates, employs, supports, business with, represents advocates company described subparagraphs (A) (K). (13) "Indirect holdings" means, respect financial company, securities financial company held account fund, mutual fund, managed one persons employed system, owns shares interests together investors subject provisions act. "Indirect holdings" include money invested plan described sections 401(k) 457 federal internal revenue code. (14) "Insurance company" means defined K.S.A. 40- 201, amendments thereto. (15) "Listed financial company" means financial company listed treasurer pursuant section 7, amendments thereto. (16) "Natural resources" means fossil fuels, minerals, metal ores nonrenewable finite resource cannot readily replaced natural means speed consumed. (17) "Nonpecuniary factor" means factor intended promote environmental, governance, ideological, political, social nontraditional goal standard. (18) (A) "Ordinary business purpose" means purpose directly related to: HB 2404 4 (i) Promoting financial success stability financial institution; (ii) mitigating risk financial institution; (iii) complying legal regulatory requirements; (iv) limiting liability financial institution. (B) "Ordinary business purpose" mean purpose social, political ideological interests. company may reasonably determined taken action considered factor purpose social, political ideological interests based upon evidence indicating purpose included in, limited to: (i) Branding, advertising, statements, explanations, reports, letters clients, communications portfolio companies, statements principles commitments; (ii) participating in, affiliation status signatory coalition, initiative, joint statement principles agreement. (19) "Person" means natural person, partnership, association, joint stock company, trust corporation. (20) "Registered investment adviser" means investment adviser provides financial investment advice clients registered either United States securities exchange commission state Kansas Kansas uniform securities act, both. (21) "Restricted financial institution" means financial institution included recently updated restricted financial institution list. (22) "Restricted financial institution list" means list financial institutions prepared, maintained published treasurer pursuant section 15, amendments thereto. (23) "Security" means note, stock, treasury stock, security future, bond, debenture, evidence indebtedness, certificate interest participation profit-sharing agreement, collateral-trust certificate, preorganization certificate subscription, transferable share, investment contract, voting-trust certificate, certificate deposit security, fractional undivided interest oil, gas mineral rights, put, call, straddle, option privilege security, including certificate deposit, group index securities, including interest therein based value thereof, put, call, straddle, option privilege entered national securities exchange relating foreign currency or, general, interest instrument commonly known "security," certificate interest participation in, temporary interim certificate for, receipt for, guarantee of, warrant right subscribe purchase foregoing. (24) "Social credit score" means rating, scoring, analysis, assessment, list, standard, guidance, criterion tabulation includes, without violating controlling state federal law, negative assessment HB 2404 5 whether person engaging following lawful activities within state: (A) committing pledging meet environmental standards beyond applicable state federal law exploration, production, utilization, transportation, sale manufacturing fossil fuel-based energy, nuclear energy, agriculture, timber, mining natural resource; (B) emitting greenhouse gases refusing disclose, reduce offset greenhouse gas emissions; (C) meeting, expecting meet committing meet environmental goals, including emissions, standards disclosures; (D) meeting, expecting meet committing meet corporate board company employment composition goals, including standards disclosures based upon characteristics protected K.S.A. 44-1001 et seq., amendments thereto; (E) manufacturing, distribution sale firearms, firearms accessories, ammunition ammunition components; (F) governing corporate board officers whose race, ethnicity, sex sexual orientation meets meet criterion; (G) refusing facilitate assist employees obtaining abortions, assisted suicide gender reassignment services; (H) exercising person's freedom speech protected either first amendment constitution United States section 11 Kansas bill rights, financial services company considered state actor, including person's political opinions, political speech, political donations, political affiliations expressive activities; (I) exercising person's free exercise religion protected first amendment constitution United States, federal religious freedom restoration act 1993, section 7 Kansas bill rights Kansas preservation religious freedom act, financial services company considered state actor, including aspects person's religious observance practice, well belief affiliation; (J) engaging with, facilitating of, employing by, supporting of, business with, representing advocating person business person described subparagraphs (A) (I). (25) "System" means Kansas public employees retirement system. (26) "Treasurer" means state treasurer. New Sec. 6. treasurer board may rely financial company's response notice communication made act without conducting investigation, research inquiry. HB 2404 7 New Sec. 7. (a) treasurer shall prepare, maintain provide board list financial companies engage ideological boycotts. list shall known restricted financial company list. maintaining list, treasurer may: (1) Review rely publicly available information regarding financial companies, appropriate treasurer's sole discretion, including information provided state, nonprofit organizations, research firms, international organizations governmental entities; (2) request written verification financial company company engage ideological boycotts. (b) financial company fails provide treasurer written verification subsection (a)(2) 31st day receiving request treasurer presumed engaged ideological boycott. (c) determining whether include financial company restricted financial company list, treasurer shall consider, limited to, following: (1) financial company's certification engaged ideological boycotts; (2) publicly available statements information made financial company, including statements member financial company's governing body, executive director financial company officer employee financial company authority issue policy statements behalf financial company; (3) information published state federal governmental entity. (d) determining whether include financial company restricted financial company list, treasurer shall rely solely following: (1) Statements complaints boycotted company; (2) media reports financial company's ideological boycott. (e) financial company shall compelled produce disclose data information deemed confidential, privileged otherwise protected disclosure state federal law. (f) financial company treasurer determines engaged ideological boycott, treasurer shall send written notice financial company least 45 days prior including financial company restricted financial company list. written notice shall state that: (1) treasurer determined financial company restricted financial company; (2) financial company placed restricted financial company list 45 days unless, within 30 days following receipt written notice, restricted financial company demonstrates HB 2404 8 financial company engaged ideological boycott; (3) restricted financial list published treasurer's website sent board, president senate, speaker house representatives attorney general. (g) Following restricted financial company's inclusion restricted financial company list, treasurer shall remove financial company list financial company demonstrates financial company ceased ideological boycotts. (h) treasurer shall update list annually often treasurer considers necessary, often quarterly, based information sources listed subsection (a), among sources. (i) later 30th day date list financial companies engage ideological boycotts first provided board updated, treasurer shall file list president senate, speaker house representatives attorney general post list treasurer's website location easily accessible public. treasurer shall include top list citation section, brief summary purpose list statement inclusion list indication unsafe unsound operating conditions financial institution risk consumer deposits. Sec. 30. K.S.A. 40-2404 hereby amended read follows: 40- 2404. following hereby defined unfair methods competition unfair deceptive acts practices business insurance: (1) Misrepresentations false advertising insurance policies. Making, issuing, circulating causing made, issued circulated, estimate, illustration, circular, statement, sales presentation, omission comparison that: (a) Misrepresents benefits, advantages, conditions terms insurance policy; (b) misrepresents dividends share surplus received insurance policy; (c) makes false misleading statements dividends share surplus previously paid insurance policy; (d) misleading misrepresentation financial condition person, legal reserve system upon life insurer operates; (e) uses name title insurance policy class insurance policies misrepresenting true nature thereof; (f) misrepresentation purpose inducing tending induce lapse, forfeiture, exchange, conversion surrender insurance policy; (g) misrepresentation purpose effecting pledge assignment effecting loan insurance policy; (h) misrepresents insurance policy shares stock. (2) False information advertising generally. Making, publishing, disseminating, circulating placing public, causing, directly indirectly, made, published, disseminated, circulated placed public, newspaper, magazine publication, HB 2404 18 form notice, circular, pamphlet, letter poster, radio television station, way, advertisement, announcement statement containing assertion, misrepresentation statement respect business insurance respect person conduct person's insurance business, untrue, deceptive misleading. (3) Defamation. Making, publishing, disseminating circulating, directly indirectly, aiding, abetting encouraging making, publishing, disseminating circulating oral written statement pamphlet, circular, article literature false, maliciously critical derogatory financial condition person, calculated injure person. (4) Boycott, coercion intimidation. Entering agreement commit, concerted action committing, act boycott, coercion intimidation resulting tending result unreasonable restraint business insurance, act boycott, coercion intimidation monopolizing attempting monopolize part business insurance. (5) False statements entries. (a) Knowingly filing supervisory public official, knowingly making, publishing, disseminating, circulating delivering person, placing public, knowingly causing directly indirectly, made, published, disseminated, circulated, delivered person, placed public, false material statement fact financial condition person. (b) Knowingly making false entry material fact book, report statement person knowingly omitting make true entry material fact pertaining business person book, report statement person. (6) Stock operations advisory board contracts. Issuing delivering permitting agents, officers employees issue deliver, agency company stock capital stock, benefit certificates shares common-law corporation, securities special advisory board contracts contracts kind promising returns profits inducement insurance. Nothing herein shall prohibit acts permitted K.S.A. 40-232, amendments thereto. (7) Unfair discrimination. (a) Making permitting unfair discrimination individuals class equal expectation life rates charged contract life insurance life annuity dividends benefits payable thereon, terms conditions contract. (b) Making permitting unfair discrimination individuals class essentially hazard HB 2404 19 amount premium, policy fees rates charged policy contract accident health insurance benefits payable thereunder, terms conditions contract, manner whatever. (c) Refusing insure, refusing continue insure, limiting amount, extent kind coverage available individual, charging individual different rate coverage solely blindness partial blindness. respect conditions, including underlying cause blindness partial blindness, persons blind partially blind shall subject standards sound actuarial principles actual reasonably anticipated experience sighted persons. Refusal insure includes denial insurer disability insurance coverage grounds policy defines "disability" presumed event insured loses person's eyesight. However, insurer may exclude coverage disabilities consisting solely blindness partial blindness condition existed time policy issued. (d) Refusing insure, refusing continue insure, limiting amount, extent kind coverage available accident health life insurance applicant proposed insured charge different rate coverage excluding limiting coverage losses denying claim incurred insured result abuse based fact applicant proposed insured is, been, may subject domestic abuse, except provided subsection (7) (d)(v). "Abuse" used paragraph means one acts defined K.S.A. 60-3102, amendments thereto, family members, current former household members, current former intimate partners. (i) insurer may ask applicant life accident health insurance proposed insured individual is, may subject domestic abuse seeks, sought reason seek medical psychological treatment counseling specifically abuse, protection abuse shelter abuse. (ii) Nothing section shall construed prohibit person declining issue insurance policy insuring life individual is, potential subject abuse perpetrator abuse applicant would owner insurance policy.
