SECTION 5.If section, subsection, paragraph, subparagraph, sentence, clause, phrase, word act reason held unconstitutional invalid, holding shall affect constitutionality validity remaining portions act, General Assembly hereby declaring would passed act, every section, subsection, paragraph, subparagraph, sentence, clause, phrase, word thereof, irrespective fact one sections, subsections, paragraphs, subparagraphs, sentences, clauses, phrases, words hereof may declared unconstitutional, invalid, otherwise ineffective. SECTION 6.This act takes effect upon approval Governor. ----XX---- web page last updated December 08, 2022 07:30 PM MISSISSIPPI LEGISLATURE 2023 Regular Session To: Judiciary B By: Representative Shanks House Bill 1480 ACT ESTABLISH "PARENTS' BILL RIGHTS ACT 2023"; DEFINE TERMINOLOGY USED HEREIN; ESTABLISH PARENT'S LIBERTY DIRECT UPBRINGING, EDUCATION, HEALTH CARE MENTAL HEALTH CHILD FUNDAMENTAL RIGHT; PROHIBIT STATE POLITICAL SUBDIVISION THEREOF SUBSTANTIALLY BURDENING PARENT'S FUNDAMENTAL RIGHT WITHOUT DEMONSTRATING BURDEN REQUIRED COMPELLING GOVERNMENTAL INTEREST; PROVIDE PARENTAL RIGHTS EXCLUSIVELY RESERVED PARENT CHILD WITHOUT OBSTRUCTION INTERFERENCE STATE POLITICAL SUBDIVISION THEREOF; PROVIDE ABUSE NEGLECT CHILD PARENT ACTION DECISION PARENT WOULD END LIFE AUTHORIZED ACT; PROHIBIT EMPLOYEES STATE POLITICAL SUBDIVISION THEREOF, EXCEPT LAW ENFORCEMENT PERSONNEL, ENCOURAGING COERCING CHILD WITHHOLD INFORMATION CHILD'S PARENT; PROHIBIT EMPLOYEES WITHHOLDING INFORMATION RELEVANT CHILD'S PHYSICAL, EMOTIONAL MENTAL HEALTH CHILD'S PARENT; REQUIRE BOARD EDUCATION SCHOOL DISTRICT DEVELOP ADOPT POLICY PROMOTE INVOLVEMENT PARENTS CHILDREN ENROLLED DISTRICT'S SCHOOLS; PRESCRIBE MINIMUM REQUIREMENT PROCEDURES ADDRESSED POLICY; PROVIDE BOARD EDUCATION SCHOOL DISTRICT DISCRETION ADOPT POLICY PROVIDE PARENTS INFORMATION ELECTRONIC FORM; REQUIRE PARENTS SUBMIT WRITTEN ELECTRONIC REQUEST CHILD'S INFORMATION SCHOOL PRINCIPAL SUPERINTENDENT SCHOOL DISTRICT; REQUIRE SCHOOL PRINCIPAL SUPERINTENDENT PROVIDE REQUESTED INFORMATION PARENTS WITHIN TEN DAYS RECEIVING REQUEST, SUBMIT PARENT WRITTEN EXPLANATION REASONS DENIAL REQUESTED INFORMATION; PRESCRIBE PROCESS PARENT MAY SUBMIT FORMAL CONSIDERATION REQUEST INFORMATION SCHOOL BOARD REQUESTED INFORMATION RECEIVED FIVE DAYS SUBMITTING INITIAL REQUEST; ESTABLISH CAUSE ACTION VIOLATION ACT; PROVIDE ACT SHALL SERVE DEFENSE CAUSE ACTION RAISED RESULT VIOLATION THEREOF; PROVIDE RULES CONSTRUCTION SHALL PROVIDE BROAD PROTECTION PARENT'S FUNDAMENTAL RIGHTS INALIENABLE UNLESS RIGHTS LEGALLY WAIVED LEGALLY TERMINATED; AMEND SECTION 37-3-49, MISSISSIPPI CODE 1972, PROVIDE PARENT PUBLIC SCHOOL STUDENT RIGHT RECEIVE EFFECTIVE COMMUNICATION SCHOOL PRINCIPAL MANNER INSTRUCTIONAL MATERIALS USED IMPLEMENT SCHOOL'S CURRICULAR OBJECTIVES; AMEND SECTION 37-13-173, MISSISSIPPI CODE 1972, PROVIDE PARENTS AUTHORITY OPT CHILDREN INSTRUCTION SCHOOL DISTRICT'S COMPREHENSIVE HEALTH EDUCATION RELATING SEX EDUCATION UPON SUBMITTING WRITTEN REQUEST SCHOOL PRINCIPAL; AMEND SECTION 37-15-3, MISSISSIPPI CODE 1972, PROVIDE STUDENT PARENTAL RIGHTS EDUCATION RECORDS CREATED, MAINTAINED, USED PUBLIC EDUCATIONAL INSTITUTIONS AGENCIES SHALL PROTECTED; STIPULATE STUDENTS PARENTS MAINTAIN RIGHT ACCESS STUDENT'S EDUCATIONAL RECORDS, WAIVE ACCESS RECORDS, CHALLENGE CONTENT RECORDS, PRIVACY RECORDS RECEIVE ANNUAL NOTICE RIGHTS RECORDS; ENACTED LEGISLATURE STATE MISSISSIPPI: SECTION 1. act shall known may cited "Parents' Bill Rights Act 2023." SECTION 2. used act, following terms shall meaning ascribed section unless context usage requires otherwise: (a) "Child" means individual age eighteen (18). term include child adjudicated legally emancipated minor accordance state law court competent jurisdiction. (b) "Curriculum" includes textbooks, reading materials, handouts, videos, presentations, digital materials, websites, online applications, digital applications phone, laptop tablet, questionnaires, surveys, written electronic materials assigned, distributed otherwise presented physically virtually students class course. (c) "Educational records" includes attendance records, test scores school-administered tests state-wide assessments, grades, extracurricular activity club participation, e-mail accounts, online virtual accounts data, disciplinary records, counseling records, psychological records, applications admission, health immunization information including medical records maintained health clinic medical facility operated controlled school district located district property, teacher counselor evaluations, reports behavioral patterns. (d) "Parent" means biological parent child, adoptive parent child, individual granted exclusive right, guardianship authority welfare child state law. (f) "Parent" means biological parent child, adoptive parent child, individual granted exclusive right authority welfare child state law. (g) "Sex" means biological sex based chromosomal structure anatomy birth. (h) "Substantial burden" means action directly indirectly constrains, inhibits, curtails, denies right parent direct upbringing, education, health care mental health parent's child, compels action contrary right parent direct upbringing, education, health care mental health parent's child. term includes, limited to, withholding benefits, assessing criminal, civil administrative penalties damages, exclusion governmental assistance programs. (i) "Syllabus" means written description topics subjects taught class course, shall include list curriculum used class course, identity individuals providing in-person live remote instruction class course, description assemblies, guest lectures, field trips educational activities part class course. (j) "Teacher training materials" means presentations, videos, professional development classes educational training activities, including written electronic materials used distributed activities, teacher required attend public school. SECTION 3. Parental Rights Fundamental. (1) Legislature finds parents liberty interest, precious property interest, care, custody management children parental rights matter fundamental constitutional significance. rights include, limited to, liberty parents direct upbringing, education, health care, mental health parent's child. Legislature finds important information relating child withheld, either inadvertently purposefully, parent, including information relating child's health, well-being, education, child custody school district charter school. Legislature finds necessary establish consistent mechanism parents notified information relating health well-being children. (2) state, political subdivision state, governmental entity, governing body, officer, employee agent thereof shall substantially burden fundamental right parent direct upbringing, education, health care, mental health parent's child without demonstrating burden required compelling governmental interest applied parent child least restrictive means furthering compelling governmental interest. SECTION 4. Rights Responsibilities. (1) parental rights exclusively reserved parent child without substantial burden interference state, political subdivision state, governmental entity institution, including without limitation, following rights responsibilities: (a) direct education child, including right choose public, private, religious home schools, right make reasonable choices within public schools education child; (b) access review written electronic educational records relating child controlled possession school, including, limited to: (i) Attendance records; (ii) Test scores school-administered tests state-wide assessments; (iii) Grades; (iv) Extracurricular activity club participation; (v) child's e-mail accounts; (vi) child's online virtual accounts data; (vii) Disciplinary records; (viii) Counseling records; (ix) Psychological records; (x) Applications admission; (xi) Health immunization information, including medical records maintained health clinic medical facility operated controlled school district located district property; (xii) Teacher counselor evaluations; (xiii) Reports behavioral patterns. (c) direct upbringing child; (d) direct moral religious training child; (e) make consent writing physical mental health care decisions child; (f) access review health medical records child; (g) consent writing biometric scan child made, shared stored; (h) consent writing record child's blood deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) created, stored shared, unless authorized pursuant court order; (i) consent writing governmental entity makes video voice recording child, unless video voice recording made part of: (i) court proceeding; (ii) law enforcement investigation; (iii) forensic interview criminal Department Child Protection Services investigation; (iv) security surveillance buildings grounds; (v) photo identification card; (j) notified promptly employee state, political subdivision state, governmental entity institution suspects abuse, neglect criminal offense committed child. paragraph create new obligation school districts charter schools report misconduct students school, fighting aggressive play, routinely addressed pursuant school disciplinary procedures; (k) opt child personal analysis, evaluation, survey data collection school district would capture data inclusion state longitudinal student data system except necessary essential establish student's educational record; (l) right child excused school attendance religious purposes; (m) right participate parent-teacher associations school organizations sanctioned board education school district. (2) section shall construed to: (a) Authorize allow parent abuse neglect child defined Section 43-21-105; (b) Apply parental action decision would end life; (c) Prohibit court competent jurisdiction issuing order otherwise permitted law; (d) Prohibit judge officer court competent jurisdiction, law enforcement agent Department Child Protective Services acting within official capacity within reasonable prudent scope authority. (3) employee state, political subdivision state, governmental entity, except law enforcement personnel, shall encourage coerce child withhold information child's parent. shall employee withhold child's parent information relevant physical, emotional mental health child information regarding child's curricular extracurricular projects, assignments activities. (4) employee state, political subdivisions, governmental entity, law enforcement personnel, encourages coerces, attempts encourage coerce, child withhold information parent may subject disciplinary action. SECTION 5. Educational Involvement. (1) board education school district, consultation parents, teachers administrators, shall develop adopt policy promote involvement parents children enrolled schools within school district, including: (a) plan parent participation schools designed improve parent teacher cooperation areas homework, attendance discipline; (b) Procedures parent may learn course study parent's child review curriculum. procedures shall allow parent to: (i) Review syllabus class course parent's child enrolled least seven (7) days start class course; (ii) Review curriculum class course offered school teacher training materials least three (3) days curriculum materials taught used instruction presented students format conspicuously identifies added curriculum; (iii) Copy record information curriculum teacher training materials; (iv) Review supplemental educational materials including source, sponsor, funding materials; (v) Meet teacher class course, principal, representative school discuss curriculum teaching training materials. (c) Procedures parent objects specific instruction presentation may withdraw parent's child instruction presentation basis material activity questions beliefs practices regarding sex, morality, religion. school district charter school may impose academic penalty upon child withdrawn pursuant section. section shall exempt child satisfying grade-level graduation requirements; (d) Procedures parent may learn nature purpose clubs extracurricular activities approved school may withdraw parent's child club extracurricular parent objects; (e) Procedures parent must provide written consent school district charter school employee agent thereof provides, procures, solicits, arranges performance of, provides referral for, performs mental health counselling treatment parent's child; (f) Procedures parent must provide written consent child uses name nickname legal name, child uses pronoun align child's sex; (g) Procedures parent may learn parental rights responsibilities laws state; (h) Procedures parents made aware rights Family Educational Rights Privacy Act (FERPA) 20 USCS Section 1232g, regulations promulgated thereunder relating parents' access children's official records. (2) parental rights procedures provided herein shall construed to: (a) Compel officers, administrators, employees, teachers, agents volunteers school district charter school students school district charter school use pronouns align child's sex otherwise infringe upon person's sincerely held religious belief even child's parent provided written consent provided herein; (b) Permit child use bathroom, locker room, changing facilities, overnight lodging accommodations align child's sex, require school district charter school allow otherwise adopt policy permit child use bathrooms, locker rooms, changing facilities, overnight lodging accommodations reserved opposite sex; (c) Permit child compete interscholastic intramural athletic team sport designated opposite sex, shall governed Section 37-97-1 et seq. (3) school district charter school shall publish procedures required section school district charter school's publicly available website. (4) board education school district may adopt policy provide parents information required section electronic form. (5) parent shall submit written electronic request information pursuant section either school principal superintendent school district. Within five (5) business days receiving request information, school principal superintendent shall either deliver requested information parent submit parent written explanation reasons denial requested information. request information denied parent receive requested information within allotted five (5) business days, parent may submit written request information governing board school district charter school, shall formally consider rule request executive session next meeting board. late parent's request agenda next meeting, request must included agenda subsequent meeting governing board. (6) aggrieved decision governing board school district charter school, parent may appeal decision Chancery Court County school district charter school located. SECTION 6. Cause Action. (1) parent may bring suit violation act may raise act defense judicial administrative proceeding without regard whether proceeding brought name state government, private person party. (2) Notwithstanding provision law, action act may commenced, relief may granted, without regard whether person commencing action sought exhausted available administrative remedies. (3) person successfully asserts claim defense act may recover declaratory relief, injunctive relief prevent remedy violation act effects violation, compensatory damages, reasonable attorneys' fees costs, appropriate relief. (4) Sovereign, governmental qualified immunities suit liability waived abolished extent liability created act. SECTION 7. Rules Construction. (1) Unless rights legally waived legally terminated, parents inalienable rights comprehensive listed section. protections fundamental right parents direct upbringing, education, health care mental health child afforded act addition protections provided federal law, state law, state federal constitutions. (2) act shall construed favor broad protection fundamental right parents direct upbringing, education, health care mental health child. (3) Nothing act shall construed authorize government burden fundamental right parents direct upbringing, education, health care mental health child. (4) child affirmative right access particular medical mental health procedure service, nothing act shall construed grant child's parent affirmative right access procedure service child's behalf. (5) provision act held invalid unenforceable terms, applied person circumstance, shall construed give maximum effect permitted law, unless holding shall one utter invalidity unenforceability, event provision shall deemed severable, shall affect remainder hereof application provision other, dissimilar circumstances. SECTION 12. Section 37-13-171, Mississippi Code 1972, brought forward follows: 37-13-171. (1) local school board every public school district shall adopt policy implement abstinence-only abstinence-plus education curriculum June 30, 2012, instruction subjects shall implemented later start 2012-2013 school year local school board shall adopt program developed Mississippi Department Human Services Mississippi Department Health. (3) program instruction sex-related education need include every component listed subsection (2) section abstinence-only education. Section 43-21-105, Mississippi Code 1972, brought forward follows: 43-21-105. following words phrases, purposes chapter, shall meanings ascribed herein unless context clearly otherwise requires: (a) "Youth court" means Youth Court Division. (b) "Judge" means judge Youth Court Division. (c) "Designee" means person judge appoints perform duty chapter requires done judge designee. judge may appoint person involved law enforcement employee Mississippi Department Human Services Mississippi Department Child Protection Services designee. (d) "Child" "youth" synonymous, means person reached eighteenth birthday. child reached eighteenth birthday active duty branch armed services married considered "child" "youth" purposes chapter. (e) "Parent" means father mother child born, father mother child legally adopted. (f) "Guardian" means court-appointed guardian person child. (g) "Custodian" means person present care custody child whether person parent otherwise. (h) "Legal custodian" means court-appointed custodian child. (i) "Delinquent child" means child reached tenth birthday committed delinquent act. (j) "Delinquent act" act, committed adult, designated crime state federal law, municipal county ordinance offenses punishable life imprisonment death. delinquent act includes escape lawful detention violations Uniform Controlled Substances Law violent behavior. (k) "Child need supervision" means child reached seventh birthday need treatment rehabilitation child: (i) habitually disobedient reasonable lawful commands parent, guardian custodian ungovernable; (ii) required attend school, willfully habitually violates rules thereof willfully habitually absents therefrom; (iii) Runs away home without good cause; (iv) committed delinquent act acts. (l) "Neglected child" means child: (i) Whose parent, guardian custodian person responsible care support, neglects refuses, able do, provide proper necessary care support, education required law, medical, surgical, care necessary well-being; however, parent withholds medical treatment child good faith treatment spiritual means alone prayer accordance tenets practices recognized church religious denomination duly accredited practitioner thereof shall not, reason alone, considered neglectful provision chapter; (ii) otherwise without proper care, custody, supervision support; (iii) Who, reason, lacks special care made necessary reason mental condition, whether mental condition mental illness intellectual disability; (iv) Who, reason, lacks care necessary health, morals well-being. (m) "Abused child" means child whose parent, guardian custodian person responsible care support, whether legally obligated not, caused allowed caused, upon child, sexual abuse, sexual exploitation, commercial sexual exploitation, emotional abuse, mental injury, nonaccidental physical injury maltreatment. However, physical discipline, including spanking, performed child parent, guardian custodian reasonable manner shall deemed abuse section. "Abused child" also means child trafficked within meaning Mississippi Human Trafficking Act person, without regard relationship person child. (n) "Sexual abuse" means obscene pornographic photographing, filming depiction children commercial purposes, rape, molestation, incest, prostitution forms sexual exploitation children circumstances indicate child's health welfare harmed threatened. (o) "A child need special care" means child mental physical illness cannot treated dispositional alternatives ordinarily available youth court. (p) "dependent child" means child child need supervision, delinquent child, abused child neglected child, child voluntarily placed custody Department Child Protection Services parent, guardian custodian. (q) "Custody" means physical possession child person. (r) "Legal custody" means legal status created court order gives legal custodian responsibilities physical possession child duty provide food, shelter, education reasonable medical care, subject residual rights responsibilities parent guardian person. (s) "Detention" means care children physically restrictive facilities. (t) "Shelter" means care children physically nonrestrictive facilities. (u) "Records involving children" means following child identified: (i) youth court records defined Section 43-21-251; (ii) forensic interviews conducted child advocacy center abuse neglect investigations; (iii) law enforcement records defined Section 43-21-255; (iv) agency records defined Section 43-21-257; (v) documents maintained representative state, county, municipality public agency insofar relate apprehension, custody, adjudication disposition child subject youth court cause. (v) "Any person responsible care support" means person providing child given time. term shall include, limited to, stepparents, foster parents, relatives, nonlicensed babysitters similar persons responsible child staff residential care facilities group homes licensed Department Human Services Department Child Protection Services. (w) singular includes plural, plural singular masculine feminine consistent intent chapter. (x) "Out-of-home" setting means temporary supervision care children staff licensed day care centers, staff public, private state schools, staff juvenile detention facilities, staff unlicensed residential care facilities group homes staff of, individuals representing, churches, civic social organizations. (y) "Durable legal custody" means legal status created court order gives durable legal custodian responsibilities physical possession child duty provide care, nurture, welfare, food, shelter, education reasonable medical care. duties enumerated subject residual rights responsibilities natural parent(s) guardian(s) child children. (z) "Status offense" means conduct subject adjudication youth court would crime committed adult. (aa) "Financially able" means parent child ineligible court-appointed attorney. (bb) "Assessment" means individualized examination child determine child's psychosocial needs problems, including type extent mental health, substance abuse co-occurring mental health substance abuse disorders recommendations treatment. term includes, limited to, drug alcohol, psychological psychiatric evaluation, records review, clinical interview administration formal test instrument. (cc) "Screening" means process, without administration formal instrument, designed identify child increased risk mental health, substance abuse co-occurring mental health substance abuse disorders warrant immediate attention, intervention comprehensive assessment. (dd) "Durable legal relative guardianship" means legal status created youth court order conveys physical legal custody child children durable legal guardianship relative fictive kin licensed foster resource parent. (ee) "Relative" means person related child affinity consanguinity within third degree. (ff) "Fictive kin" means person related child legally biologically considered relative due significant, familial-like ongoing relationship child family. (gg) "Reasonable efforts" means exercise reasonable care due diligence Department Human Services, Department Child Protection Services, appropriate entity person use appropriate available services prevent unnecessary removal child home provide services related meeting needs child parents. (hh) "Commercial sexual exploitation" means sexual act crime sexual nature, committed child financial economic gain, obtain thing value quid pro quo exchange property purpose. (b) "Fiduciary" includes person acting behalf board trustees investment manager proxy advisor. (c) "Fiduciary commitment" means evidence fiduciary's purpose managing assets fiduciary, including, limited to, following fiduciary's capacity fiduciary: (i) Advertising, statements, explanations, reports, letters clients, communications portfolio companies, statements principles, commitments; (ii) Participation in, affiliation with, status signatory to, coalition, initiative, joint statement principles, agreement. (c) "Financial" means prudently determined fiduciary material effect financial risk financial return investment. (i) term "financial" include action taken, factor considered, fiduciary purpose whatsoever social, political ideological interests. (ii) fiduciary may reasonably determined taken action, considered factor, purpose social, political, ideological interests based upon evidence indicating purpose, including, limited to, fiduciary commitment further, portfolio company engagement, board shareholder votes, otherwise fiduciary, following beyond controlling federal state law requires: 1. (e) "Public retirement system," "system" "plan" means retirement pension system plan maintained, provided offered governmental entity. SECTION 2. Fiduciary duty. (1) making supervising investments reserve fund public retirement system, fiduciary board shall discharge duties solely financial interest participants beneficiaries exclusive purposes of: (a) Providing financial benefits participants beneficiaries; (b) Defraying reasonable expenses administering system. (2) investment manager retained board shall subject fiduciary duties board. (3) fiduciary shall take account financial factors discharging duties respect plan. (4) shares held directly indirectly behalf public retirement system and/or participants beneficiaries shall voted solely financial interest plan participants beneficiaries. (5) Unless economically practicable alternative available, governmental entity establishes maintains public retirement system board system may grant proxy voting authority person part governmental entity, unless person practice of, writing commits to, follow guidelines match governmental entity's board's obligation act solely upon financial factors. (5) Unless economically practicable alternative available, public retirement system assets shall entrusted fiduciary, unless fiduciary practice of, writing commits to, follow guidelines, engaging portfolio companies voting shares proxies, match governmental entity's board's obligation act solely upon financial factors. (7) proxy votes shall tabulated reported annually board. vote, report shall contain vote caption, plan's vote, recommendation company management, and, applicable, proxy advisor's recommendation. reports shall posted publicly available webpage board's website. KEAN District 30 (Monmouth Ocean) Assemblyman CHRISTOPHER P. DEPHILLIPS District 40 (Bergen, Essex, Morris Passaic) SYNOPSIS Prohibits board education providing instruction family life education, sex education, sexual health, sexual orientation, gender identity students preschool grade four. CURRENT VERSION TEXT introduced. Act concerning sex education public schools supplementing chapter 35 Title 18A New Jersey Statutes. Enacted Senate General Assembly State New Jersey: 1. a. board education shall provide instruction family life education, sex education, sexual health, sexual orientation, gender identity students enrolled preschool grade four. b. Notwithstanding provisions section 4 P.L.2007, c.260 (C.18A:7F-46) law, rule, regulation contrary, State Board Education shall, within 30 days effective date act, revise New Jersey Student Learning Standards Comprehensive Health Physical Education reflect provisions subsection a. section. 2. act shall take effect immediately. STATEMENT bill prohibits board education providing instruction family life education, sex education, sexual health, sexual orientation, gender identity students enrolled preschool grade four. bill also requires State Board Education, within 30 days bill's effective date, revise New Jersey Student Learning Standards Comprehensive Health Physical Education reflect bill's provisions. AMENDMENTS; RELATED PURPOSES. ENACTED LEGISLATURE STATE MISSISSIPPI: SECTION 1. act shall known may cited "Families' Rights Responsibilities Act 2023." SECTION 2. used act, following terms shall meaning ascribed section unless context usage requires otherwise: (a) "Child" means individual age eighteen (18). term include child adjudicated legally emancipated minor accordance state law court competent jurisdiction. (b) "Curriculum" includes textbooks, reading materials, handouts, videos, presentations, digital materials, websites, online applications, digital applications phone, laptop tablet, questionnaires, surveys, written electronic materials assigned, distributed otherwise presented physically virtually students class course. (c) "Educational records" includes attendance records, test scores school-administered tests state-wide assessments, grades, extracurricular activity club participation, e-mail accounts, online virtual accounts data, disciplinary records, counseling records, psychological records, applications admission, health immunization information including medical records maintained health clinic medical facility operated controlled school district located district property, teacher counselor evaluations, reports behavioral patterns. (d) "Parent" means biological parent child, adoptive parent child, individual granted exclusive right, guardianship authority welfare child state law. (e) "Substantial burden" means action directly indirectly constrains, inhibits, curtails, denies right parent direct upbringing, education, health care mental health parent's child, compels action contrary right parent direct upbringing, education, health care mental health parent's child. term includes, limited to, withholding benefits, assessing criminal, civil administrative penalties damages, exclusion governmental assistance programs. SECTION 3. Parental Rights Fundamental. (1) liberty parent direct upbringing, education, health care mental health parent's child fundamental right. (2) state, political subdivision state governmental entity shall substantially burden fundamental right parent direct upbringing, education, health care mental health parent's child without demonstrating burden required compelling governmental interest highest order applied parent child least restrictive means furthering compelling governmental interest. SECTION 4. Rights Responsibilities. (1) parental rights exclusively reserved parent child without obstruction interference state, political subdivision state, governmental entity institution, including without limitation, following rights responsibilities: (a) direct education child, including right choose public, private, religious home schools, right make reasonable choices within public schools education child; (b) access review written electronic educational records relating child controlled possession school; (c) direct upbringing child; (d) direct moral religious training child; (e) make consent writing physical mental health care decisions child; (f) access review health medical records child; (g) consent writing biometric scan child made, shared stored; (h) consent writing record child's blood deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) created, stored shared, unless authorized pursuant court order; (i) consent writing governmental entity makes video voice recording child, unless video voice recording made part of: (i) court proceeding; (ii) law enforcement investigation; (iii) forensic interview criminal Department Child Protection Services investigation; (iv) security surveillance buildings grounds; (v) photo identification card; (j) notified promptly employee state, political subdivision state, governmental entity institution suspects abuse, neglect criminal offense committed child; (k) opt child personal analysis, evaluation, survey data collection school district would capture data inclusion state longitudinal student data system except necessary essential establish student's educational record; (l) right child excused school attendance religious purposes; (m) right participate parent-teacher associations school organizations sanctioned board education school district. (2) section authorize allow parent abuse neglect child defined Section 43-21-105. section apply parental action decision would end life. section prohibit court issuing order otherwise permitted law. (3) employee state, political subdivision state, governmental entity, except law enforcement personnel, shall encourage coerce child withhold information child's parent. shall employee withhold child's parent information relevant physical, emotional mental health child. SECTION 5. Educational Involvement. (1) board education school district, consultation parents, teachers administrators, shall develop adopt policy promote involvement parents children enrolled schools within school district, including: (a) plan parent participation schools designed improve parent teacher cooperation areas homework, attendance discipline; (b) Procedures parent may learn course study parent's child review curriculum. procedures shall allow parent to: (i) Review syllabus class course parent's child enrolled least seven (7) days start class course. syllabus shall include written description topics subjects taught class course, shall include list curriculum used class course, identity individuals providing in-person live remote instruction class course, description assemblies, guest lectures, field trips educational activities part class course; (ii) Review curriculum class course offered school teacher training materials least three (3) days curriculum materials taught used instruction presented students; (iii) Copy record information curriculum teacher training materials; (iv) Meet teacher class course, principal, representative school discuss curriculum teaching training materials. (c) Procedures notify parent least three (3) days advance obtain parent's written consent parent's child attends instruction presentation goal purpose studying, exploring informing students gender roles stereotypes, gender identity, gender expression, sexual orientation romantic sexual relationships; (d) Procedures parent objects specific instruction presentation basis harmful may withdraw parent's child instruction presentation. Objection specific instruction presentation basis harmful includes, limited to, objection material activity questions beliefs practices regarding sex, morality religion; (e) Procedures parent may learn nature purpose clubs extracurricular activities approved school may withdraw parent's child club extracurricular parent objects; (f) Procedures parent must provide written consent child uses name nickname legal name, child uses pronoun align child's sex. However, even parent provides written consent, person shall compelled use pronouns align child's sex; (g) Procedures parent may learn parental rights responsibilities laws state. (2) board education school district may adopt policy provide parents information required section electronic form. (3) parent shall submit written electronic request information pursuant section either school principal superintendent school district. Within ten (10) days receiving request information, school principal superintendent shall either deliver requested information parent submit parent written explanation reasons denial requested information. request information denied parent receive requested information within fifteen (15) days submitting request information, parent may submit written request information board education school district, shall formally consider request next scheduled public meeting board request properly noticed agenda. request cannot properly noticed agenda, board education shall formally consider request next subsequent public meeting board. SECTION 6. Medical Mental Health Care. (1) Except otherwise provided law court order, person, corporation, association, organization, state-supported institution individual employed entities must obtain consent parent child taking following actions: (a) Procuring, soliciting perform, arranging performance of, providing referral for, performing surgical procedures upon child; (b) Procuring, soliciting perform, arranging performance of, providing referral for, performing physical examination upon child; (c) Prescribing dispensing medication prescription drugs child; (d) Procuring, soliciting perform, arranging performance of, providing referral for, performing mental health evaluation clinical nonclinical setting, mental health treatment child. (2) parental consent pursuant subsection (1) given telemedicine, person entity obtaining parental consent must verify identity parent site consent given. (3) provisions section shall apply determined physician that: (a) emergency exists; (b) Either following conditions true: (i) necessary perform activity listed subsection (1) order prevent death imminent irreparable physical injury child; (ii) parent child cannot located contacted reasonably diligent effort. (4) provisions section apply abortion, shall governed Chapter 41, Title 41, Mississippi Code 1972. SECTION 7. Cause Action. (1) parent may bring suit violation act may raise act defense judicial administrative proceeding without regard whether proceeding brought name state government, private person party. (2) Notwithstanding provision law, action act may commenced, relief may granted, without regard whether person commencing action sought exhausted available administrative remedies. (3) person successfully asserts claim defense act may recover declaratory relief, injunctive relief, compensatory damages, reasonable attorneys' fees costs, appropriate relief. (4) Sovereign, governmental qualified immunities suit liability waived abolished extent liability created act. SECTION 8. Rules Construction. (1) Unless rights legally waived legally terminated, parents inalienable rights comprehensive listed section. protections fundamental right parents direct upbringing, education, health care mental health child afforded act addition protections provided federal law, state law, state federal constitutions. (2) act shall construed favor broad protection fundamental right parents direct upbringing, education, health care mental health child. (3) Nothing act shall construed authorize government burden fundamental right parents direct upbringing, education, health care mental health child. (4) child affirmative right access particular medical mental health procedure service, nothing act shall construed grant child's parent affirmative right access procedure service child's behalf. (5) State statutory law adopted date enactment act subject act unless law explicitly excludes application reference act. SECTION 9. Section 37-3-49, Mississippi Code 1972, amended follows: 37-3-49. SECTION 13. Section 37-13-171, Mississippi Code 1972, brought forward follows: 37-13-171. (1) local school board every public school district shall adopt policy implement abstinence-only abstinence-plus education curriculum June 30, 2012, instruction subjects shall implemented later start 2012-2013 school year local school board shall adopt program developed Mississippi Department Human Services Mississippi Department Health. State Department Education shall approve district's curriculum sex-related education shall establish protocol used districts provide continuity teaching approved curriculum manner age, grade developmentally appropriate. (2) Abstinence-only education shall remain state standard sex-related education taught public schools. purposes section, abstinence-only education includes type instruction program which, appropriate age grade: (a) Teaches social, psychological health gains realized abstaining sexual activity, likely negative psychological physical effects abstaining; (b) Teaches harmful consequences child, child's parents society bearing children wedlock likely produce, including health, educational, financial difficulties child parents likely face, well inappropriateness social economic burden placed others; (c) Teaches unwanted sexual advances irresponsible teaches reject sexual advances alcohol drug use increases vulnerability sexual advances; (d) Teaches abstinence sexual activity marriage, fidelity within marriage, certain way avoid out-of-wedlock pregnancy, sexually transmitted diseases related health problems. instruction program may include discussion condoms contraceptives, discussion includes factual presentation risks failure rates contraceptives. case shall instruction program include demonstration condoms contraceptives applied; (e) Teaches current state law related sexual conduct, including forcible rape, statutory rape, paternity establishment, child support homosexual activity; (f) Teaches mutually faithful, monogamous relationship context marriage appropriate setting sexual intercourse. (3) program instruction sex-related education need include every component listed subsection (2) section abstinence-only education. However, program instruction abstinence-only curriculum may include anything contradicts excluded components. purposes section, abstinence-plus education includes every component listed subsection (2) section age grade appropriate, addition programmatic instructional component approved department, shall include instruction demonstrations application use condoms. Abstinence-plus education may discuss contraceptives, nature, causes effects sexually transmitted diseases, prevention sexually transmitted diseases, including HIV/AIDS, along factual presentation risks failure rates. (4) course containing sex-related education offered public schools shall include instruction either abstinence-only abstinence-plus education. (5) Local school districts, discretion, may host programs designed teach parents discuss abstinence children. (6) shall effort either abstinence-only abstinence-plus curriculum teach abortion used prevent birth baby. (7) times sex-related education discussed taught, boys girls shall separated according gender different classrooms, sex-related education instruction may conducted boys girls company students opposite gender. (8) section shall stand repealed July 1, 2024. SECTION 14. Section 43-21-105, Mississippi Code 1972, brought forward follows: 43-21-105. following words phrases, purposes chapter, shall meanings ascribed herein unless context clearly otherwise requires: (a) "Youth court" means Youth Court Division. (b) "Judge" means judge Youth Court Division. (c) "Designee" means person judge appoints perform duty chapter requires done judge designee. judge may appoint person involved law enforcement employee Mississippi Department Human Services Mississippi Department Child Protection Services designee. (d) "Child" "youth" synonymous, means person reached eighteenth birthday. child reached eighteenth birthday active duty branch armed services married considered "child" "youth" purposes chapter. (e) "Parent" means father mother child born, father mother child legally adopted. (f) "Guardian" means court-appointed guardian person child. (g) "Custodian" means person present care custody child whether person parent otherwise. (h) "Legal custodian" means court-appointed custodian child. (i) "Delinquent child" means child reached tenth birthday committed delinquent act. (j) "Delinquent act" act, committed adult, designated crime state federal law, municipal county ordinance offenses punishable life imprisonment death. delinquent act includes escape lawful detention violations Uniform Controlled Substances Law violent behavior. (k) "Child need supervision" means child reached seventh birthday need treatment rehabilitation child: (i) habitually disobedient reasonable lawful commands parent, guardian custodian ungovernable; (ii) required attend school, willfully habitually violates rules thereof willfully habitually absents therefrom; (iii) Runs away home without good cause; (iv) committed delinquent act acts. (l) "Neglected child" means child: (i) Whose parent, guardian custodian person responsible care support, neglects refuses, able do, provide proper necessary care support, education required law, medical, surgical, care necessary well-being; however, parent withholds medical treatment child good faith treatment spiritual means alone prayer accordance tenets practices recognized church religious denomination duly accredited practitioner thereof shall not, reason alone, considered neglectful provision chapter; (ii) otherwise without proper care, custody, supervision support; (iii) Who, reason, lacks special care made necessary reason mental condition, whether mental condition mental illness intellectual disability; (iv) Who, reason, lacks care necessary health, morals well-being. (m) "Abused child" means child whose parent, guardian custodian person responsible care support, whether legally obligated not, caused allowed caused, upon child, sexual abuse, sexual exploitation, commercial sexual exploitation, emotional abuse, mental injury, nonaccidental physical injury maltreatment. However, physical discipline, including spanking, performed child parent, guardian custodian reasonable manner shall deemed abuse section. "Abused child" also means child trafficked within meaning Mississippi Human Trafficking Act person, without regard relationship person child. (n) "Sexual abuse" means obscene pornographic photographing, filming depiction children commercial purposes, rape, molestation, incest, prostitution forms sexual exploitation children circumstances indicate child's health welfare harmed threatened. (o) "A child need special care" means child mental physical illness cannot treated dispositional alternatives ordinarily available youth court. (p) "dependent child" means child child need supervision, delinquent child, abused child neglected child, child voluntarily placed custody Department Child Protection Services parent, guardian custodian. (q) "Custody" means physical possession child person. (r) "Legal custody" means legal status created court order gives legal custodian responsibilities physical possession child duty provide food, shelter, education reasonable medical care, subject residual rights responsibilities parent guardian person. (s) "Detention" means care children physically restrictive facilities. (t) "Shelter" means care children physically nonrestrictive facilities. (u) "Records involving children" means following child identified: (i) youth court records defined Section 43-21-251; (ii) forensic interviews conducted child advocacy center abuse neglect investigations; (iii) law enforcement records defined Section 43-21-255; (iv) agency records defined Section 43-21-257; (v) documents maintained representative state, county, municipality public agency insofar relate apprehension, custody, adjudication disposition child subject youth court cause. (w) singular includes plural, plural singular masculine feminine consistent intent chapter. (x) "Out-of-home" setting means temporary supervision care children staff licensed day care centers, staff public, private state schools, staff juvenile detention facilities, staff unlicensed residential care facilities group homes staff of, individuals representing, churches, civic social organizations. (y) "Durable legal custody" means legal status created court order gives durable legal custodian responsibilities physical possession child duty provide care, nurture, welfare, food, shelter, education reasonable medical care. duties enumerated subject residual rights responsibilities natural parent(s) guardian(s) child children. SECTION 15. act shall take effect force July 1, 2023. SECTION 2. used act, following terms shall meaning ascribed section unless context usage requires otherwise: (a) "Child" means individual age eighteen (18). term include child adjudicated legally emancipated minor accordance state law court competent jurisdiction. (d) "Parent" means biological parent child, adoptive parent child, individual granted exclusive right, guardianship authority welfare child state law. (e) "Substantial burden" means action directly indirectly constrains, inhibits, curtails, denies right parent direct upbringing, education, health care mental health parent's child, compels action contrary right parent direct upbringing, education, health care mental health parent's child. term includes, limited to, withholding benefits, assessing criminal, civil administrative penalties damages, exclusion governmental assistance programs. (2) state, political subdivision state governmental entity shall substantially burden fundamental right parent direct upbringing, education, health care mental health parent's child without demonstrating burden required compelling governmental interest highest order applied parent child least restrictive means furthering compelling governmental interest. Section 43-21-105, Mississippi Code 1972, brought forward follows: 43-21-105. following words phrases, purposes chapter, shall meanings ascribed herein unless context clearly otherwise requires: (a) "Youth court" means Youth Court Division. (b) "Judge" means judge Youth Court Division. (c) "Designee" means person judge appoints perform duty chapter requires done judge designee. judge may appoint person involved law enforcement employee Mississippi Department Human Services Mississippi Department Child Protection Services designee. (d) "Child" "youth" synonymous, means person reached eighteenth birthday. child reached eighteenth birthday active duty branch armed services married considered "child" "youth" purposes chapter. (e) "Parent" means father mother child born, father mother child legally adopted. (f) "Guardian" means court-appointed guardian person child. (g) "Custodian" means person present care custody child whether person parent otherwise. (h) "Legal custodian" means court-appointed custodian child. (i) "Delinquent child" means child reached tenth birthday committed delinquent act. (j) "Delinquent act" act, committed adult, designated crime state federal law, municipal county ordinance offenses punishable life imprisonment death. delinquent act includes escape lawful detention violations Uniform Controlled Substances Law violent behavior. (k) "Child need supervision" means child reached seventh birthday need treatment rehabilitation child: (i) habitually disobedient reasonable lawful commands parent, guardian custodian ungovernable; (ii) required attend school, willfully habitually violates rules thereof willfully habitually absents therefrom; (iii) Runs away home without good cause; (iv) committed delinquent act acts. (l) "Neglected child" means child: (i) Whose parent, guardian custodian person responsible care support, neglects refuses, able do, provide proper necessary care support, education required law, medical, surgical, care necessary well-being; however, parent withholds medical treatment child good faith treatment spiritual means alone prayer accordance tenets practices recognized church religious denomination duly accredited practitioner thereof shall not, reason alone, considered neglectful provision chapter; (ii) otherwise without proper care, custody, supervision support; (iii) Who, reason, lacks special care made necessary reason mental condition, whether mental condition mental illness intellectual disability; (iv) Who, reason, lacks care necessary health, morals well-being. (m) "Abused child" means child whose parent, guardian custodian person responsible care support, whether legally obligated not, caused allowed caused, upon child, sexual abuse, sexual exploitation, commercial sexual exploitation, emotional abuse, mental injury, nonaccidental physical injury maltreatment. However, physical discipline, including spanking, performed child parent, guardian custodian reasonable manner shall deemed abuse section. "Abused child" also means child trafficked within meaning Mississippi Human Trafficking Act person, without regard relationship person child. (n) "Sexual abuse" means obscene pornographic photographing, filming depiction children commercial purposes, rape, molestation, incest, prostitution forms sexual exploitation children circumstances indicate child's health welfare harmed threatened. (o) "A child need special care" means child mental physical illness cannot treated dispositional alternatives ordinarily available youth court. (p) "dependent child" means child child need supervision, delinquent child, abused child neglected child, child voluntarily placed custody Department Child Protection Services parent, guardian custodian. (q) "Custody" means physical possession child person. (r) "Legal custody" means legal status created court order gives legal custodian responsibilities physical possession child duty provide food, shelter, education reasonable medical care, subject residual rights responsibilities parent guardian person. (s) "Detention" means care children physically restrictive facilities. (t) "Shelter" means care children physically nonrestrictive facilities. (u) "Records involving children" means following child identified: (i) youth court records defined Section 43-21-251; (ii) forensic interviews conducted child advocacy center abuse neglect investigations; (iii) law enforcement records defined Section 43-21-255; (iv) agency records defined Section 43-21-257; (v) documents maintained representative state, county, municipality public agency insofar relate apprehension, custody, adjudication disposition child subject youth court cause. (v) "Any person responsible care support" means person providing child given time. term shall include, limited to, stepparents, foster parents, relatives, nonlicensed babysitters similar persons responsible child staff residential care facilities group homes licensed Department Human Services Department Child Protection Services. (w) singular includes plural, plural singular masculine feminine consistent intent chapter. (x) "Out-of-home" setting means temporary supervision care children staff licensed day care centers, staff public, private state schools, staff juvenile detention facilities, staff unlicensed residential care facilities group homes staff of, individuals representing, churches, civic social organizations. (y) "Durable legal custody" means legal status created court order gives durable legal custodian responsibilities physical possession child duty provide care, nurture, welfare, food, shelter, education reasonable medical care. duties enumerated subject residual rights responsibilities natural parent(s) guardian(s) child children. (z) "Status offense" means conduct subject adjudication youth court would crime committed adult. (aa) "Financially able" means parent child ineligible court-appointed attorney. (bb) "Assessment" means individualized examination child determine child's psychosocial needs problems, including type extent mental health, substance abuse co-occurring mental health substance abuse disorders recommendations treatment. term includes, limited to, drug alcohol, psychological psychiatric evaluation, records review, clinical interview administration formal test instrument. (cc) "Screening" means process, without administration formal instrument, designed identify child increased risk mental health, substance abuse co-occurring mental health substance abuse disorders warrant immediate attention, intervention comprehensive assessment. (ee) "Relative" means person related child affinity consanguinity within third degree. (ff) "Fictive kin" means person related child legally biologically considered relative due significant, familial-like ongoing relationship child family. No. 1029 BILL ENTITLED ACT relating civil liability for, governmental health plan coverage of, public funding gender modification procedures treatments. ENACTED LEGISLATURE STATE TEXAS: SECTION 1. legislature finds that: (1) evidenced 2018 video Vanderbilt University Medical Center administrator promoted gender modification surgeries financially beneficial stated entire clinics financed phalloplasties, medical community knowledge many so-called "gender affirming" treatments best interest health patient rather promoted monetary gain health care facilities receive providing treatments; (2) medical community conflict interest offering gender modification treatments procedures treatments procedures create lifelong patients result required follow-up visits treatments procedures. SECTION 2. Title 4, Civil Practice Remedies Code, amended adding Chapter 74B read follows: CHAPTER 74B. LIABILITY GENDER MODIFICATION PROCEDURES TREATMENTS Sec. 74B.001. DEFINITION. chapter, "gender modification procedure treatment" means health care procedure treatment provided purpose transitioning patient's biological sex, determined patient's sex organs, chromosomes, endogenous profiles, affirming patient's perception patient's sex perception inconsistent patient's sex. term includes: (1) surgery sterilizes patient, including: (A) castration; (B) vasectomy; (C) hysterectomy; (D) oophorectomy; (E) metoidioplasty; (F) orchiectomy; (G) penectomy; (H) phalloplasty; (I) vaginoplasty; (2) mastectomy; (3) prescription, administration, supply following medications induce transient permanent infertility: (A) puberty-blocking medication stop delay normal puberty; (B) supraphysiologic doses testosterone females; (C) supraphysiologic doses estrogen males; (4) removal otherwise healthy non-diseased body part tissue. Sec. 74B.002. CONFLICT LAWS. extent chapter conflicts another law, chapter prevails. Sec. 74B.003. STRICT LIABILITY HEALTH COVERAGE. health benefit plan issuer strictly liable patient patient's medical, mental health, pharmaceutical costs, including costs associated reversing gender modification procedure treatment, incurred life patient result gender modification procedure treatment covered issuer's plan. Sec. 74B.004. LIABILITY PHYSICIAN HEALTH CARE PROVIDER. physician health care provider provides gender modification procedure treatment patient is: (1) liable patient malpractice claim provision procedure treatment; (2) strictly liable patient patient's medical, mental health, pharmaceutical costs, including costs associated reversing gender modification procedure treatment, incurred life patient result procedure treatment. Sec. 74B.005. EXCEPTIONS. Sections 74B.003 74B.004 apply provision physician health care provider, consent child's parent legal guardian, applicable, coverage health benefit plan appropriate medically necessary gender modification procedures treatments patient who: (1) born medically verifiable genetic disorder sex development, including: (A) 46,XX chromosomes virilization; (B) 46,XY chromosomes undervirilization; (C) ovarian testicular tissue; (2) normal sex chromosome structure male female determined physician genetic testing. SECTION 3. Subtitle F, Title 10, Government Code, amended adding Chapter 2273A read follows: CHAPTER 2273A. PROHIBITED USES PUBLIC MONEY Sec. 2273A.001. DEFINITIONS. chapter: (1) "Gender modification procedure treatment" meaning assigned Section 74B.001, Civil Practice Remedies Code. (2) "Governmental entity" means state, state agency, political subdivision. Sec. 2273A.002. USE GENDER MODIFICATION PROCEDURE TREATMENT. governmental entity may use provide public money provision administration gender modification procedure treatment. SECTION 4. Subtitle E, Title 8, Insurance Code, amended adding Chapter 1372 read follows: CHAPTER 1372. PROHIBITED COVERAGE GENDER MODIFICATION PROCEDURES TREATMENTS Sec. 1372.001. DEFINITION. chapter, "gender modification procedure treatment" meaning assigned Section 74B.001, Civil Practice Remedies Code. Sec. 1372.002. APPLICABILITY CHAPTER. Notwithstanding law, chapter applies to: (1) basic coverage plan Chapter 1551; (2) basic plan Chapter 1575; (3) primary care coverage plan Chapter 1579; (4) plan providing basic coverage Chapter 1601; (5) state Medicaid program, including Medicaid managed care program operated Chapter 533, Government Code; (6) child health plan program Chapter 62, Health Safety Code. Sec. 1372.003. PROHIBITED COVERAGE; EXCEPTION. (a) health benefit plan may provide coverage gender modification procedure treatment. (b) section apply coverage health benefit plan appropriate medically necessary gender modification procedures treatments patient who: (1) born medically verifiable genetic disorder sex development, including: (A) 46,XX chromosomes virilization; (B) 46,XY chromosomes undervirilization; (C) ovarian testicular tissue; (2) normal sex chromosome structure male female determined physician genetic testing. SECTION 5. (a) Chapter 74B, Civil Practice Remedies Code, added Act, applies cause action accrues effective date Act. (b) changes law made Act apply health benefit plan delivered, issued delivery, renewed effective date Act. SECTION 6. Act takes effect September 1, 2023. MISSISSIPPI LEGISLATURE 2023 Regular Session To: Education By: Senator(s) Hill, Seymour, Chism Senate Bill 2765 ACT ENTITLED "MISSISSIPPI FAMILIES' RIGHTS RESPONSIBILITIES ACT"; PROVIDE DEFINITIONS; PROVIDE PARENTAL RIGHTS EXCLUSIVELY RESERVED PARENT CHILD WITHOUT INTERFERENCE STATE POLITICAL SUBDIVISION STATE; PROVIDE LOCAL SCHOOL BOARD CONSULTATION PARENTS TEACHERS SHALL DEVELOP ADOPT POLICY PROMOTE INVOLVEMENT PARENTS CHILDREN ENROLLED PUBLIC SCHOOLS; REQUIRE PUBLIC SCHOOLS ADOPT PROCEDURES ENSURE PARENT PROVIDES WRITTEN PERMISSION CHILD PARTICIPATES IDENTITY CURRICULUM CRITICAL THEORY CURRICULUM ALLOW PARENTS EXEMPT CHILD SPECIFIC LESSONS OBJECTIONABLE FAMILY; REQUIRE PARENTAL CONSENT MEDICAL MENTAL HEALTH CARE; PROVIDE CAUSE ACTION VIOLATIONS ACT; PROVIDE RULES CONSTRUCTION; AMEND SECTION 37-13-9, MISSISSIPPI CODE 1972, CONFORMITY; BRING FORWARD SECTIONS 41-41-3, 41-41-7 41-41-11, MISSISSIPPI CODE 1972, RELATING IMPLIED CONSENT MEDICAL PROCEDURES MINORS; RELATED PURPOSES. ENACTED LEGISLATURE STATE MISSISSIPPI: SECTION 1. act shall known may cited "Mississippi Families' Rights Responsibilities Act." SECTION 2. used act: (a) term "child" means individual age eighteen (18). (b) term "curriculum" includes textbooks, reading materials, handouts, videos, presentations, digital materials, websites, online applications, digital applications phone, laptop, tablet, questionnaires, surveys, written electronic materials assigned, distributed, otherwise presented physically virtually students class course. (c) term "identity curriculum" means curriculum goal purpose studying, exploring, informing students gender roles stereotypes, gender identity, gender expression, sexual orientation, romantic sexual relationships. (d) term "critical theory curriculum" means curriculum discusses following concepts: (i) United States State Mississippi fundamentally, inherently, irredeemably racist, sexist, oppressive discriminatory; (ii) individual, virtue sex, race, ethnicity, religion, color national origin, inherently racist, sexist, oppressive discriminatory whether consciously unconsciously; (iii) individual, virtue sex, race, ethnicity, religion, color national origin, blamed held responsible actions committed past members individual's sex, race, ethnicity, religion, color national origin; (iv) individual's moral character necessarily determined, whole part, individual's sex, race, ethnicity, religion, color national origin; (v) individual feel guilt, blame, discomfort, anguish, form psychological distress account individual's sex, race, ethnicity, religion, color national origin; (vi) individual, virtue sex, race, ethnicity, religion, color national origin, marginalized perpetually victimized unable advance society due victimized, marginalized, oppressed others. (e) term "educational records" includes attendance records, test scores school-administered tests state-wide assessments, grades, extracurricular activity club participation, email accounts, online virtual accounts data, disciplinary records, counseling records, psychological records, applications admission, health immunization information, including medical records maintained health clinic medical facility operated controlled school district located district property, teacher counselor evaluations, reports behavioral patterns. (f) term "parent" means biological parent child, adoptive parent child, individual granted exclusive right authority welfare child state law. (g) term "substantial burden" means action directly indirectly constrains, inhibits, curtails, denies right parent direct upbringing, education, health care, mental health parent's child compels action contrary right parent direct upbringing, education, health care, mental health parent's child. includes, limited to, withholding benefits, assessing criminal, civil, administrative penalties damages, exclusion governmental programs. (h) term "teacher-training materials" means presentations, videos, professional development classes, educational training activities, including written electronic materials used distributed activities, teacher required attend public school. SECTION 3. Parental rights fundamental. (1) liberty parent direct upbringing, education, health care, mental health parent's child fundamental right. (2) state, political subdivision state, governmental entity shall substantially burden fundamental right parent direct upbringing, education, health care, mental health parent's child without demonstrating burden required compelling governmental interest highest order applied parent child least restrictive means furthering compelling governmental interest. SECTION 4. Rights responsibilities. (1) parental rights exclusively reserved parent child without obstruction interference state, political subdivision state, governmental entity, institution, including, without limitation, following rights responsibilities: (a) direct education child, including right choose public, private, religious home schools, right make reasonable choices within public schools education child; (b) access review written electronic educational records relating child controlled possession school, including, limited all: (i) Attendance records; (ii) Test scores school-administered tests state-wide assessments; (iii) Grades; (iv) Extracurricular activity club participation; (v) child's email accounts; (vi) child's online virtual accounts data; (vii) Disciplinary records; (viii) Counseling records; (ix) Psychological records; (x) Applications admission; (xi) Health immunization information, including medical records maintained health clinic medical facility operated controlled school district located district property; (xii) Teacher counselor evaluations; (xiii) Reports behavioral patterns; (c) direct upbringing child; (d) direct moral religious training child; (e) make consent writing physical mental health care decisions child; (f) access review health medical records child; (g) consent writing biometric scan child made, shared, stored; (h) consent writing record child's blood deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) created, stored, shared, unless authorized pursuant court order; (i) consent writing governmental entity makes video voice recording child, unless video voice recording made part of: (i) court proceeding; (ii) law enforcement investigation; (iii) forensic interview criminal Department Child Services investigation; (iv) security surveillance buildings grounds; (v) photo identification card; (j) notified promptly employee state, political subdivision state, governmental entity, institution suspects abuse, neglect, criminal offense committed child; (k) opt child personal analysis, evaluation, survey, data collection school district would capture data inclusion State Longitudinal Student Data System except necessary essential establish student' educational record; (l) right child excused school attendance religious purposes; (m) right participant parent-teacher associations school organizations sanctioned board education school district. (2) section authorize allow parent abuse neglect child defined Sections 97-5-39 43-21-105, Mississippi Code 1972. section apply parental action decision would end life. section prohibit court issuing order otherwise permitted law. ENACTED LEGISLATURE STATE TEXAS: SECTION 1. Section 164.052 (a), Occupations Code, amended read follows: Sec. 164.052. PROHIBITED PRACTICES PHYSICIAN LICENSE APPLICANT. (a) physician applicant license practice medicine commits prohibited practice person: (1) submits board false misleading statement, document, certificate application license; (2) presents board license, certificate, diploma illegally fraudulently obtained; (3) commits fraud deception taking passing examination; (4) uses alcohol drugs intemperate manner that, board's opinion, could endanger patient's life; (5) commits unprofessional dishonorable conduct likely deceive defraud public, provided Section 164.053, injure public; (6) uses advertising statement false, misleading, deceptive; (7) advertises professional superiority performance professional service superior manner advertising readily subject verification; (8) purchases, sells, barters, uses, offers purchase, sell, barter, use, medical degree, license, certificate, diploma, transcript license, certificate, diploma incident application board license practice medicine; NO. 508 THIRTY-SECOND LEGISLATURE, 2023 STATE HAWAII BILL ACT relating sex-specific student athletic teams. ENACTED LEGISLATURE STATE HAWAII: SECTION 1. legislature finds proper healthy society maintain opportunities female athletes demonstrate skill, strength, athletic abilities also providing opportunities obtain recognition accolades, college scholarships, numerous long-term benefits result success athletic endeavors. legislature also finds recent years, question transgender athletes competing biologically opposite genders stirred controversies across nation, male-to-female transgender athletes winning events ranging girls state high school championship titles, womens NCAA 500-yard freestyle swimming event. legislature finds dire need promote sex equality ensuring female athletes designated space compete females. become part national conversation, legislature finds particular issue, male female designation mean biological male biological female, respectively. purpose Act require designation separate sex-specific athletic teams sports. SECTION 2. Chapter 302A, Hawaii Revised Statutes, amended adding new section properly designated read follows: "§302A- Sex-specific athletic teams. (a) requirement designate separate sex-specific athletic teams sports within interscholastic, intercollegiate, intramural, club athletic teams sports. include sports teams sponsored public, primary secondary school, public postsecondary institution, school institution whose students teams compete public school public postsecondary institution. teams shall expressly designated one following based biological sex: (1) Males, men, boys; (2) Females, women, girls; (3) Coed mixed. (b) Athletic teams sports designated females, women, girls may open students male sex. (c) dispute regarding student's sex shall resolved student's school institution requesting student provide health examination consent form statement signed student's personal health care provider must verify student's biological sex. health care provider may verify student's biological sex part routine sports physical examination relying one following: (1) student's reproductive anatomy; (2) student's genetic makeup; (3) student's normal endogenously produced testosterone levels. (d) State Board Education shall adopt rules regarding receipt timely resolution disputes schools institutions consistent subsection." SECTION 3. Chapter 302A, Hawaii Revised Statutes, amended adding new section properly designated read follows: "§302A- Protection educational institutions. (a) governmental entity, licensing accrediting organization, athletic association organization may entertain complaint, open investigation, take adverse action school public postsecondary institution maintaining separate interscholastic, intercollegiate, intramural, club athletic teams sports students female sex." (a) student deprived athletic opportunity suffers direct indirect harm result violation section shall private cause action injunctive relief, damages, relief available law school public postsecondary institution. STATEMENT bill prohibits school district teaching students sex education certain circumstances prohibits school district administering student academic nonacademic survey, assessment, analysis, evaluation reveals information concerning student student's family, unless school district meets certain requirements. bill provides classroom instruction school district personnel third parties sex, sex acts, abortion, birth control, sexual orientation, gender identity occur manner kindergarten grade five school school district. bill also provides classroom instruction school district personnel third parties sex, sex acts, abortion, birth control, sexual orientation, gender identity occur manner grade six 12 school school district, unless prior classroom instruction occurring, school district: (1) provides parents guardians written detailed information curriculum subjects taught; (2) provides parents guardians easily accessible electronic method review lesson plans ask questions; (3) receives express written consent parent guardian student receive classroom instruction. provisions bill apply curriculum classroom instruction concerning subjects anatomy biology, provided curriculum classroom instruction intended course portion course science. current law, school district may administer survey student reveals certain information student, student's family, district obtains prior written informed consent student's parent guardian. district obtains prior written informed consent student's parent guardian, law permits district administer survey reveals information concerning political affiliations; mental psychological problems potentially embarrassing student student's family; sexual behavior attitudes; illegal, anti-social, self-incriminating demeaning behavior; critical appraisals individuals respondent close family relationship; legally recognized privileged analogous relationships, lawyers, physicians, ministers; income; social security number. Additionally, current law permits school district administer anonymous, voluntary surveys concerning student health upon prior written notification parents guardians. Specifically, law permits school districts administer survey concerning use alcohol, tobacco, drugs, vaping; sexual behavior attitudes; behaviors may contribute intentional unintentional injuries violence; physical activity nutrition-related behaviors. surveys concerning student health may administered two weeks written notification provided parents guardians. bill repeals aforementioned sections current law permit school districts administer certain surveys, expressly prohibits school districts administering survey reveals information student student's family, unless school district: (1) notifies student's parent guardian intent administer survey, provides copy survey, two weeks prior administration; (2) includes first item notification, bold face type, statement explaining student's parent guardian may decline administration survey, declining survey way impact student's academics used student school; (3) receives prior written informed consent student's parent guardian. bill also prohibits school district engaging, contracting, partnering private profit nonprofit entity purposes administering student academic nonacademic survey, assessment, analysis, evaluation reveals information student student's family. bill, parent guardian alleging school district personnel school district knowingly, willfully, negligently violated provisions bill may: (1) request Commissioner Education appoint special administrative law judge hear parent guardian's concerns; special administrative law judge determine facts relating allegation, consider information provided school district parent guardian, render recommended decision resolution State Board Education within 30 days receipt request parent guardian; State Board Education approve reject recommended decision next regularly scheduled meeting less seven calendar days 30 calendar days date recommended decision transmitted State Board Education; (2) bring action school district obtain declaratory judgment school district procedure practice violates provisions bill seek injunctive relief. court may award damages award reasonable attorney fees court costs parent guardian receives declaratory injunctive relief. 88R9763 CXP-D By: Schaefer H.B.
