SPONSORS: Rep. Roy, Rock. 31; Rep. Spillane, Rock. 2; Rep. McCarter, Belk. 8; Rep. Verville, Rock. 2; Rep. Notter, Hills. 12; Rep. Seidel, Hills. 29; Rep. A. Lekas, Hills. 38; Rep. Love, Rock. 13 COMMITTEE: Health, Human Services Elderly Affairs ----------------------------------------------------------------- ANALYSIS bill prohibits gender transition care minors 18 years age, prohibits teaching gender identity public schools changes definition conversion therapy. - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - Explanation: Matter added current law appears bold italics. Matter removed current law appears [in brackets struckthrough.] Matter either (a) new (b) repealed reenacted appears regular type. 23-0071 02/05 STATE NEW HAMPSHIRE Year Lord Two Thousand Twenty Three ACT prohibiting gender transition procedures minors, relative sex gender public schools, relative definition conversion therapy. Enacted Senate House Representatives General Court convened: 1 Title. act shall known may cited "Protection Child Medical Psychological Experimentation Act". 2 Legislative Findings. general court finds that: I. New Hampshire compelling government interest protecting health safety citizens, especially vulnerable children; II.(a) small percentage American population experiences distress identifying biological sex. (b) According American Psychiatric Association, “For natal adult males, prevalence ranges 0.005 0.014 percent, natal females, 0.002 0.003 percent.”; III. small percentage children gender nonconforming experience distress identifying biological sex, studies consistently demonstrate majority come identify biological sex adolescence adulthood, thereby rendering physiological interventions unnecessary; IV. Furthermore, scientific studies show individuals struggling distress identifying biological sex often already experienced psychopathology, indicates individuals encouraged seek mental health services address comorbidities underlying causes distress undertaking hormonal surgical intervention; V. Even among people undergone inpatient gender reassignment procedures, suicide rates, psychiatric morbidities, mortality rates remain markedly elevated background population; VI.(a) health care providers prescribing puberty blocking drugs, gonadotropin-releasing hormone analogues, order delay onset progression puberty children experience distress identifying biological sex. (b) prescribing puberty-blocking drugs done despite lack long-term longitudinal studies evaluating risks benefits using drugs treatment distress gender transition; VII. Health care providers also prescribing cross-sex hormones children experience distress identifying biological sex, despite fact randomized clinical trials conducted efficacy safety use cross-sex hormones adults children purpose treating distress gender transition; VIII. use cross-sex hormones comes serious known risks, as: (a) biological females: (1) Erythrocytosis, increase red blood cells; (2) Severe liver dysfunction; (3) Coronary artery disease, including heart attacks; (4) Cerebrovascular disease, including strokes; (5) Hypertension; (6) Increased risk breast uterine cancers; (7) Irreversible infertility; (b) biological males: (1) Thromboembolic disease, including blood clots; (2) Cholelithiasis, including gallstones; (3) Coronary artery disease, including heart attacks; (4) Macroprolactinoma, tumor pituitary gland; (5) Cerebrovascular disease, including strokes; (6) Hypertriglyceridemia, elevated level triglycerides blood; (7) Breast cancer; (8) Irreversible infertility; IX. Genital non-genital gender reassignment surgeries generally recommended children, although evidence indicates referrals children surgeries becoming frequent; X.(a) Genital gender reassignment surgery includes several irreversible invasive procedures males females involves alteration biologically healthy functional body parts. (b) biological males, surgery may involve: (1) Genital reconstruction including penectomy, removal penis; (2) Orchiectomy, removal testicles; (3) Vaginoplasty, construction vagina-like structure, typically penile inversion procedure; (4) Clitoroplasty, construction clitoris-like structure; (5) Vulvoplasty, construction vulva-like structure. (c) biological females, surgery may involve: (1) hysterectomy oophorectomy; (2) Reconstruction urethra; (3) Genital reconstruction including metoidioplasty phalloplasty, construction penis-like structure; (4) Vaginectomy, removal vagina; (5) Scrotoplasty, construction penis-like scrotum-like structure; (6) Implantation erection testicular prostheses; XI. complications, risks, long-term care concerns associated genital gender reassignment surgery males females numerous complex; XII.(a) Non-genital gender reassignment surgery includes various invasive procedures males females also involves alteration removal biologically normal functional body parts. (b) biological males, surgery may involve: (1) Augmentation mammoplasty; (2) Facial feminization surgery; (3) Liposuction; (4) Lipofilling; (5) Voice surgery; (6) Thyroid cartilage reduction; (7) Gluteal augmentation; (8) Hair reconstruction; (9) aesthetic procedures. (c) biological females, surgery may involve: (1) subcutaneous mastectomy; (2) Voice surgery; (3) Liposuction; (4) Lipofilling; (5) Pectoral implants; (6) aesthetic procedures; XIII.(a) accepted principle economics public policy service product subsidized reimbursed, demand service product increased. (b) 2015 2016, gender reassignment surgeries increased nearly twenty percent United States; XIV. grave concern general court medical community allowing individuals experience distress identifying biological sex subjects irreversible drastic non-genital gender reassignment surgery irreversible, permanently sterilizing genital gender reassignment surgery, despite lack studies showing benefits extreme interventions outweigh risks; XV. risks gender transition procedures far outweigh benefit stage clinical study procedures. 3 New Chapter; System Gender Dysphoria Care Minors. Amend RSA inserting chapter 135-F following new chapter:CHAPTER 135-GSYSTEM GENDER DYSPHORIA CARE MINORS 135-G:1 Definitions. chapter: I. "Biological sex” means biological indication male female context reproductive potential capacity, sex chromosomes, naturally occurring sex hormones, gonads, non-ambiguous internal external genitalia present birth, without regard individual’s psychological, chosen, subjective experience gender. II. “Cross-sex hormones” means: (a) Testosterone androgens given biological females amounts larger potent would normally occur naturally healthy biological sex females; (b) Estrogen given biological males amounts larger potent would normally occur naturally healthy biological sex males. III. “Gender” means psychological, behavioral, social, cultural aspects male female. IV. “Gender reassignment surgery” means medical surgical service seeks surgically alter remove healthy physical anatomical characteristics features typical individual’s biological sex, order instill create physiological anatomical characteristics resemble sex different individual’s biological sex, including without limitation, genital nongenital gender reassignment surgery performed purpose assisting individual gender transition. V. “Gender transition” means process person goes identifying living gender corresponds biological sex identifying living gender different biological sex, may involve social, legal, physical changes. VI.(a) “Gender transition procedures” means medical surgical service, including without limitation physician's services, inpatient outpatient hospital services, prescribed drugs related gender transition seeks to: (1) Alter remove physical anatomical characteristics features typical individual’s biological sex; (2) Instill create physiological anatomical characteristics resemble sex different individual’s biological sex, including without limitation medical services provide puberty blocking drugs, cross-sex hormones, mechanisms promote development feminizing masculinizing features opposite biological sex, genital non-genital gender reassignment surgery performed purpose assisting individual gender transition. (b) “Gender transition procedures” include: (1) Services persons born medically verifiable disorder sex development, including person external biological sex characteristics ambiguous, born 46 XX chromosomes virilization, 46 XY chromosomes undervirilization, ovarian testicular tissue; (2) Services provided physician otherwise diagnosed disorder sexual development physician determined genetic biochemical testing person normal sex chromosome structure, sex steroid hormone production, sex steroid hormone action; (3) treatment infection, injury, disease, disorder caused exacerbated performance gender transition procedures, whether gender transition procedure performed accordance state federal law whether funding gender transition procedure permissible chapter; (4) procedure undertaken individual suffers physical disorder, physical injury, physical illness would, certified physician, place individual imminent danger death impairment major bodily function unless surgery performed. VII. “Genital gender reassignment surgery” means medical procedure performed purpose assisting individual gender transition, including without limitation: (a) Surgical procedures penectomy, orchiectomy, vaginoplasty, clitoroplasty, vulvoplasty biologically male patients hysterectomy ovariectomy biologically female patients; (b) Reconstruction fixed part urethra without metoidioplasty; (c) Phalloplasty, vaginectomy, scrotoplasty, implantation erection testicular prostheses biologically female patients. VIII. “Health care professional” person licensed, certified, otherwise authorized laws state administer health care ordinary course practice profession. IX. “Non-genital gender reassignment surgery” means medical procedures performed purpose assisting individual gender transition including without limitation: (a) Surgical procedures biologically male patients, augmentation mammoplasty, facial feminization surgery, liposuction, lipofilling, voice surgery, thyroid cartilage reduction, gluteal augmentation, hair reconstruction, various aesthetic procedures; (b) Surgical procedures biologically female patients, subcutaneous mastectomy, voice surgery, liposuction, lipofilling, pectoral implants, various aesthetic procedures. X. “Physician” means person licensed practice medicine state. XI. “Puberty-blocking drugs” means gonadotropin-releasing hormone analogues synthetic drugs used biological males stop luteinizing hormone secretion therefore testosterone secretion, synthetic drugs used biological females stop production estrogens progesterone, used delay suppress pubertal development children purpose assisting individual gender transition. XII. Public funds” means state, county, local government monies, addition department, agency, instrumentality authorized appropriated state law derived fund moneys deposited. 135-G:2 Prohibition Gender Transition Care Children Young Adults. I. physician health care professional shall provide gender transition procedures individual 18 years age. II. physician health care professional shall refer individual 18 years age health care professional gender transition procedures. III. physician health care professional prohibited providing following procedures gender transition procedures individual 18 years age: (a) Services persons born medically verifiable disorder sex development, including person external biological sex characteristics ambiguous, born 46 XX chromosomes virilization, 46 XY chromosomes undervirilization, ovarian testicular tissue; (b) Services provided physician otherwise diagnosed disorder sexual development physician determined genetic biochemical testing person normal sex chromosome structure, sex steroid hormone production, sex steroid hormone action; (c) treatment infection, injury, disease, disorder caused exacerbated performance gender transition procedures, whether gender transition procedure performed accordance state federal law whether funding gender transition procedure permissible chapter; (d) procedure undertaken individual suffers physical disorder, physical injury, physical illness would, certified physician, place individual imminent danger death impairment major bodily function unless surgery performed. 135-G:3 Prohibition Use Public Funds Gender Transition Care. I. Public funds shall directly indirectly used, granted, paid, distributed entity, organization, individual provides gender transition procedures individual 18 years age. II. Health care services furnished following situations shall include gender transition procedures individual 18 years age: (a) health care facility owned state county local government; (b) physician health care professional employed state county local government. III. New Hampshire Medicaid program shall reimburse provide coverage gender transition procedures individual 18 years age. 135-G:4 Enforcement. MISSISSIPPI LEGISLATURE 2023 Regular Session To: Education By: Senator(s) Hill Senate Bill 2763 ACT ENACT "FAMILIES' RIGHTS RESPONSIBILITIES ACT"; PROVIDE LIBERTY PARENT DIRECT UPBRINGING, EDUCATION, HEALTH CARE MENTAL HEALTH PARENT'S CHILD SHALL FUNDAMENTAL RIGHT; PROVIDE STATE, POLITICAL SUBDIVISION STATE GOVERNMENTAL ENTITY SHALL SUBSTANTIALLY BURDEN FUNDAMENTAL RIGHT PARENT DIRECT UPBRINGING, EDUCATION, HEALTH CARE MENTAL HEALTH PARENT'S CHILD WITHOUT DEMONSTRATING BURDEN REQUIRED COMPELLING GOVERNMENTAL INTEREST HIGHEST ORDER APPLIED PARENT CHILD LEAST RESTRICTIVE MEANS FURTHERING COMPELLING GOVERNMENTAL INTEREST; PROVIDE SPECIFIC RIGHTS RESPONSIBILITIES PARENTS; SET STANDARDS EDUCATIONAL INVOLVEMENT PARENTS SCHOOL DISTRICTS; PROVIDE PERSON, CORPORATION, ASSOCIATION, ORGANIZATION, STATE-SUPPORTED INSTITUTION INDIVIDUAL EMPLOYED ENTITIES SHALL OBTAIN CONSENT PARENT CHILD TAKING SPECIFIC MEDICAL CARE; PROVIDE CAUSE ACTION VIOLATION ACT; PROVIDE PARENTS INALIENABLE RIGHTS COMPREHENSIVE LISTED ACT; RELATED PURPOSES. ENACTED LEGISLATURE STATE MISSISSIPPI: SECTION 1. Title. Act shall known may cited "Families' Rights Responsibilities Act." SECTION 2. Definitions. purposes act, following terms shall meanings ascribed herein: (a) "Child" means individual age eighteen. (b) "Parent" means biological parent child, adoptive parent child, individual granted exclusive right authority welfare child state law. (c) "Substantial burden" means action directly indirectly constrains, inhibits, curtails denies right parent direct upbringing, education, health care mental health parent's child compels action contrary right parent direct upbringing, education, health care mental health parent's child. term shall include limited to, withholding benefits, assessing criminal, civil administrative penalties damages, exclusion governmental programs. SECTION 3. Parental rights fundamental. (1) liberty parent direct upbringing, education, health care mental health parent's child shall fundamental right. (2) state, political subdivision state governmental entity shall substantially burden fundamental right parent direct upbringing, education, health care mental health parent's child without demonstrating burden required compelling governmental interest highest order applied parent child least restrictive means furthering compelling governmental interest. SECTION 4. Rights responsibilities. (1) parental rights shall exclusively reserved parent child without obstruction interference state, political subdivision state, governmental entity institution, including without limitation, following rights responsibilities: (a) direct education child, including right choose public, private, religious home schools, right make reasonable choices within public schools education child; (b) access review school records relating child; (c) direct upbringing child; (d) direct moral religious training child; (e) make consent writing physical mental healthcare decisions child; (f) access review medical records child; (g) consent writing biometric scan child made, shared stored; (h) consent writing record child's blood deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) created, stored shared, unless authorized pursuant court order; (i) consent writing governmental entity makes video voice recording child, unless video voice recording made part of: (i) court proceeding; (ii) law enforcement investigation; (iii) forensic interview criminal Mississippi Department Child Protection Services investigation; (iv) security surveillance buildings grounds; (v) photo identification card; (j) notified promptly employee state, political subdivision state, governmental entity institution suspects abuse, neglect criminal offense committed child someone parent, unless incident first reported law enforcement notification parent would impede law enforcement Mississippi Department Child Protection Services investigation. (2) section authorize allow parent abuse neglect child defined Section 97-5-39. section apply parental action decision would end life. section prohibit court issuing order otherwise permitted law. (3) employee state, political subdivision state governmental entity, except law enforcement personnel, shall encourage coerce child withhold information child's parent. shall employee withhold child's parent information relevant physical, emotional mental health child. conduct shall grounds discipline employee, addition remedies provided parent Act. SECTION 5. Educational Involvement. (1) board education school district, consultation parents, teachers administrators, shall develop adopt policy promote involvement parents children enrolled schools within school district, including: (a) plan parent participation schools, designed improve parent teacher cooperation areas homework, attendance discipline; (b) Procedures parent may learn course study parent's child review educational learning materials, including source supplemental educational materials; (c) Procedures parent objects specific instruction presentation basis harmful may withdraw parent's child instruction presentation. SECTION 6. Medical Care. (1) Except otherwise provided law court order, person, corporation, association, organization, state-supported institution individual employed entities shall obtain consent parent child taking following actions: (a) Procuring, soliciting perform, arranging performance of, providing referral performing surgical procedures upon child; (b) Procuring, soliciting perform, arranging performance of, providing referral performing physical examination upon child; (c) Prescribing dispensing medication prescription drugs child; (d) Procuring, soliciting perform, arranging performance of, providing referral performing mental health evaluation clinical nonclinical setting mental health treatment child. (2) parental consent pursuant Subsection (1) section given telemedicine, person entity obtaining parental consent must verify identity parent site consent given. (3) provisions section shall apply determined physician that: (a) emergency exists; (b) Either following conditions true: (i) necessary perform activity listed Subsection (1) section order prevent death imminent, irreparable physical injury child, (ii) parent child cannot located contacted reasonably diligent effort. (4) provisions section shall apply performance abortions upon minors, shall governed Sections 41-41-51 41-41-63. SECTION 7. Cause Action. (1) parent may bring suit violation Act may raise Act defense judicial administrative proceeding without regard whether proceeding brought name State government, private person party. (2) Notwithstanding provision law, action Act may commenced, relief may granted, without regard whether person commencing action sought exhausted available administrative remedies. (3) person successfully asserts claim defense Act may recover declaratory relief, injunctive relief, compensatory damages, reasonable attorneys' fees costs appropriate relief. (4) Sovereign, governmental qualified immunities suit liability waived abolished extent liability created Act. SECTION 8. Rules Construction. (1) Unless rights legally waived legally terminated, parents inalienable rights comprehensive listed section. protections fundamental right parents direct upbringing, education, health care mental health child afforded Act addition protections provided Federal law, State law, State Federal constitutions. (2) Act shall construed favor broad protection fundamental right parents direct upbringing, education, health care mental health child. (3) Nothing Act shall construed authorize government burden fundamental right parents direct upbringing, education, health care mental health child. (4) child affirmative right access particular medical treatment, nothing Act shall construed grant child's parent affirmative right access treatment child's behalf. RELATED PURPOSES. ENACTED LEGISLATURE STATE MISSISSIPPI: SECTION 1. act shall known may cited "Mississippi Help Harm Act." SECTION 2. following shall codified Section 11-77-1, Mississippi Code 1972: 11-77-1. purposes chapter, following terms shall meanings defined section: (a) "Gender" means psychological, behavioral, social cultural aspects male female. (b) "Gender reassignment surgery services" means following medical surgical services performed individual purpose attempting alter appearance affirm individual's perception gender sex, appearance perception inconsistent individual's sex: (i) Prescribing administering puberty blocking medication stop delay normal puberty; (ii) Prescribing administering supraphysiologic doses testosterone androgens females; (iii) Prescribing administering supraphysiologic doses estrogen males; (iv) Performing surgeries sterilize, including castration, vasectomy, hysterectomy, oophorectomy, orchiectomy, penectomy; (v) Performing surgeries artificially construct tissue appearance genitalia differs individual's sex, including metoidioplasty, phalloplasty, vaginoplasty; (vi) Removing healthy non-diseased body part tissue, except male circumcision. (c) "Sex" means biological indication male female context reproductive potential capacity, sex chromosomes, naturally occurring sex hormones, gonads nonambiguous internal external genitalia present birth, without regard individual's psychological, chosen subjective experience gender. SECTION 3. following shall codified Section 11-77-3, Mississippi Code 1972: 11-77-3. (1) person shall knowingly perform provide gender reassignment surgery services minor. (2) person shall knowingly engage conduct aids abets gender reassignment surgery services performed provided minor. section may construed impose liability speech conduct protected federal state law. (3) licensed medical professional, including, limited to, physician, osteopath, physician assistant, nurse practitioner nurse, violates prohibition subsection (1) (2) section shall license State Mississippi revoked pursuant action taken respective licensing board. (4) claim accruing July 1, 2023, private cause action may brought physician, osteopath, hospital, prescribing caregiver, clinic health care facility injuries arising course medical, surgical professional services related performance gender reassignment surgery services. (3) "Gender" means psychological, behavioral, social, cultural aspects male female. (5) "Gender transition" means process person goes identifying living gender corresponds biological sex identifying living gender different biological sex, may involve social, legal, physical changes. (6)(a) "Gender-transition procedures" means medical surgical service including, limited to, physician's services, inpatient outpatient hospital services, prescribed drugs related gender transition seeks to: (i) alter remove physical anatomical characteristics features typical individual's biological sex; (ii) instill create physiological anatomical characteristics resemble sex different individual's biological sex including, limited to, medical services provide puberty-blocking drugs, cross-sex hormones, mechanisms promote development feminizing masculinizing features opposite biological sex, genital nongenital gender-reassignment surgery performed purpose assisting individual gender transition. No. 319 BILL ENTITLED ACT relating protection persons participation health care service reasons conscience; providing civil remedy; authorizing disciplinary action. ENACTED LEGISLATURE STATE TEXAS: SECTION 1. legislature finds that: (1) public policy state respect conscience health care providers right health care provider hold belief whether certain health care services morally acceptable; (2) without comprehensive protections, conscience health care providers may violated; (3) health care provider must protected required participation health care service provider declined participation reasons conscience discriminatory adverse action resulting nonparticipation. SECTION 2. Chapter 161, Health Safety Code, amended adding Subchapter X read follows: SUBCHAPTER X. TEXAS HEALTH CARE CONSCIENCE PROTECTION ACT Sec. 161.701. DEFINITIONS. subchapter: (1) "Conscience" means sincerely held set moral convictions arising from: (A) belief relation God; (B) religious faith spiritual practice; (C) moral philosophy ethical position, without regard whether philosophy position related religious faith. (2) "Emergency care" means bona fide emergency services provided sudden onset medical traumatic condition manifested acute symptoms sufficient severity, including severe pain, absence immediate medical attention could reasonably expected to: (A) place patient's health serious jeopardy; (B) result serious impairment patient's bodily functions; (C) result serious dysfunction bodily organ body part patient. (3) "Health care facility" means public private organization, corporation, partnership, sole proprietorship, association, agency, network, joint venture, entity provides health care services patients. term includes hospital, clinic, medical center, ambulatory surgical center, private physician's office, pharmacy, nursing home, laboratory diagnostic facility, infirmary, dispensary, medical school, nursing school, pharmacy school, medical training facility. (4) "Health care provider" means nurse, nurse aide, medical assistant, hospital employee, allied health professional, laboratory technician, clinic employee, nursing home employee, pharmacist, pharmacy employee, researcher, medical, pharmacy, nursing school student, professional, paraprofessional, or, without regard whether person holds license, person furnishes assists furnishing health care service. (5) "Health care service" means phase patient health care treatment. term includes: (A) examination, testing, diagnosis, referral, prognosis, dispensing administering drug device, ancillary research, instruction, therapy, treatment, preparing performing surgery procedure; (B) family planning, counseling, referrals, advice connection use procurement contraceptives, sterilization, abortion; (C) record-making procedures, preparation treatment notes, care treatment rendered health care facility, physician, health care provider. (6) "Physician" means individual licensed practice medicine state. Sec. 161.702. RIGHT DECLINE PARTICIPATION HEALTH CARE SERVICE REASONS CONSCIENCE; CONSTRUCTION SUBCHAPTER. (a) Except provided Subsection (b), person may decline participate health care service reasons conscience. (b) person may decline participate following services: (1) emergency care; (2) except provided Chapter 166, life-sustaining treatment. (c) Nothing subchapter may construed to: (1) supersede Chapter 166 governing provision, withholding, withdrawing life-sustaining treatment; (2) apply emergency care, life-sustaining treatment, cardiopulmonary resuscitation. (d) exercise right conscience section limited person's right refuse participate specific health care service. Sec. 161.703. IMMUNITY PHYSICIANS HEALTH CARE PROVIDERS. physician health care provider may held civilly criminally liable physician health care provider declines participate health care service wholly partly reasons conscience. Sec. 161.704. ADVERSE ACTION. person, including public official medical school institution conducts education training programs physicians health care providers, violates subchapter taking adverse action another person person declines participate health care service reasons conscience. Violations include discrimination taking adverse action regard to: (1) licensure; (2) certification; (3) employment terms, benefits, seniority status, promotion, transfer; (4) staff appointments privileges; (5) denial employment, admission, participation program person eligible; (6) reference reasons conscience application form; (7) questions regarding applicant's participation providing health care service reasons conscience; (8) imposition burden terms conditions employment; (9) denial aid, assistance, benefits; (10) conditional receipt aid, assistance, benefits; (11) coercion disqualification person receiving aid, assistance, benefits. Sec. 161.705. PROTOCOL DECLINING PARTICIPATION PROVISION HEALTH CARE SERVICE. (a) health care facility shall develop written protocol circumstances person declines participate providing health care service, emergency care life-sustaining treatment, reasons conscience. protocol must: (1) describe patient's access health care services information ensure patient permanently substantially prevented obtaining services; (2) explain process facility implement facilitate timely manner patient's access services. (b) person declines participate providing health care service reasons conscience shall: (1) notify health care facility declination; (2) comply applicable protocol developed section. (c) section permit protocol developed section require health care facility, physician, health care provider counsel patient refer patient another physician facility regarding health care service contrary conscience physician health care provider. Sec. 161.706. DISCIPLINARY ACTION; COMPLAINT. (a) health care facility, physician, health care provider holds license issued licensing agency state subject review disciplinary action licensing agency violation subchapter facility, physician, provider violated applicable licensing law. (b) person injured violation subchapter may file complaint licensing agency issued license health care facility, physician, health care provider allegedly violated subchapter. (c) physician health care provider may file complaint appropriate licensing agency section unless physician health care provider complies health care facility's protocol developed Section 161.705. Sec. 161.707. CIVIL REMEDIES. person injured violation subchapter may bring civil action person violates subchapter. person brings action section may obtain: (1) injunctive relief; (2) damages incurred person, including: (A) actual damages psychological, emotional, physical injuries resulting violation subchapter; (B) court costs; (C) reasonable attorney's fees; (3) injunctive relief damages. Abandoned includes judicial finding parent made minimal efforts support communicate child. Failure maintain normal parental relationship child without cause period six months constitutes prima facie evidence abandonment. 2. "Abuse" means infliction allowing physical injury, impairment bodily function disfigurement infliction allowing another person cause serious emotional damage evidenced severe anxiety, depression, withdrawal untoward aggressive behavior emotional damage diagnosed medical doctor psychologist caused acts omissions individual care, custody control child. (c) Unreasonable confinement child. 3. "Adult" means person eighteen years age older. 4. MISSISSIPPI LEGISLATURE 2023 Regular Session To: Public Health Human Services By: Representatives Currie, Arnold, Boyd (19th), Calvert, Carpenter, Creekmore IV, Darnell, Ford (54th), Hale, Lancaster, Mangold, Morgan, Pigott, Shanks, Turner, Wallace, Williamson House Bill 1127 ACT KNOWN MISSISSIPPI SAVE ADOLESCENTS EXPERIMENTATION (SAFE) ACT; PROVIDE LEGISLATIVE FINDINGS REGARDING RISKS GENDER TRANSITION PROCEDURES MINORS; PROVIDE DEFINITIONS CERTAIN TERMS; PROHIBIT PHYSICIANS HEALTH CARE PROFESSIONALS PROVIDING GENDER TRANSITION PROCEDURES PERSON EIGHTEEN YEARS AGE; PROHIBIT PHYSICIANS HEALTH CARE PROFESSIONALS REFERRING PERSON EIGHTEEN YEARS AGE HEALTH CARE PROFESSIONAL GENDER TRANSITION PROCEDURES; PROVIDE CERTAIN EXCEPTIONS PROHIBITIONS; PROHIBIT DIRECT INDIRECT USE, GRANT, PAYMENT DISTRIBUTION PUBLIC FUNDS ENTITY, ORGANIZATION INDIVIDUAL PROVIDES GENDER TRANSITION PROCEDURES PERSON EIGHTEEN YEARS AGE; PROVIDE HEALTH CARE SERVICES FURNISHED STATE LOCALLY-OWNED HEALTH CARE FACILITY PHYSICIAN HEALTH CARE PROFESSIONAL EMPLOYED STATE LOCAL GOVERNMENT SHALL INCLUDE GENDER TRANSITION PROCEDURES PERSON EIGHTEEN YEARS AGE; PROVIDE AMOUNTS PAID TAXABLE YEAR PROVISION GENDER TRANSITION PROCEDURES PREMIUMS HEALTH CARE COVERAGE INCLUDES COVERAGE GENDER TRANSITION PROCEDURES DEDUCTIBLE STATE INCOME TAX LAWS; PROVIDE REFERRAL PROVISION GENDER TRANSITION PROCEDURES PERSON EIGHTEEN YEARS AGE PHYSICIAN HEALTH CARE PROFESSIONAL UNPROFESSIONAL CONDUCT SUBJECT DISCIPLINE APPROPRIATE LICENSING ENTITY HEALTH CARE PROFESSIONAL; AUTHORIZE ATTORNEY GENERAL BRING ACTION ENFORCE COMPLIANCE ACT; CREATE NEW SECTION 43-13-117.7, MISSISSIPPI CODE 1972, PROHIBIT DIVISION MEDICAID REIMBURSING PROVIDING COVERAGE GENDER TRANSITION PROCEDURES PERSON EIGHTEEN YEARS AGE; AMEND SECTION 83-9-22, MISSISSIPPI CODE 1972, CREATE NEW SECTION 83-9-37, MISSISSIPPI CODE 1972, PROVIDE HEALTH BENEFIT PLAN INSURANCE POLICY PLAN PROVIDING HEALTH CARE COVERAGE SHALL INCLUDE REIMBURSEMENT GENDER TRANSITION PROCEDURES PERSON EIGHTEEN YEARS AGE, REQUIRED PROVIDE COVERAGE GENDER TRANSITION PROCEDURES PERSON EIGHTEEN YEARS AGE; AMEND SECTIONS 27-7-17, 73-15-29 73-25-29, MISSISSIPPI CODE 1972, CONFORM PROVISIONS ACT; RELATED PURPOSES. ENACTED LEGISLATURE STATE MISSISSIPPI: SECTION 1. Title. act shall known may cited "Mississippi Save Adolescents Experimentation (SAFE) Act" SECTION 2. Legislative findings. Legislature finds that: (a) Mississippi compelling government interest protecting health safety citizens, especially vulnerable children; (b) (i) small percentage American population experiences distress identifying biological sex. (ii) According American Psychiatric Association, "For natal adult males, prevalence ranges 0.005% 0.014%, natal females, 0.002% 0.003%."; (c) small percentage children gender nonconforming experience distress identifying biological sex, studies consistently demonstrate majority come identify biological sex adolescence adulthood, thereby rendering physiological interventions unnecessary; (d) Furthermore, scientific studies show individuals struggling distress identifying biological sex often already experienced psychopathology, indicates individuals encouraged seek mental health services address comorbidities underlying causes distress undertaking hormonal surgical intervention; (e) Even among people undergone inpatient gender reassignment procedures, suicide rates, psychiatric morbidities, mortality rates remain markedly elevated background population; (f) (i) health care providers prescribing puberty blocking drugs, gonadotropin-releasing hormone analogues, order delay onset progression puberty children experience distress identifying biological sex. (ii) prescribing puberty-blocking drugs done despite lack long-term longitudinal studies evaluating risks benefits using drugs treatment distress gender transition; (g) Health care providers also prescribing cross-sex hormones children experience distress identifying biological sex, despite fact randomized clinical trials conducted efficacy safety use cross-sex hormones adults children purpose treating distress gender transition; (h) use cross-sex hormones comes serious known risks, as: (i) biological females: 1. Erythrocytosis, increase red blood cells; 2. Severe liver dysfunction; 3. Coronary artery disease, including heart attacks; 4. Cerebrovascular disease, including strokes; 5. Hypertension; 6. Increased risk breast uterine cancers; 7. Irreversible infertility; (ii) biological males: 1. Thromboembolic disease, including blood clots; 2. Cholelithiasis, including gallstones; 3. Coronary artery disease, including heart attacks; 4. Macroprolactinoma, tumor pituitary gland; 5. Cerebrovascular disease, including strokes; 6. Hypertriglyceridemia, elevated level tryglycerides blood; 7. Breast cancer; 8. Irreversible infertility; (i) Genital nongenital gender reassignment surgeries generally recommended children, although evidence indicates referrals children surgeries becoming frequent; (j) (i) Genital gender reassignment surgery includes several irreversible invasive procedures males females involves alteration biologically healthy functional body parts. (ii) biological males, surgery may involve: 1. Genital reconstruction including penectomy, removal penis; 2. Orchiectomy, removal testicles; 3. Vaginoplasty, construction vagina-like structure, typically penile inversion procedure; 4. Clitoroplasty, construction clitoris-like structure; 5. Vulvoplasty, construction vulva-like structure. (iii) biological females, surgery may involve: 1. hysterectomy oophorectomy; 2. Reconstruction urethra; 3. Genital reconstruction including metoidioplasty phalloplasty, construction penis-like structure; 4. Vaginectomy, removal vagina; 5. Scrotoplasty, construction penis-like scrotum-like structure; 6. Implantation erection testicular prostheses; (k) complications, risks, long-term care concerns associated genital gender reassignment surgery males females numerous complex; (l) (i) Nongenital gender reassignment surgery includes various invasive procedures males females also involves alteration removal biologically normal functional body parts. (ii) biological males, surgery may involve: 1. Augmentation mammoplasty; 2. Facial feminization surgery; 3. Liposuction; 4. Lipofilling; 5. Voice surgery; 6. Thyroid cartilage reduction; 7. Gluteal augmentation; 8. Hair reconstruction; 9. aesthetic procedures. (iii) biological females, surgery may involve: 1. subcutaneous mastectomy; 2. Voice surgery; 3. Liposuction; 4. Lipofilling; 5. Pectoral implants; 6. aesthetic procedures; (m) (i) accepted principle economics public policy service product subsidized reimbursed, demand service product increased. (ii) 2015 2016, gender reassignment surgeries increased nearly twenty percent (20%) United States; (n) grave concern Legislature medical community allowing individuals experience distress identifying biological sex subjects irreversible drastic nongenital gender reassignment surgery irreversible, permanently sterilizing genital gender reassignment surgery, despite lack studies showing benefits extreme interventions outweigh risks; (o) risks gender transition procedures far outweigh benefit stage clinical study procedures. SECTION 3. Definitions. used act: (a) "Biological sex" means biological indication male female context reproductive potential capacity, sex chromosomes, naturally occurring sex hormones, gonads, nonambiguous internal external genitalia present birth, without regard individual's psychological, chosen, subjective experience gender; (b) "Cross-sex hormones" means: (i) Testosterone androgens given biological females amounts larger potent would normally occur naturally healthy biological sex females; (ii) Estrogen given biological males amounts larger potent would normally occur naturally healthy biological sex males; (c) "Gender" means psychological, behavioral, social, cultural aspects male female; (d) "Gender reassignment surgery" means medical surgical service seeks surgically alter remove healthy physical anatomical characteristics features typical individual's biological sex, order instill create physiological anatomical characteristics resemble sex different individual's biological sex, including, without limitation, genital nongenital gender reassignment surgery performed purpose assisting individual gender transition; (e) "Gender transition" means process person goes identifying living gender corresponds biological sex identifying living gender different biological sex, may involve social, legal, physical changes; (f) (i) "Gender transition procedures" means medical surgical service, including, without limitation, physician's services, inpatient outpatient hospital services, prescribed drugs related gender transition seeks to: 1. Alter remove physical anatomical characteristics features typical individual's biological sex; 2. Instill create physiological anatomical characteristics resemble sex different individual's biological sex, including, without limitation, medical services provide puberty-blocking drugs, cross-sex hormones, mechanisms promote development feminizing masculinizing features opposite biological sex, genital nongenital gender reassignment surgery performed purpose assisting individual gender transition. (ii) "Gender transition procedures" include: 1. Services persons born medically verifiable disorder sex development, including person external biological sex characteristics irresolvably ambiguous, born forty-six (46) XX chromosomes virilization, forty-six (46) XY chromosomes undervirilization, ovarian testicular tissue; 2. Services provided physician otherwise diagnosed disorder sexual development physician determined genetic biochemical testing person normal sex chromosome structure, sex steroid hormone production, sex steroid hormone action; 3. treatment infection, injury, disease, disorder caused exacerbated performance gender transition procedures, whether gender transition procedure performed accordance state federal law whether funding gender transition procedure permissible act; 4. procedure undertaken individual suffers physical disorder, physical injury, physical illness would, certified physician, place individual imminent danger death impairment major bodily function unless surgery performed; (g) "Genital gender reassignment surgery" means medical procedure performed purpose assisting individual gender transition, including, without limitation: (i) Surgical procedures penectomy, orchiectomy, vaginoplasty, clitoroplasty, vulvoplasty biologically male patients hysterectomy ovariectomy biologically female patients; (ii) Reconstruction fixed part urethra without metoidioplasty; (iii) Phalloplasty, vaginectomy, scrotoplasty, implantation erection testicular prostheses biologically female patients; (h) "Health care professional" person licensed, certified, otherwise authorized laws state administer health care ordinary course practice profession; (i) "Nongenital gender reassignment surgery" means medical procedures performed purpose assisting individual gender transition, including, without limitation: (i) Surgical procedures biologically male patients, augmentation mammoplasty, facial feminization surgery, liposuction, lipofilling, voice surgery, thyroid cartilage reduction, gluteal augmentation, hair reconstruction, various aesthetic procedures; (ii) Surgical procedures biologically female patients, subcutaneous mastectomy, voice surgery, liposuction, lipofilling, pectoral implants, various aesthetic procedures; (j) "Physician" means person licensed practice medicine state; (k) "Puberty-blocking drugs" means gonadotropin-releasing hormone analogues synthetic drugs used biological males stop luteinizing hormone secretion therefore testosterone secretion, synthetic drugs used biological females stop production estrogens progesterone, used delay suppress pubertal development children purpose assisting individual gender transition; (l) "Public funds" means state, county, local government monies, addition department, agency, instrumentality authorized appropriated state law derived fund moneys deposited. SECTION 4. Prohibition gender transition procedures minors. (1) physician health care professional shall provide gender transition procedures person eighteen (18) years age. (2) physician, health care professional shall refer person eighteen (18) years age health care professional gender transition procedures. (3) physician health care professional prohibited providing following procedures gender transition procedures person eighteen (18) years age: (a) Services persons born medically verifiable disorder sex development, including person external biological sex characteristics irresolvably ambiguous, born forty-six (46) XX chromosomes virilization, forty-six (46) XY chromosomes undervirilization, ovarian testicular tissue; (b) Services provided physician otherwise diagnosed disorder sexual development physician determined genetic biochemical testing person normal sex chromosome structure, sex steroid hormone production, sex steroid hormone action; (c) treatment infection, injury, disease, disorder caused exacerbated performance gender transition procedures, whether gender transition procedure performed accordance state federal law whether funding gender transition procedure permissible act; (d) procedure undertaken person suffers physical disorder, physical injury, physical illness would, certified physician, place person imminent danger death impairment major bodily function unless surgery performed. SECTION 5. Prohibition use public funds tax deduction gender transition procedures. (1) Public funds shall directly indirectly used, granted, paid, distributed entity, organization, individual provides gender transition procedures person eighteen (18) years age. (2) Health care services furnished following situations shall include gender transition procedures person eighteen (18) years age: (a) health care facility owned state county local government; (b) physician health care professional employed state county local government. (3) amount paid individual entity taxable year provision gender transition procedures premiums health care coverage includes coverage gender transition procedures deductible state income tax laws. (b) person eighteen (18) years age may bring action throughout minority parent next friend, may bring action name upon reaching majority time point twenty (20) years reaching age majority. SECTION 13. act shall take effect force July 1, 2023. 88R11351 EAS-D By: Hall S.B. No. 1082 BILL ENTITLED ACT relating definition use terms "male" "female" purposes certain government documents. ENACTED LEGISLATURE STATE TEXAS: SECTION 1. FINDINGS. legislature finds that: (1) males females possess unique immutable biological differences manifest prior birth increase individuals age experience puberty; (2) biological differences sexes mean females able get pregnant, give birth, breastfeed children; (3) biological differences sexes mean males are, average, bigger, stronger, faster females; (4) biological differences sexes leave females physically vulnerable males specific forms violence, including sexual violence; (5) females historically suffered discrimination education, athletics, employment; (6) biological differences sexes enduring may, circumstances, warrant creation separate social, educational, athletic, spaces order ensure individuals' safety allow members sex succeed thrive; (7) inconsistencies court rulings policy initiatives regard definitions "sex," "male," "female," "man," "woman" led endangerment single-sex spaces resources, necessitating clarification certain terms; (8) individual's sex defined individual's biological sex birth, either male female. SECTION 2. Chapter 2051, Government Code, amended adding Subchapter G read follows: SUBCHAPTER G. DEFINITIONS MALE FEMALE CERTAIN GOVERNMENT DOCUMENTS, PUBLICATIONS, NOTICES Sec. 2051.251. DEFINITIONS. subchapter: (1) "Female" means individual whose biological reproductive system developed produce ova. (2) "Governmental entity" meaning assigned Section 2051.041. (3) "Male" means individual whose biological reproductive system developed fertilize ova female. Sec. 2051.252. DEFINITIONS MALE FEMALE CERTAIN GOVERNMENT DOCUMENTS, PUBLICATIONS, NOTICES. document, policy, survey, questionnaire, report, publication, notice, written electronic material produced governmental entity official may reference two sexes, male female, requesting providing information regarding person's sex. SECTION 3. Act takes effect September 1, 2023. MISSISSIPPI LEGISLATURE 2023 Regular Session To: Judiciary, Division By: Senator(s) Hill, Branning Senate Bill 2773 ACT ENACT DEFENSE TITLE IX ACT; PROVIDE INTERPRETATION CLARIFICATION CERTAIN TERMS RELATING TITLE IX FEDERAL CODE; STATE LEGISLATIVE FINDINGS INTENT; CLARIFY TERMS PURPOSES STATE LAW; PROVIDE POLICIES LAWS DISTINGUISH SEXES SUBJECT INTERMEDIATE CONSTITUTIONAL SCRUTINY; RELATED PURPOSES. ENACTED LEGISLATURE STATE MISSISSIPPI: SECTION 1. (1) section shall known may cited "The Defense Title IX Act." (2) Legislature finds declares that: (a) Males females possess unique immutable biological differences manifest prior birth increase age puberty. (b) Biological differences sexes mean females get pregnant, give birth breastfeed children. (c) Biological differences sexes mean males are, average, larger size possess greater body strength females. (d) Whereas biological differences sexes expose females greater harm males specific forms violence, including sexual violence. (e) Females historically suffered discrimination education, athletics employment. (f) Females achieved inspirational significant accomplishments education, athletics employment. (g) Biological differences sexes enduring may, circumstances, warrant creation separate social, educational, athletic spaces order ensure safety and/or allow members sex succeed thrive. (h) comes sex: (i) "Equal" mean "same" "identical"; (ii) Separate inherently unequal. (i) Recent misguided court rulings policy initiatives relating definition "sex" led endangerment single-sex spaces resources dedicated women, thereby necessitating clarification certain terms. (3) Therefore, intent Legislature that: (a) purposes state/federal law, person's "sex" defined biological sex (either male female) birth. (b) purposes state/federal law, 'female' individual whose biological reproductive system developed produce ova; 'male' individual whose biological reproductive system developed fertilize ova female. (c) purposes state/federal law, 'woman' 'girl' refer human females, terms 'man' 'boy' refer human males. (d) purposes state/federal law, word 'mother' defined parent female sex 'father' defined parent male sex. (e) comes sex, 'equal' mean 'same' 'identical'. (f) comes sex, separate inherently unequal. (g) legitimate reasons distinguish sexes respect athletics, prisons detention facilities, domestic violence shelters, rape crisis centers, locker rooms, restrooms, areas biology, safety, and/or privacy implicated. (h) Policies laws distinguish sexes subject intermediate constitutional scrutiny, forbids unfair discrimination similarly-situated males females allows law distinguish sexes distinctions substantially related important governmental objectives. (i) public school school district federal/state/local agency, department, office collects vital statistics purpose complying anti-discrimination laws purpose gathering accurate public health, crime, economic data shall identify individual part collected data set either male female birth. SECTION 2. act shall take effect force July 1, 2023. END_STATUTE MISSISSIPPI LEGISLATURE 2023 Regular Session To: Judiciary By: Representative Ford (73rd) House Bill 1074 ACT ENACT TITLE IX PRESERVATION ACT; PROVIDE INTERPRETATION CLARIFICATION CERTAIN TERMS RELATING TITLE IX FEDERAL CODE; STATE LEGISLATIVE INTENT; CLARIFY TERMS PURPOSES STATE LAW; PROVIDE POLICIES LAWS DISTINGUISH SEXES SUBJECT INTERMEDIATE CONSTITUTIONAL SCRUTINY; REQUIRE PUBLIC SCHOOL, SCHOOL DISTRICT, STATE LOCAL AGENCY, DEPARTMENT OFFICE COLLECTS VITAL STATISTICS PURPOSE COMPLYING ANTI-DISCRIMINATION LAWS PURPOSE GATHERING ACCURATE PUBLIC HEALTH, CRIME, ECONOMIC DATA IDENTIFY INDIVIDUAL PART COLLECTED DATA SET EITHER MALE FEMALE BIRTH; RELATED PURPOSES. ENACTED LEGISLATURE STATE MISSISSIPPI: SECTION 1. act shall known may cited "The Title IX Preservation Act." SECTION 2. Legislature finds declares that: (a) Males females possess unique immutable biological differences manifest prior birth increase age experience puberty; (b) Biological differences sexes mean females able get pregnant, give birth breastfeed children; (c) Biological differences sexes mean males are, average, bigger, stronger, faster females; (d) Biological differences sexes leave females physically vulnerable males specific forms violence, including sexual violence; (e) Females historically suffered discrimination education, athletics employment; (f) Biological differences sexes enduring may, circumstances, warrant creation separate social, educational, athletic, spaces order ensure safety and/or allow members sex succeed thrive; (g) Inconsistencies court rulings policy initiatives respect definitions "sex," "male," "female," "man," "woman" led endangerment single-sex spaces resources, thereby necessitating clarification certain terms. SECTION 3. purposes state law: (a) person's "sex" defined biological sex (either male female) birth; (b) "female" individual whose biological reproductive system developed produce ova; "male" individual whose biological reproductive system developed fertilize ova female; (c) terms "woman" "girl" refer human females, terms "man" "boy" refer human males; (d) term "mother" defined parent female sex, term "father" defined parent male sex. SECTION 4. legitimate reasons distinguish sexes respect athletics, prisons, detention facilities, domestic violence shelters, rape crisis centers, locker rooms, restrooms, areas biology, safety and/or privacy implicated. SECTION 5. Policies laws distinguish sexes subject intermediate constitutional scrutiny forbids unfair discrimination similarly-situated males females allows law distinguish sexes distinctions substantially related important governmental objectives. SECTION 6. public school school district state local agency, department, office collects vital statistics purpose complying anti-discrimination laws purpose gathering accurate public health, crime, economic data shall identify individual part collected data set either male female birth. SECTION 7. (1) person employed public school, school district, state local agency, department office shall required address employee student enrolled entity pronoun, salutation, greeting, terminology inconsistent person's sex defined herein. (2) public school, school district, state local agency, department office shall required permit employee student dress manner inconsistent professional standards dress generally prevailing community persons sex, defined herein, person student. SECTION 8. act shall take effect force July 1, 2023. SECTION 2. Chapter 161, Health Safety Code, amended adding Subchapter X read follows: SUBCHAPTER X. GENDER TRANSITIONING GENDER REASSIGNMENT PROCEDURES TREATMENTS CERTAIN CHILDREN Sec. 161.701. DEFINITIONS. subchapter: (1) "Child" means individual younger years age. (2) "Health care provider" means person physician licensed, certified, otherwise authorized laws state provide render health care dispense prescribe prescription drug ordinary course business practice profession. (3) "Physician" means person licensed practice medicine state. Sec. 161.702. PROHIBITED PROVISION GENDER TRANSITIONING GENDER REASSIGNMENT PROCEDURES TREATMENTS CERTAIN CHILDREN. purpose transitioning child's biological sex determined sex organs, chromosomes, endogenous profiles child affirming child's perception child's sex perception inconsistent child's biological sex, physician health care provider may not: (1) perform surgery sterilize child, including: (A) castration; (B) vasectomy; (C) hysterectomy; (D) oophorectomy; (E) metoidioplasty; (F) orchiectomy; (G) penectomy; (H) phalloplasty; (I) vaginoplasty; (2) perform mastectomy; (3) provide, administer, prescribe, dispense following prescription drugs induce transient permanent infertility: (A) puberty suppression blocking prescription drugs stop delay normal puberty; (B) supraphysiologic doses testosterone females; (C) supraphysiologic doses estrogen males; (4) remove otherwise healthy non-diseased body part tissue. Sec. 161.703. EXCEPTIONS. prohibitions Section 161.702 apply provision physician health care provider, consent child's parent legal guardian, appropriate medically necessary gender transitioning gender reassignment procedures treatments child who: (1) born medically verifiable genetic disorder sex development, including: (A) 46, XX chromosomes virilization; (B) 46, XY chromosomes undervirilization; (C) ovarian testicular tissue; (2) normal sex chromosome structure male female determined physician genetic testing. Sec. 161.704. DISCIPLINARY ACTION. Texas Medical Board another state regulatory agency jurisdiction physician health care provider subject Section 161.702 shall revoke license, certification, authorization physician health care provider board agency determines violated section. SECTION 2. Chapter 161, Health Safety Code, amended adding Subchapter X read follows: SUBCHAPTER X. GENDER TRANSITIONING GENDER REASSIGNMENT PROCEDURES TREATMENTS CERTAIN CHILDREN Sec. 161.701. DEFINITIONS. subchapter: (1) "Child" means individual younger years age. (2) "Health care provider" means person physician licensed, certified, otherwise authorized state's laws provide render health care dispense prescribe prescription drug ordinary course business practice profession. (3) "Medicaid" means medical assistance program established Chapter 32, Human Resources Code. (4) "Physician" means person licensed practice medicine state. Sec. 161.702. PROHIBITED PROVISION GENDER TRANSITIONING GENDER REASSIGNMENT PROCEDURES TREATMENTS CERTAIN CHILDREN. purpose transitioning child's biological sex determined sex organs, chromosomes, endogenous profiles child affirming child's perception child's sex perception inconsistent child's biological sex, physician health care provider may knowingly: (1) perform surgery sterilizes child, including: (A) castration; (B) vasectomy; (C) hysterectomy; (D) oophorectomy; (E) metoidioplasty; (F) orchiectomy; (G) penectomy; (H) phalloplasty; (I) vaginoplasty; (2) perform mastectomy; (3) provide, prescribe, administer, dispense following prescription drugs induce transient permanent infertility: (A) puberty suppression blocking prescription drugs stop delay normal puberty; (B) supraphysiologic doses testosterone females; (C) supraphysiologic doses estrogen males; (4) remove otherwise healthy non-diseased body part tissue. Sec. 161.703. EXCEPTIONS. Section 161.702 apply provision physician health care provider, consent child's parent legal guardian, of: (1) puberty suppression blocking prescription drugs purpose normalizing puberty minor experiencing precocious puberty; (2) appropriate medically necessary procedures treatments child who: (A) born medically verifiable genetic disorder sex development, including: (i) 46,XX chromosomes virilization; (ii) 46,XY chromosomes undervirilization; (iii) ovarian testicular tissue; (B) normal sex chromosome structure male female determined physician genetic testing. Sec. 161.704. PROHIBITED USE PUBLIC MONEY. Public money may directly indirectly used, granted, paid, distributed health care provider, medical school, hospital, physician, entity, organization, individual provides facilitates provision procedure treatment child prohibited Section 161.702. Sec. 161.705. PROHIBITED STATE HEALTH PLAN REIMBURSEMENT. commission may provide Medicaid reimbursement child health plan program established Chapter 62 may provide reimbursement physician health care provider provision procedure treatment child prohibited Section 161.702. Sec. 161.706. ATTORNEY GENERAL ENFORCEMENT. (a) attorney general reason believe person committing, committed, commit violation Section 161.702, attorney general may bring action enforce subchapter restrain enjoin person committing, continuing commit, repeating violation. (b) Venue action brought section district court Travis County county violation occurred occur. SECTION 3. (2) "Health care provider" means physician, advanced practice registered nurse, physician assistant licensed practice State pursuant Articles 1 7, Chapter 47, Title 40 Article 1, Chapter 33, Title 40, respectively. (4) "Parent" means biological parent, adoptive parent, legal guardian, person legal custody child. Andrew S. Chesney SYNOPSIS INTRODUCED: 105 ILCS 5/10-20.85 new105 ILCS 5/34-18.82 new Amends School Code. Provides school districts may regulate restrict access public restrooms, locker rooms, dressing rooms, similar places basis biological sex may also adopt policy provides gender neutral alternative facilities students, staff, members public, school district deems appropriate. Provides school districts required to: (1) adopt policy restricts regulates access public restrooms, locker rooms, dressing rooms, similar places basis biological sex; (2) adopt policy includes facilitation gender neutral alternative facilities students, staff, members public; (3) limit access minor accompanied adult guardian opposite sex specified facility appropriate adult guardian; (4) prohibit person disabilities using specified facility appropriate biological sex either person disabilities adult caretaker providing assistance; (5) prohibit access facilities custodial staff, school staff, persons emergency situation; (6) alter current policies access public restrooms, locker rooms, dressing rooms, similar places. Document reformatted meet World Wide Web specifications.) bill amend South Carolina Code Laws adding Section 40-47-300 provide definitions; adding Section 40-47-310 provide person younger twenty-one years age may undergo gender transition procedures; adding Section 40-47-320 provide person younger twenty-one years age may receive appropriate medical services otherwise related gender transition procedures limited circumstances; adding Section 40-47-330 provide prerequisites person older twenty-one years age undergo gender transition procedures; adding Section 40-47-340 provide public funds may used pay gender transition procedures; adding Section 59-32-35 provide gender identity disorders may taught part comprehensive health education program, provide students gender identity disorders must encouraged seek mental health treatment disorder must encouraged seek gender transition procedures, provide school personnel must notify parents learn student suffers gender identity disorder. enacted General Assembly State South Carolina: SECTION 1.Chapter 47, Title 40 S.C. Code amended adding: Article Gender Reassignment Procedures Section 40-47-300.For purposes article: (1) "Biological sex" means biological indication male female context reproductive potential capacity, sex chromosomes, naturally occurring sex hormones, gonads, nonambiguous internal external genitalia present birth, without regard individual's psychological, chosen, subjective experience gender. (2) "Cross-sex hormones" means testosterone androgens given biological females amounts larger potent would normally occur naturally healthy biological sex females; estrogen given biological males amounts larger potent would normally occur naturally healthy biological sex males; (3) "Gender" means psychological, behavioral, social, cultural aspects male female. (4) "Gender reassignment surgery" means medical surgical service seeks surgically alter remove healthy physical anatomical characteristics features typical individual's biological sex, order instill create physiological anatomical characteristics resemble sex different individual's biological sex, including without limitation, genital nongenital gender reassignment surgery performed purpose assisting individual gender transition. (5) "Gender transition" means process person goes identifying living gender corresponds biological sex identifying living gender different biological sex, may involve social, legal, physical changes. (6) "Gender transition procedures" means medical surgical service, including without limitation physician's services, inpatient outpatient hospital services, prescribed drugs related gender transition seeks to: (a) alter remove physical anatomical characteristics features typical individual's biological sex; (b) instill create physiological anatomical characteristics resemble sex different individual's biological sex, including without limitation medical services provide puberty-blocking drugs, cross-sex hormones, mechanisms promote development feminizing masculinizing features opposite biological sex, genital nongenital gender reassignment surgery performed purpose assisting individual gender transition. (7) "Genital gender reassignment surgery" means medical procedure performed purpose assisting individual gender transition, including without limitation: (a) surgical procedures penectomy, orchiectomy, vaginoplasty, clitoroplasty, vulvoplasty biologically male patients hysterectomy ovariectomy biologically female patients; (b) reconstruction fixed part urethra without metoidioplasty; (c) phalloplasty, vaginectomy, scrotoplasty, implantation erection testicular prostheses biologically female patients, (8) "Nongenital gender reassignment surgery" means medical procedures performed purpose assisting individual gender transition including without limitation: (a) surgical procedures biologically male patients, augmentation mammoplasty, facial feminization surgery, liposuction, lipofilling, voice surgery, thyroid cartilage reduction, gluteal augmentation, hair reconstruction, various aesthetic procedures; (b) surgical procedures biologically female patients, subcutaneous mastectomy, voice surgery, liposuction, lipofilling, pectoral implants, various aesthetic procedures. (9) "Puberty-blocking drugs" means gonadotropin-releasing hormone analogues synthetic drugs used biological males stop luteinizing hormone secretion therefore testosterone secretion, synthetic drugs used biological females stop production estrogens progesterone, used delay suppress pubertal development children purpose assisting individual gender transition. (10) "Public funds" means state, county, local government monies, addition department, agency, instrumentality authorized appropriated state law derived fund moneys deposited. Section 40-47-310.A person younger twenty-one years age may undergo gender transition procedures. Section 40-47-320.Notwithstanding provisions contained Section 4-47-310, physician may provide patient twenty-one years age: (1) appropriate medical services person born medically verifiable disorder sexual development, including, limited to, person external biological sexual characteristics ambiguous, including, limited to, people born forty-six XX chromosomes virilization forty-six XY chromosomes undervirilization ovarian testicular tissue; (2) appropriate medical services treat disorder sexual development arising person normal sex chromosome structure, sex steroid hormone production, sex steroid hormone action diagnosed genetic biochemical testing; (3) treatment infection, injury, disease, disorder caused exacerbated performance gender transition procedures, whether gender transition procedure performed accordance state federal law; (4) procedure undertaken person suffers physical disorder, physical injury, physical illness would, certified physician, place person imminent danger death impairment major bodily function unless treated physician. Section 40-47-330.In order person twenty-one years age older receive gender transition procedures, must first obtain referral primary care physician referral licensed psychiatrist must certify person diagnosed gender dysphoria similar condition psychiatrist psychiatrist believes gender transition procedures would appropriate person. Section 40-47-340.Public funds may used directly indirectly gender reassignment services. SECTION 2.Chapter 32, Title 59 S.C. Code amended adding: Section 59-32-35.(A) comprehensive health education program may include instruction concerning gender dysphoria, gender identity disorder, psychological conditions result person identifying gender different sex assigned birth sex-related physical characteristics. (B) Instruction provided students pursuant subsection (A) must: (1) encourage students afflicted gender identity condition seek assistance mental health professional; (2) encourage student pursue gender transition procedures, defined Section 40-47-300. (C) teacher, school administrator, school employee suspects knows student suffers gender dysphoria, gender identity disorder, psychological conditions result person identifying gender different sex assigned birth sex-related physical characteristics must notify student's parent legal guardian. provisions subsection apply whether teacher, school administrator, school employee learns student's condition instruction provided section otherwise. ENACTED LEGISLATURE STATE MISSISSIPPI: SECTION 1. purposes act, following terms shall meanings ascribed herein: (a) "Biological sex" means biological indication male female context reproductive potential capacity, sex chromosomes, naturally occurring sex hormones, gonads, nonambiguous internal external genitalia present birth, without regard individual's psychological, chosen, subjective experience gender; (b) "Cross-sex hormones" means: (i) Testosterone androgens given biological females amounts larger potent would normally occur naturally healthy biological sex females; (ii) Estrogen given biological males amounts larger potent would normally occur naturally healthy biological sex males; (c) "Gender" means psychological, behavioral, social, cultural aspects male female; (d) "Gender reassignment surgery" means medical surgical service seeks surgically alter remove healthy physical anatomical characteristics features typical individual's biological sex, order instill create physiological anatomical characteristics resemble sex different individual's biological sex, including, without limitation, genital nongenital gender reassignment surgery performed purpose assisting individual gender transition including, without limitation: (i) Surgical procedures penectomy, orchiectomy, vaginoplasty, clitoroplasty, vulvoplasty biologically male patients hysterectomy ovariectomy biologically female patients; (ii) Reconstruction fixed part urethra without metoidioplasty; (iii) Phalloplasty, vaginectomy, scrotoplasty, implantation erection testicular prostheses biologically female patients; (iv) Surgical procedures biologically male patients, augmentation mammoplasty, facial feminization surgery, liposuction, lipofilling, voice surgery, thyroid cartilage reduction, gluteal augmentation, hair reconstruction, various aesthetic procedures; (v) Surgical procedures biologically female patients, subcutaneous mastectomy, voice surgery, liposuction, lipofilling, pectoral implants, various aesthetic procedures; (e) "Gender transition" means process person goes identifying living gender corresponds biological sex identifying living gender different biological sex, may involve social, legal, physical changes; (f) (i) "Gender transition procedures" means medical surgical service, including, without limitation, physician's services, inpatient outpatient hospital services, prescribed drugs related gender transition seek to: 1. Alter remove physical anatomical characteristics features typical individual's biological sex; 2. Instill create physiological anatomical characteristics resemble sex different individual's biological sex, including, without limitation, medical services provide puberty-blocking drugs, cross-sex hormones, mechanisms promote development feminizing masculinizing features opposite biological sex, genital nongenital gender reassignment surgery performed purpose assisting individual gender transition. (ii) "Gender transition procedures" include: 1. Services persons born medically verifiable disorder sex development, including person external biological sex characteristics irresolvably ambiguous, born forty-six (46) XX chromosomes virilization, forty-six (46) XY chromosomes undervirilization, ovarian testicular tissue; 2. Services provided physician otherwise diagnosed disorder sexual development physician determined genetic biochemical testing person normal sex chromosome structure, sex steroid hormone production, sex steroid hormone action; 3. treatment infection, injury, disease, disorder caused exacerbated performance gender transition procedures, whether gender transition procedure performed accordance state federal law whether funding gender transition procedure permissible act; 4. procedure undertaken individual suffers physical disorder, physical injury, physical illness would, certified physician, place individual imminent danger death impairment major bodily function unless surgery performed; (g) "Health care professional" means person licensed, certified, otherwise authorized laws state administer health care ordinary course practice profession; (h) "Physician" means person licensed practice medicine state; (i) "Puberty-blocking drugs" means gonadotropin-releasing hormone analogues synthetic drugs used biological males stop luteinizing hormone secretion therefore testosterone secretion, synthetic drugs used biological females stop production estrogens progesterone, used delay suppress pubertal development children purpose assisting individual gender transition; (j) "Public funds" means state, county, local government monies, addition department, agency, instrumentality authorized appropriated state law derived fund monies deposited. SECTION 2. (1) (a) person may administer, supply, consent to, assist administering supplying puberty-blocking drug cross-sex hormone person age twenty-one (21) years age. (c) physician health care professional shall provide gender transition procedures person twenty-one (21) years age. MISSISSIPPI LEGISLATURE 2023 Regular Session To: Judiciary By: Representative Hobgood-Wilkes House Bill 1144 ACT CREATE TITLE IX PRESERVATION ACT; STATE LEGISLATIVE INTENT; PROVIDE INTERPRETATION CLARIFICATION CERTAIN TERMS RELATING TITLE IX FEDERAL CODE; CLARIFY TERMS PURPOSES STATE LAW; PROVIDE POLICIES LAWS DISTINGUISH SEXES SUBJECT INTERMEDIATE CONSTITUTIONAL SCRUTINY; REQUIRE PUBLIC SCHOOL, SCHOOL DISTRICT, STATE LOCAL AGENCY, DEPARTMENT, OFFICE COLLECTS VITAL STATISTICS PURPOSE COMPLYING ANTI-DISCRIMINATION LAWS PURPOSE GATHERING ACCURATE PUBLIC HEALTH, CRIME, ECONOMIC DATA IDENTIFY INDIVIDUAL PART COLLECTED DATA SET EITHER MALE FEMALE BIRTH; RELATED PURPOSES. ENACTED LEGISLATURE STATE MISSISSIPPI: SECTION 1. act shall known may cited "Title IX Preservation Act." SECTION 2. Legislature finds that: (a) Males females possess unique immutable biological differences manifest prior birth increase age experience puberty; (b) Biological differences sexes means females able get pregnant, give birth, breastfeed children; (c) Biological differences sexes means males are, average, bigger, stronger, faster females; (d) Biological differences sexes leave females physically vulnerable males specific forms violence, including sexual violence; (e) Females historically suffered discrimination education, athletics, employment; (f) Biological differences sexes enduring may, circumstances, warrant creation separate social, educational, athletic, spaces order ensure safety and/or allow members sex succeed thrive; (g) Inconsistencies court rulings policy initiatives respect definitions "sex," "male," "female," "man," "woman" led endangerment single-sex spaces resources, thereby necessitating clarification certain terms. SECTION 3. purposes state law: (a) person's "sex" defined biological sex, either male female, birth; (b) "female" individual whose biological reproductive system developed produce ova; "male" individual whose biological reproductive system developed fertilize ova female; (c) "Woman" "girl" refer human females, terms "man" "boy" refer human males; (d) word "mother" defined parent female sex "father" defined parent male sex; (e) comes sex, "equal" mean "same" "identical"; (f) comes sex, separate inherently unequal. SECTION 4. legitimate reasons distinguish sexes respect athletics, prisons detention facilities, domestic violence shelters, rape crisis centers, locker rooms, restrooms, areas biology, safety, and/or privacy implicated. SECTION 5. Policies laws distinguish sexes subject intermediate constitutional scrutiny, forbids unfair discrimination similarly-situated males females allows law distinguish sexes distinctions substantially related important governmental objectives. SECTION 6. public school school district state local agency, department, office collects vital statistics purpose complying anti-discrimination laws purpose gathering accurate public health, crime, economic data shall identify individual part collected data set either male female birth. SECTION 7. act shall take effect force July 1, 2023. 2023S0054-T 01/23/23 By: Middleton S.B.
