MCGUCKIN District 10 (Ocean) Assemblyman JOHN CATALANO District 10 (Ocean) Co-Sponsored by: Assemblymen Scharfenberger Peterson SYNOPSIS "Fairness Women's Sports Act." CURRENT VERSION TEXT Introduced Pending Technical Review Legislative Counsel. Act concerning student participation school-sanctioned sporting events supplementing chapter 11 Title 18A New Jersey Statutes. Enacted Senate General Assembly State New Jersey: 1. Legislature finds declares that: a. United States v. Virginia, 518 U.S.515, 533 (1996), Supreme Court noted "inherent differences men women," differences "remain cause celebration, denigration members either sex artificial constraints individual's opportunity." b. "inherent differences" range chromosomal hormonal differences physiological differences. c. Men generally denser stronger bones, tendons, ligaments well larger hearts, greater lung volume per body mass, higher red blood cell count, higher hemoglobin. d. Men also higher natural levels testosterone, affects traits hemoglobin levels, body fat content, storage use carbohydrates, development type 2 muscle fibers, result men able generate higher speed power physical activity. e. classifications based sex generally disfavored, court United States v. Virginia also recognized "sex classifications may used compensate women particular economic disabilities [they have] suffered, promote equal employment opportunity, [and] advance full development talent capacities Nation's people." f. One place sex classifications allow "full development talent capacities Nation's people" context sports athletics. g. biological differences females males, especially relate natural levels testosterone, help explain male female secondary sex characteristics develop puberty lifelong effects, including important success sports strength, speed, endurance. h. Courts recognized inherent, physiological differences males females result different athletic capabilities. i. Specifically, courts noted males females similarly situated athletic competition due innate physiological differences males generally possess physiological advantages female competitors. j. recent study female male Olympic performances since 1983 found that, although athletes sexes improved time span, "gender gap" female male performances remained stable. suggests women's performances high level never match men. k. benefits natural testosterone provides male athletes diminished use puberty blockers cross-sex hormones. recent study impact treatments found even 12 months hormonal therapy, man identifies woman taking cross-sex hormones possesses significant advantage female athletes still likely performance benefits women. l. separate sex-specific teams furthers efforts promote sex equality. Sex-specific teams accomplish providing opportunities female athletes demonstrate skill, strength, athletic abilities also providing opportunities obtain recognition accolades, college scholarships, numerous long-term benefits flow success athletic endeavors. 2. a. Interscholastic, intercollegiate, intramural, club athletic teams sports sponsored public nonpublic school member New Jersey State Interscholastic Athletic Association (NJSIAA), public institution higher education higher education institution member national collegiate athletic association (NCAA), national association intercollegiate athletics (NAIA), national junior college athletic association (NJCAA) shall expressly designated one following based biological sex: (1) males, men, boys; (2) females, women, girls; (3) coed mixed. b. Athletic teams sports designated females, women, girls shall open students male sex. student's sex disputed, student shall establish sex presenting signed physician's statement shall indicate student's sex based solely on: (1) student's internal external reproductive anatomy; (2) student's normal endogenously produced levels testosterone; (3) analysis student's genetic makeup. 3. government entity, licensing accrediting organization, athletic association organization shall entertain complaint, open investigation, take adverse action school institution higher education maintaining separate interscholastic, intercollegiate, intramural, club athletic teams sports students female sex. 4. a. student deprived athletic opportunity suffers direct indirect harm result violation chapter shall private cause action injunctive relief, damages, relief available law school institution higher education. b. student subject retaliation adverse action school, institution higher education, athletic association organization result reporting violation chapter employee representative school, institution, athletic association organization, State federal agency oversight schools institutions higher education State, shall private cause action injunctive relief, damages, relief available law school, institution, athletic association organization. c. school institution higher education suffers direct indirect harm result violation chapter shall private cause action injunctive relief, damages, relief available law government entity, licensing accrediting organization, athletic association organization. d. civil actions permitted section shall initiated within two years harm occurred. Persons organizations prevail claim brought pursuant section shall entitled monetary damages, including psychological, emotional, physical harm suffered, reasonable attorney's fees costs, appropriate relief. 5. act shall take effect immediately. PARENTAL RIGHTS REMEDIES (a) Texas Education Agency shall adopt procedures notifying student's parent change student's services monitoring related student's mental, emotional, physical health well-being school's ability provide safe supportive learning environment student. procedures must reinforce fundamental right parents make decisions regarding upbringing control children requiring school district personnel encourage student discuss issues relating well-being parent facilitate discussion issue parent. procedures may prohibit parents accessing student's education health records created, maintained, used school district. Parental consent health care service waive parent's right access student's educational health records notified change student's services monitoring provided section. (c) administering student well-being questionnaire health screening form student kindergarten grade 5, school district must provide questionnaire health screening form parent obtain permission parent. (d) school district shall adopt procedures parent notify principal, designee, regarding concerns section student's school process resolving concerns within 7 calendar days notification parent. (1) minimum, procedures must require within 30 days notification parent concern remains unresolved, school district must either resolve concern provide statement reasons resolving concern. (2) concern resolved school district, parent may: (A) Request Commissioner Education appoint special magistrate member State Bar Texas good standing least 5 years' experience administrative law. special magistrate shall determine facts relating dispute school district procedure practice, consider information provided school district, render recommended decision resolution State Board Education within 30 days receipt request parent. State Board Education must approve reject recommended decision next regularly scheduled meeting calendar days 30 days date recommended decision transmitted. costs special magistrate shall borne school district. No. 41 BILL ENTITLED ACT relating professional liability insurance coverage prohibitions provision certain children procedures treatments gender transitioning, gender reassignment, gender dysphoria. ENACTED LEGISLATURE STATE TEXAS: SECTION 1. Chapter 161, Health Safety Code, amended adding Subchapter X read follows: SUBCHAPTER X. GENDER TRANSITIONING GENDER REASSIGNMENT PROCEDURES TREATMENTS CERTAIN CHILDREN Sec. 161.701. DEFINITIONS. subchapter: (1) "Child" means individual younger years age. (2) "Health care provider" means person physician licensed, certified, otherwise authorized laws state provide render health care dispense prescribe prescription drug ordinary course business practice profession. (3) "Physician" means person licensed practice medicine state. Sec. 161.702. PROHIBITED PROVISION GENDER TRANSITIONING GENDER REASSIGNMENT PROCEDURES TREATMENTS CERTAIN CHILDREN. purpose transitioning child's biological sex determined sex organs, chromosomes, endogenous profiles child affirming child's perception child's sex perception inconsistent child's biological sex, physician health care provider may not: (1) perform surgery sterilize child, including: (A) castration; (B) vasectomy; (C) hysterectomy; (D) oophorectomy; (E) metoidioplasty; (F) orchiectomy; (G) penectomy; (H) phalloplasty; (I) vaginoplasty; (2) perform mastectomy; (3) provide, administer, prescribe, dispense following prescription drugs induce transient permanent infertility: (A) puberty suppression blocking prescription drugs stop delay normal puberty; (B) supraphysiologic doses testosterone females; (C) supraphysiologic doses estrogen males; (4) remove otherwise healthy non-diseased body part tissue. Sec. 161.703. EXCEPTIONS. prohibitions Section 161.702 apply provision physician health care provider, consent child's parent legal guardian, appropriate medically necessary gender transitioning gender reassignment procedures treatments child who: (1) born medically verifiable genetic disorder sex development, including: (A) 46, XX chromosomes virilization; (B) 46, XY chromosomes undervirilization; (C) ovarian testicular tissue; (2) normal sex chromosome structure male female determined physician genetic testing. NO. 891 THIRTY-SECOND LEGISLATURE, 2023 STATE HAWAII BILL ACT relating gender transition surgery. ENACTED LEGISLATURE STATE HAWAII: SECTION 1. legislature finds culture war continues rage United States. years, many social disputes arising within cultural conversations United States surrounding gender, gender identity, gender expression, topic transgenderism firm grip public discourse. Topics transgenderism evoke many powerful emotions people various opinions, across levels society. appears next big society issue addressed either legislative branch judicial branch government. legislature also finds human brain reach full development roughly age 25. widely known accepted fact, one instrumental background enacting laws protect minors. minors cannot firearms, buy alcohol, vote, circumstances cannot make decisions legal consequence enter contracts. However, new cultural movement seems perfectly fine allowing minors request life-altering medical surgeries alter bodies permanently. "gender transition" surgeries include limited operations double mastectomies, feminizing vaginoplasty, masculinizing phalloplasty, scrotoplasty, metoidioplasty, facial reconstruction surgery. legislature finds protecting children decisions capacity fully understand necessary proper. growing number "detransitioners," individuals undergone gender transition surgeries therapy, since decided transition back original gender. many stories detransitioners started permeate discussion transgenderism, experiences reinforce need protect minors making irreversible medical decisions unable fully understand. preserve innocence childhood prevent future regret among current youth population, imperative state prohibit gender reassignment / gender transition surgeries minors. purpose Act prohibit gender reassignment / transition surgeries minors. CURRENT VERSION TEXT introduced. Act concerning protection children supplementing Title 45 Revised Statutes. Enacted Senate General Assembly State New Jersey: 1. act shall known may cited "Child Protection Anti-Mutilation Act." 2. a. used section: "Minor" means unemancipated person age 18. "Sex" means biological state male female, based individual's sex organs, chromosomes, endogenous hormone profiles. b. Notwithstanding provision law contrary, except provided subsection c. section, person shall engage respect to, perform upon, cause following practices performed upon, minor: (1) prescribing administering puberty blocking medication stop delay normal puberty; (2) prescribing administering supraphysiologic doses testosterone androgens females; (3) prescribing administering supraphysiologic doses estrogen males; (4) performing surgeries result sterilization, including, limited to, castration, vasectomy, hysterectomy, oophorectomy, orchiectomy, penectomy; (5) performing surgeries artificially construct tissue appearance genitalia differs individual's sex, including, limited to, metoidioplasty, phalloplasty, vaginoplasty; (6) removing healthy non-diseased body part tissue, except case male circumcision. c. provisions subsection b. section shall apply procedures undertaken treat minor medically verifiable disorder sex development, including: (1) individual external biological sex characteristics irresolvably ambiguous, including individual 46 XX chromosomes virilization, individual 46 XY chromosomes virilization, individual ovarian testicular tissue; (2) individual diagnosed physician disorder sexual development, physician determined, genetic biochemical testing, person normal sex chromosome structure, sex steroid hormone production, sex steroid hormone action male female. d. person violates provisions section shall guilty crime third degree. 3. Director Division Consumer Affairs Department Law Public Safety Commissioner Health shall adopt rules regulations, pursuant "Administrative Procedure Act," P.L.1968, c.410 (C.52:14B-1 et seq.), necessary implement provisions act. 4. act shall take effect immediately. STATEMENT bill establishes "Child Protection Anti-Mutilation Act." bill prohibits person from, regard unemancipated person 18 years age, engaging in, performing, causing performed following practices: 1) prescribing administering puberty blocking medication stop delay normal puberty; 2) prescribing administering supraphysiologic doses testosterone androgens females; 3) prescribing administering supraphysiologic doses estrogen males; 4) performing surgeries result sterilization, including, limited to, castration, vasectomy, hysterectomy, oophorectomy, orchiectomy, penectomy; 5) performing surgeries artificially construct tissue appearance genitalia differs individual's sex, including, limited to, metoidioplasty, phalloplasty, vaginoplasty; 6) removing healthy non-diseased body part tissue, except case male circumcision. restrictions established bill apply procedures undertaken treat minor medically verifiable disorder sex development, including: individual external biological sex characteristics irresolvably ambiguous individual diagnosed physician disorder sexual development, physician determined, genetic biochemical testing, person normal sex chromosome structure, sex steroid hormone production, sex steroid hormone action male female. person violates provisions bill guilty crime third degree, punishable imprisonment three five years, fine $15,000, both. ASSEMBLY, No. 1418 STATE NEW JERSEY 220th LEGISLATURE PRE-FILED INTRODUCTION 2022 SESSION Sponsored by: Assemblyman ROBERT AUTH District 39 (Bergen Passaic) Co-Sponsored by: Assemblymen Peterson, Scharfenberger, Catalano, McGuckin DiMaio SYNOPSIS Provides public school parent objects learning material activity parent considers harmful may receive voucher school district enroll student nonpublic school. CURRENT VERSION TEXT Introduced Pending Technical Review Legislative Counsel. Act concerning vouchers certain public school students supplementing chapter 35 Title 18A New Jersey Statutes. Enacted Senate General Assembly State New Jersey: 1. event parent guardian student enrolled school district objects learning material activity part curriculum, basis material activity harmful, withdraws child school district enrolls child nonpublic school, resident school district shall provide parent guardian voucher support tuition fees nonpublic school. voucher shall equal 75 percent resident school district's annual spending per pupil prorated based upon number days remaining school year. objection learning material activity basis harmful includes, limited to, objection material activity questions, violates, conflicts parent guardian's belief practice regarding sex, sexuality, sexual orientation, gender identity expression, conscience, ethics, morality, religion. 2. act shall take effect immediately. STATEMENT bill provides event parent guardian student enrolled school district objects learning material activity part curriculum, basis material activity harmful, withdraws child school district enrolls child nonpublic school, resident school district required provide parent guardian voucher support tuition fees nonpublic school. voucher equal 75 percent resident school district's annual spending per pupil prorated based upon number days remaining school year. objection learning material activity basis harmful includes, limited to, objection material activity questions, violates, conflicts parent guardian's belief practice regarding sex, sexuality, sexual orientation, gender identity expression, conscience, ethics, morality, religion. TESTA, JR. District 1 (Atlantic, Cape May Cumberland) Senator JAMES W. HOLZAPFEL District 10 (Ocean) SYNOPSIS "Fairness Women's Sports Act." CURRENT VERSION TEXT Introduced Pending Technical Review Legislative Counsel. Act concerning student participation school-sanctioned sporting events supplementing chapter 11 Title 18A New Jersey Statutes. Enacted Senate General Assembly State New Jersey: 1. Legislature finds declares that: a. United States v. Virginia, 518 U.S.515, 533 (1996), Supreme Court noted "inherent differences men women," differences "remain cause celebration, denigration members either sex artificial constraints individual's opportunity." b. "inherent differences" range chromosomal hormonal differences physiological differences. c. Men generally denser stronger bones, tendons, ligaments well larger hearts, greater lung volume per body mass, higher red blood cell count, higher hemoglobin. d. Men also higher natural levels testosterone, affects traits hemoglobin levels, body fat content, storage use carbohydrates, development type 2 muscle fibers, result men able generate higher speed power physical activity. e. classifications based sex generally disfavored, court United States v. Virginia also recognized "sex classifications may used compensate women particular economic disabilities [they have] suffered, promote equal employment opportunity, [and] advance full development talent capacities Nation's people." f. One place sex classifications allow "full development talent capacities Nation's people" context sports athletics. g. biological differences females males, especially relate natural levels testosterone, help explain male female secondary sex characteristics develop puberty lifelong effects, including important success sports strength, speed, endurance. h. Courts recognized inherent, physiological differences males females result different athletic capabilities. i. Specifically, courts noted males females similarly situated athletic competition due innate physiological differences males generally possess physiological advantages female competitors. j. recent study female male Olympic performances since 1983 found that, although athletes sexes improved time span, "gender gap" female male performances remained stable. suggests women's performances high level never match men. k. benefits natural testosterone provides male athletes diminished use puberty blockers cross-sex hormones. recent study impact treatments found even 12 months hormonal therapy, man identifies woman taking cross-sex hormones possesses significant advantage female athletes still likely performance benefits women. l. separate sex-specific teams furthers efforts promote sex equality. Sex-specific teams accomplish providing opportunities female athletes demonstrate skill, strength, athletic abilities also providing opportunities obtain recognition accolades, college scholarships, numerous long-term benefits flow success athletic endeavors. 2. a. Interscholastic, intercollegiate, intramural, club athletic teams sports sponsored public nonpublic school member New Jersey State Interscholastic Athletic Association (NJSIAA), public institution higher education higher education institution member national collegiate athletic association (NCAA), national association intercollegiate athletics (NAIA), national junior college athletic association (NJCAA) shall expressly designated one following based biological sex: (1) males, men, boys; (2) females, women, girls; (3) coed mixed. b. Athletic teams sports designated females, women, girls shall open students male sex. student's sex disputed, student shall establish sex presenting signed physician's statement shall indicate student's sex based solely on: (1) student's internal external reproductive anatomy; (2) student's normal endogenously produced levels testosterone; (3) analysis student's genetic makeup. 3. government entity, licensing accrediting organization, athletic association organization shall entertain complaint, open investigation, take adverse action school institution higher education maintaining separate interscholastic, intercollegiate, intramural, club athletic teams sports students female sex. 4. a. student deprived athletic opportunity suffers direct indirect harm result violation chapter shall private cause action injunctive relief, damages, relief available law school institution higher education. b. student subject retaliation adverse action school, institution higher education, athletic association organization result reporting violation chapter employee representative school, institution, athletic association organization, State federal agency oversight schools institutions higher education State, shall private cause action injunctive relief, damages, relief available law school, institution, athletic association organization. c. school institution higher education suffers direct indirect harm result violation chapter shall private cause action injunctive relief, damages, relief available law government entity, licensing accrediting organization, athletic association organization. d. civil actions permitted section shall initiated within two years harm occurred. Persons organizations prevail claim brought pursuant section shall entitled monetary damages, including psychological, emotional, physical harm suffered, reasonable attorney's fees costs, appropriate relief. 5. act shall take effect immediately. By: Harrison H.B. No. 1029 BILL ENTITLED ACT relating prohibition funding gender reassignment. ENACTED LEGISLATURE STATE TEXAS: SECTION 1. Subtitle F, Title 10, Government Code, amended adding Chapter 2275 read follows: Chapter 2275. Prohibition Use Taxpayer Resources Sec. 2275.001. DEFINITIONS. chapter: (1) "Gender reassignment" means medical intervention, including surgery performed purpose altering person's primary secondary sex characteristics drugs biologicals prescribed purpose altering maintaining alteration person's primary secondary sex characteristics. (2) "Intersex person" means person who: (A) inborn chromosomal, gonadal, genital, endocrine characteristics, combination characteristics, suited typical definition male female atypical determined sex person; (B) considered medical professional inborn chromosomal, gonadal, genital, endocrine characteristics ambiguous atypical determined sex person. Sec. 2275.002. PROHIBITION USE TAXPAYER RESOURCES GENDER REASSIGNMENT. (a) funds authorized appropriated State law shall expended gender reassignment. (b) funds authorized appropriated State law shall expended health benefits covers gender reassignment. (c) prohibition subsection (a) (b) apply gender reassignment performed intersex person. SECTION 2. Act takes effect immediately receives vote two-thirds members elected house, provided Section 39, Article III, Texas Constitution. Act receive vote necessary immediate effect, Act takes effect September 1, 2023. 2023-2024 Bill 3827 Text Previous Version (Jan. 26, 2023) - South Carolina Legislature Online South Carolina General Assembly125th Session, 2023-2024Bill 3827Indicates Matter StrickenIndicates New Matter(Text matches printed bills. Document reformatted meet World Wide Web specifications.) bill AMEND SOUTH CAROLINA CODE LAWS ADDING SECTION 59-29-12 PROVIDE STUDENTS STATE-FUNDED PLACES LEARNING EDUCATION FOCUSED EXCELLENCE INTEGRITY, EQUIP THINK INDEPENDENTLY CRITICALLY, SUPPORT EDUCATORS MAINTAINING LEARNING WORK ENVIRONMENT UNENCUMBERED SOCIAL POLITICAL ACTIVISM, TREAT STUDENTS EMPLOYEES SCHOOLS DIGNITY UNIQUE INDIVIDUALS WITHOUT STEREOTYPING SCAPEGOATING, PROVIDE INSTRUCTION FREE IDEOLOGICAL INDOCTRINATION COERCION, FOSTER DEFEND INTELLECTUAL INQUIRY FREEDOM SPEECH WELL FREEDOM COMPELLED SPEECH, REQUIRE CLEAR DISTINCTIONS TEACHING THEORY FACT, REQUIRE FULL TRANSPARENCY CURRICULA, PROTECT PRIVACY INNOCENCE CHILDREN GUARD OBSCENE MATURE MATERIALS, RESPECT RIGHTS PARENTS child's DECISION-MAKERS HEALTH WELL-BEING, INCLUDING EMOTIONAL SEXUAL DEVELOPMENT, DEFER PARENTS child's PRIMARY SOURCE MORAL SOCIAL VALUES, ALLOW PARENTS OPT ACTIVITIES VIOLATE ACT, ESTABLISH CLEAR PROTOCOL REPORTING VIOLATIONS ALLOWING LOCAL ENTITIES ADDRESS CORRECT ISSUES, REQUIRE PRIVACY NONDISCLOSURE INVESTIGATION PROCESS. enacted General Assembly State South Carolina: SECTION 1. Chapter 29, Title 59 S.C. Code amended adding: Section 59-29-12. (A) intent General Assembly state-funded education entities, including places learning, state local agencies, accreditation entities, overseeing authorities, instructional content providers, educators, faculty, administrators, staff: (1) strive provide every student well-rounded, rigorous, high-quality education positive focus excellence high expectations; (2) support allow educators focus effectively teaching subjects content maintaining learning work environment unencumbered social political activism; (3) treat students, parents, colleagues respectfully equally unique individuals, refraining stereotyping scapegoating others based personal group characteristics political religious beliefs; (4) encourage equip students, without employing ideological coercion indoctrination, think critically, creatively, independently; (5) foster defend freedom intellectual inquiry, freedom speech, freedom compelled speech, freedom association; (6) respect students' freedom express differing viewpoints without penalty marginalization, especially controversial topics; (7) provide instruction intellectually honest, placed historical context, grounded verifiable facts; (8) provide full transparency parents, legal custodians, public teaching subjects instructional materials used educate students; (9) respect innocence children guarding obscene age-inappropriate topics content, protecting right privacy; (10) respect right of, defer to, parents legal custodians primary decision-makers source children's education regard learning morals, ethics, civic responsibilities, social values, political religious beliefs, emotional sexual development, health medical decisions, sexual gender beliefs. (B) purposes section: (1) "Place learning" means public, charter, private childcare facility, preschool, elementary, middle, secondary, postsecondary school, institution higher learning receives funds grants originate State South Carolina, whether whole part, directly State agencies indirectly intermediary entity. (2) "State-funded education entity" (SFEE) means entity receives funds grants originate State South Carolina, whether whole part, directly state agencies indirectly intermediary entity, includes: (a) place learning; (b) public private institution, organization, business engaged providing accreditation, licensing, professional development, training services, instructional reading materials, surveys, questionnaires, screenings, supplemental resources school class library content format place learning employees; (c) "overseeing authority," includes state local agency, school board, school authorizer sponsor, board directors, similar entity administrative oversight duties entities (a) (b) above. (3) "State Board" means South Carolina State Board Education. (4) "Harmful minors" "sexual activity" meanings defined Title 16, Chapter 15, Article 3, particular Section 16-15-375 except modified purposes section subsection (D)(5)(a) below. (C) General Assembly hereby affirms principles enshrined Declaration Independence, United States Constitution, Civil Rights Act 1964, Constitution South Carolina, South Carolina Human Affairs Law found Chapter 13, Title 1, following concepts discriminatory, violate Constitutional statutory rights individuals, contrary inimical intentions enumerated subsection (A)(1): (1) one race biological sex inherently superior inferior another race biological sex; (2) group individual, virtue race, ethnicity, color, biological sex, sexual orientation, national origin, heritage, culture, religion, political belief inherently racist, sexist, bigoted, ignorant, biased, fragile, privileged, oppressive, contributive oppression, whether consciously unconsciously; (3) individual group receive adverse favorable treatment, discriminated solely partly race, ethnicity, color, biological sex, sexual orientation, national origin, heritage, culture, religion, political belief; (4) members one race, biological sex, color, ethnicity cannot attempt treat, relate to, advise, instruct others without respect race, biological sex, color, ethnicity, culture, individuals separated accordance race, color, ethnicity purposes employment, instruction, training, living arrangements, activities; (5) individual's moral character, value, status, whether wholly partly, necessarily determined race, ethnicity, color, biological sex, national origin, heritage, culture, religion, political belief; (6) individual, virtue race, biological sex, color, ethnicity, heritage, bears responsibility, must confess atone actions committed past members race, biological sex, ethnic group; (7) individual made feel shame, guilt, anguish, form psychological distress race, color, ethnicity, biological sex, national origin, heritage, culture, religion, political belief; (8) traits, behaviors, concepts meritocracy, hard work ethic, punctuality, use standard English language, sense urgency, pursuit excellence, valuing written word, individualism, logic, objectivity racist sexist, created particular race group oppress another race group; (9) individual must compelled affirm, accept, adopt, profess, adhere concepts, forms language, definitions firmly widely established, empirically scientifically accurate, controversial theoretical, as: (a) gender theory, including nonbinary pronouns honorifics; (b) unconscious implicit bias; (c) race biological sex social constructs; (D) state-funded education entity, including employees volunteers, shall not: (1) promote, engage in, treat individuals accordance with, discriminatory concepts subsection (C); (2) direct otherwise compel individuals personally affirm, accept, adopt, profess, adhere discriminatory concepts subsection (C); (3) conduct, sponsor, encourage, require individuals participate instruction, presentations, discussions, trainings, questionnaires, surveys, clubs, counseling, activities affirm promote discriminatory concepts subsection (C), whether part lesson, assigned suggested materials made available format setting, conducted premises, remotely, third party; (4) conduct instruction that: (a) teaches theoretical ideas uncorroborated claims factual; (b) materially distorts misrepresents verifiable historical facts; (c) inculcates, coerces, pressures, encourages students accepting affirming particular ideology political belief, participating social political activism protesting, marching, lobbying, writing campaigns; (d) offers course credit, incentives, favorable consideration participating social political activism; (e) advertises, promotes, endorses social political ideologies, causes, movements, organizations, political candidates; (f) creates atmosphere hostile open respectful inquiry discussion, demeans, marginalizes, penalizes individuals expressing differing viewpoints, especially controversial issues; (g) promotes endorses concept "equity," defined treating different individuals groups unequally achieve equal similar outcomes, concept violates nondiscriminatory statutes contrary America's foundational underpinnings equality, equality law, role equality United States Constitution; (h) promotes endorses narratives that: (i) United States founded purpose oppression, American Revolution fought purpose protecting oppression, United States history story defined oppression; (ii) respect relationship American values, slavery racism anything deviations from, betrayals of, failures live to, authentic founding principles United States, include liberty equality; (5) subjects minors age eighteen instruction, presentations, displays, performances, discussions, assignments, questionnaires, surveys, materials medium made available format setting, including making access available online services, school class libraries, book fairs, catalogs violate students' privacy involve contain following age-inappropriate content, reserved parents legal custodians discuss with, explain to, children accordance family values and, elect to, health professionals choosing: (a) sexually explicit obscene materials accordance Article 3, Chapter 15, Title 16, materials using obscene profane language accordance Chapter 17, Title 16, particular Section 16-17-530. purposes section, materials shall considered age-inappropriate harmful minors sexually explicit obscene content profane language present portion materials; and, claims taken whole content serious literary, artistic, political, scientific value shall apply shall exempt materials considered harmful minors; (b) concepts instruction sexual activity, sexual orientation, gender theory, gender identity, gender multiplicity, gender expression, except may needed exclusively teaching public health model sexual risk avoidance education human biological reproduction part larger unit study grades 9 12; SPONSORS: Sen. Carson, Dist 14; Sen. Avard, Dist 12; Sen. Gannon, Dist 23; Sen. Gray, Dist 6; Sen. Birdsell, Dist 19; Sen. Bradley, Dist 3; Sen. Ward, Dist 8; Sen. Innis, Dist 7; Sen. Murphy, Dist 16; Sen. Ricciardi, Dist 9; Sen. Lang, Dist 2; Sen. Abbas, Dist 22; Sen. Gendreau, Dist 1; Sen. Pearl, Dist 17 COMMITTEE: Education ----------------------------------------------------------------- ANALYSIS bill establishes parents' bill rights, constitutes violation rights, mechanism notify parents rights. - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - Explanation: Matter added current law appears bold italics. Matter removed current law appears [in brackets struckthrough.] Matter either (a) new (b) repealed reenacted appears regular type. 23-1062 07/05 STATE NEW HAMPSHIRE Year Lord Two Thousand Twenty Three ACT establishing parents' bill rights education. Enacted Senate House Representatives General Court convened: 1 Declaration Purpose. I. general court finds reaffirms parents fundamental right responsibility direct upbringing, education, care minor children order meaningfully effectively exercise right, educational institution may withhold information child, child’s health, child’s school environment, child’s in-school behavior child’s parent parents absent compelling government interest. II. general court finds child’s parents responsibility, means, resources ensure child receives appropriate health care, social support, religious guidance, moral inculcation develop happy productive members society. III. Accordingly, general court finds necessary establish consistent mechanism parents notified information relating health, well-being, educational progress minor children children custody control public schools. 2 New Chapter; Parents' Bill Rights Education. Amend RSA inserting chapter 189-A following new chapter:CHAPTER 189-BPARENTS' BILL RIGHTS EDUCATION 189-B:1 Short Title. chapter may cited Parent’s Bill Rights Education. 189-B:2 Definitions. chapter: I. "Parent" means person legal custody minor child natural adoptive parent legal guardian, term shall include parent parent-child relationship terminated judicial decree voluntary relinquishment. II. “Minor” means person age 18 years. III. “Compelling state interest” shall include circumstance school school personnel actual objectively reasonable belief, supported clear convincing evidence, believe action inaction impinges upon rights identified RSA 189-B:3 likely cause child abused neglected defined RSA 169-C:3, except compelling state interest shall found exist solely school school personnel believe child's best interest served impinging upon parental rights. IV. “School” shall include, without limitation, school board, school district, school administrative unit, public charter school. V. “School personnel” shall include teacher, administrator, employer, individual acting furtherance behalf school. VI.(a) “Infringement” purposes chapter shall include: (1) violation infringement rights described chapter; (2) knowing withholding truthful information required disclosed child’s parent pursuant chapter; (3) knowing provision misleading intentionally inaccurate information required disclosed forbidden withheld child’s parent pursuant chapter; (4) denial existence information required disclosed child’s parent pursuant chapter information known school school personnel inquired parent. (b) “Infringement” purposes chapter shall include: (1) development implementation school curricula and/or programming authorized New Hampshire law disclosures required chapter made. (2) denial requests parents school district adopt requested curricula and/or programming child consistent properly adopted curricula and/or programming. (3) denial one requests parent school district permit child engage course study approved school district, except specifically permitted chapter required New Hampshire law. 189-B:3 Parental Rights. I. parental rights reserved parents minor children state without obstruction interference school school personnel. rights parent regarding child children include, limited to, following: (a) right direct upbringing moral religious training parent’s minor child. (b) right direct education parent’s minor child. right includes right choose enroll child assigned resident public school, public charter school, approved nonpublic school, home education program, Education Freedom Account program, set forth RSA 193:1 RSA 194:F:1, et seq. (c) right request child enrolled public school public school assigned residence avoid manifest educational hardship, set forth RSA 193:3. (d) right enroll child private school, including religious school, home education program, available options, authorized law, alternative public education, set forth RSA 193:1 RSA 194:F-1, et seq. (e) right obtain access child public curricular courses co-curricular programs offered local school district student resides choosing enroll child non-public public chartered, home education EFA program, set forth RSA 193:1-c RSA 194-F:2(d). (f) right inspect instructional material used part educational curriculum child within reasonable period following request, set forth 20 U.S.C. section 1232h(c)(1)(C). (g) right exempt minor child immunizations if, opinion physician, immunization detrimental child religious beliefs, set forth RSA 141-C:20-a RSA 141-C:20-c. (h) right exempt public-school student participating required statewide assessments English, language arts, mathematics, and/or science, set forth RSA 193-C:6. (i) right receive information regarding level achievement academic growth child state academic assessments English, language arts, mathematics, and/or science, set forth Every Student Succeeds Act, 20 U.S.C. section 1112 (e)(1)(B)(i). (j) right opt health sex education objectionable material, set forth RSA 186:11, IX-b IX-c. (k) right access review education records relating minor child within 14 days day school receives request access set forth RSA 189:66, IV, 34 C.F.R. 99.5. (l) right promptly notified criminal offense committed minor child, set forth RSA 193-D:4. (m) right notified whenever seclusion restraint used child set forth RSA 126-U:7. (n) right informed school district’s policy regarding discipline policies procedures, set forth RSA 193:13. (o) right advised non-academic survey questionnaire administered child requirement parent consent child completing survey questionnaire, well right opt child Youth Risk Behavior Survey developed Centers Disease Control Prevention, set forth RSA 186:11, IX-d. (p) right access review medical records child maintained school school personnel, except: (1) restricted RSA 132:32-132:36, RSA 141-C:18, RSA 141-F:7, RSA 135-C:19-A; (2) parent convicted crime violence minor child; (3) parent subject investigation crime committed minor child law enforcement agency requested applicable court information released parent order protect integrity ongoing investigation. (q) right consent writing biometric scan child made, shared, stored, set forth RSA 189:65 RSA 189:68. (r) right consent writing record child’s blood deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) created, stored, shared, except required general law authorized pursuant court order. (s) right informed of, provide consent to, medical procedure treatment performed child, except pursuant RSA 132:34, RSA 141-C:18, provision emergency medical treatment. (t) right inquire school school personnel truthfully completely informed child identified name name child enrolled school nickname reasonable person would understand commonly derived name, including circumstances reasonable person would understand purpose facilitating change gender gender transition. (u) right inquire school school personnel truthfully completely informed child identified referred school district staff, gender child identified referred enrolled. (v) right inquire school school personnel truthfully completely informed school school personnel proceeding intervention affirm provide accommodation child’s asserted gender identity student’s gender identity child identified referred enrolled. (w) right know extracurricular activities, clubs, organizations child participating in. II. Federal law provides additional parent family involvement schools receiving Title I, Part A; Title I, Part C (migrant); Title III, Part (EL) funds, including: (a) right receive information, including student reports, understandable uniform format extent practicable, language parents understand, set forth 20 U.S.C. sections 1112(e)(4); 1114(b)(4); 1116(e)(5); 1116(f). (b) Upon request parent, right receive information regarding state qualifications student’s classroom teachers paraprofessionals providing services child, set forth 20 U.S.C. section 1112(e)(1)(A)(i-ii). (c) right receive annual local educational agency report card includes information agency whole school served agency, set forth 20 U.S.C. section 1111(h)(2)(A-B)(i-iii). III. Nothing chapter shall: (a) Authorize parent minor child state engage conduct unlawful abuse neglect minor child violation general law. (b) Prohibit court competent jurisdiction, law enforcement officer, employees government agency responsible child welfare acting official capacity, pursuant RSA 186:11, IX-c. 189-B:4 Violations. I. school school personnel, shall infringe upon parental rights set forth RSA 189-B:3, unless infringement supported clear convincing evidence narrowly tailored address compelling state interest. II. parent claiming violation provision chapter may bring action declaratory and/or injunctive relief monetary damages school school personnel. parent prevails court action, court shall award parent reasonable attorneys’ fees court costs, including attorneys’ fees court costs incurred appeal supreme court. 189-B:5 Procedure Upon Determination Existence Compelling State Interest Warranting Infringement Upon Parental Rights. Upon determining compelling state interest requires school school personnel infringe upon parental rights described chapter, school personnel shall immediately notify superior intent infringe upon parental rights written report identifies articulable facts person believes justifies infringement parental rights. report shall identify individual parental rights school school personnel proposes infringe upon basis infringement. report shall also state anticipated duration continued impingement parental rights steps school school personnel proposes take address compelling state interest. infringement parental rights shall continue longer necessary address compelling state interest. 189-B:6 School Board Notification Parent’s Rights. Every school board shall annually provide written notice parents minors district rights set forth RSA 189-B:3. 189-B:7 Severability. provision chapter application person circumstance held invalid, invalidity affect provisions applications chapter given effect without invalid provision application, end provisions chapter severable. 3 Effective Date. act shall take effect September 1, 2023. AGENCIES CONTACTED: Department Education MISSISSIPPI LEGISLATURE 2023 Regular Session To: Education By: Senator(s) Hill Senate Bill 2820 ACT ENTITLED "TRANSPARENCY EDUCATION ACT"; PROVIDE PARENTS PUBLIC SCHOOL STUDENTS CERTAIN RIGHTS RELATED CHILD'S EDUCATION, INCLUDING RIGHT REVIEW SYLLABUS, CURRICULUM TEACHER-TRAINING MATERIALS MEET TEACHER DISCUSS COURSE CONTENT; REQUIRE PUBLIC SCHOOLS ADOPT PROCEDURES ENSURE PARENT PROVIDES WRITTEN PERMISSION CHILD PARTICIPATES IDENTITY CURRICULUM CRITICAL THEORY CURRICULUM ALLOW PARENTS EXEMPT CHILD SPECIFIC LESSONS OBJECTIONABLE FAMILY; DIRECT PUBLIC SCHOOLS HOLD CURRICULUM NIGHT ALLOW PARENTS REVIEW CURRICULUM MEET TEACHERS STAFF; PROVIDE PARENTAL ACCESS CERTAIN SCHOOL DISTRICT RECORDS CONCERNING CHILD; PROVIDE COMPLAINT PROCEDURES; AMEND SECTION 37-13-9, MISSISSIPPI CODE 1972, CONFORMITY; RELATED PURPOSES. ENACTED LEGISLATURE STATE MISSISSIPPI: SECTION 1. Title. act may known cited "Transparency Education Act." SECTION 2. Definitions. used act: (a) "Curriculum" includes textbooks, reading materials, handouts, videos, presentations, digital materials, websites, online applications, digital applications phone, laptop tablet, questionnaires, surveys, written electronic materials assigned, distributed, otherwise presented physically virtually students class course. (b) "Identity curriculum" means curriculum goal purpose studying, exploring, informing students gender roles stereotypes, gender identity, gender expression, sexual orientation, romantic sexual relationships. (c) "Critical theory curriculum" means curriculum discusses following concepts: (i) United States State Mississippi fundamentally, inherently, irredeemably racist, sexist, oppressive discriminatory; (ii) individual, virtue sex, race, ethnicity, religion, color national origin, inherently racist, sexist, oppressive discriminatory whether consciously unconsciously; (iii) individual, virtue sex, race, ethnicity, religion, color national origin, blamed held responsible actions committed past members individual's sex, race, ethnicity, religion, color national origin; (iv) individual's moral character necessarily determined, whole part, individual's sex, race, ethnicity, religion, color national origin; (v) individual feel guilt, blame, discomfort, anguish, form psychological distress account individual's sex, race, ethnicity, religion, color national origin; (vi) individual, virtue sex, race, ethnicity, religion, color national origin, marginalized perpetually victimized unable advance society due victimized, marginalized, oppressed others. (d) "Public school" "school" means school subject provisions Title 37, Mississippi Code 1972. Public school include school subject Title 37, including private school, religious school home-educating family. (e) "Parent" means natural adoptive parent legal guardian minor child. (f) "Syllabus" means written description topics subjects taught class course, shall include list curriculum used class course, identity individuals providing in-person live remote instruction class course, description assemblies, guest lectures, field trips, educational activities part class course. SECTION 3. Parents' rights school procedures. (1) public school shall procedure parent to: (a) Review syllabus curriculum class course offered school, teacher-training materials, regular hours operation school special appointment; (b) Copy record information syllabus, curriculum teacher-training materials; (c) Meet teacher class course, principal, representative school discuss syllabus, curriculum teacher-training materials. (2) public school shall procedure ensure child attend instruction presentation includes Identity Curriculum Critical Theory Curriculum unless school received written permission child's parent authorizing child attend instruction presentation. (3) public school shall procedure parent withdraw child specific instruction presentation parent, parent's sole discretion, objects child receiving. procedure shall set forth reasonable arrangements school personnel take provide alternative instruction educational activities child. Alternative instruction may provided parent alternative instruction offered school meet concerns parent. school required pay costs alternative instruction provided parent. School personnel may impose academic penalty upon child withdrawn objectionable instruction presentation section. section exempt child satisfying grade-level graduation requirements. (4) public school shall publish procedures required section school's website. SECTION 4. Curriculum transparency. (1) least seven (7) days prior start academic school period semester, public school shall: (a) Compile physical and/or electronic copy syllabus curriculum class course offered school; (b) Post school's website syllabus class course offered school; (c) Schedule provide written notice parents "curriculum night" shall held later fourteen (14) days start academic school period semester. curriculum night, school shall allow parents to: (i) Review in-person syllabus curriculum class course offered school; (ii) Speak subjects curriculum taught class course teacher, teacher unavailable, another representative school familiar subjects curriculum course class. (d) Send written notice parents child enrolled school, post conspicuous location school's website, following information: (i) Parents right review syllabus curriculum class course school office regular hours operation regular hours special appointment; (ii) Parents right copy record information syllabus curriculum; (iii) Parents right meet teacher class course, principal, representative school discuss syllabus curriculum; (iv) explanation rights parents obligations public schools set forth act, including active website address parents read copy act; (v) permission form parent must sign return school prior child attending instruction presentation containing Identity Curriculum Critical Theory Curriculum; (vi) form parent may sign return school withdraw child specific instruction presentation parent, parent's sole discretion, objects child receiving. (2) curriculum added class course start academic school period semester, school shall provide following parents child enrolled class course least three (3) days prior added curriculum taught: (a) written electronic copy revised syllabus shall conspicuously identify added curriculum; (b) written electronic statement informing parents right review added curriculum class course offered school copy record information revised syllabus added curriculum discuss teacher, principal, representative school; (c) written electronic statement informing parents may withdraw child specific instruction presentation parent, parent's sole discretion, objects child receiving provide link location school's website parent obtain form. SECTION 5. Right access child's educational records. (1) parent shall access written electronic records concerning parent's child controlled possession school district, district employee person organization hired, contracted authorized school district provide services students, including: (a) Attendance records; (b) Test scores school-administered tests state-wide assessments; (c) Grades; (d) Extracurricular activity club participation; (e) child's email accounts; (f) child's online virtual accounts data; (g) Disciplinary records; (h) Counseling records; (i) Psychological records; (j) Applications admission; (k) Health immunization information, including medical records maintained health clinic medical facility operated controlled school district located district property; (l) Teacher counselor evaluations; (m) Reports behavioral patterns. (2) School employees shall withhold conceal information from, facilitate, encourage coerce child withhold conceal information from, child's parents child's: (a) Curricular extracurricular projects, assignments activities; (b) Physical, emotional, mental health; (c) Purported gender identity requested transition, child's purported gender identity incongruous biological sex. SECTION 6. Remedies violations. (1) parent may submit written complaint detailing violation act superintendent school district. parent shall entitled meeting superintendent discuss complaint desired parent. superintendent shall investigate complaint respond parent writing within fourteen (14) days receiving complaint describing actions superintendent shall take remedy complaint. (2) parent may appeal actions superintendent school district local school board submitting written complaint detailing violation act description superintendent's response failed remedy complaint. local school board shall appoint committee investigate complaints. committee shall meet parent discuss complaint. Within thirty (30) days receiving complaint, committee shall submit recommended response proposed steps remedy complaint full board action board next regularly scheduled meeting. (3) board's action remedy complaint, parent may file suit assert violation act claim school district. (4) Nothing section precludes parent filing suit asserting violation act claim otherwise allowed law. (5) parent successfully asserts claim act may recover: (a) Declaratory relief; (b) Injunctive relief prevent remedy violation act effects violation; (c) Reasonable attorneys' fees costs; (d) appropriate relief. SECTION 7. Student privacy. student whose bodily privacy violated, including encountering person opposite sex bathroom, locker room facility traditionally designated exclusive use members one sex, action, policy practice primary secondary school institution higher education shall private cause action injunctive relief, damages relief available law school institution. SECTION 8. Rules construction severability. (1) act shall construed favor broad protection parental authority care, upbringing, education child. (2) provision act application provision particular person circumstance held invalid law, remainder act application provisions person circumstance shall affected. SECTION 9. PROVIDE ABUSE NEGLECT CHILD PARENT ACTION DECISION PARENT WOULD END LIFE AUTHORIZED ACT; PROHIBIT EMPLOYEES STATE POLITICAL SUBDIVISION THEREOF, EXCEPT LAW ENFORCEMENT PERSONNEL, ENCOURAGING COERCING CHILD WITHHOLD INFORMATION CHILD'S PARENT; STIPULATE LIMITATIONS PLACED UPON PERSONS, CORPORATIONS, ASSOCIATIONS, ORGANIZATIONS, STATE SUPPORTED INSTITUTIONS INDIVIDUALS EMPLOYED ENTITIES PROVIDE MEDICAL MENTAL HEALTH SERVICE PROCEDURE CHILD WITHOUT FIRST OBTAINING CONSENT CHILD'S PARENT, EXCEPT OTHERWISE PROVIDED LAW COURT ORDER; PROVIDE ACT SHALL SERVE DEFENSE CAUSE ACTION RAISED RESULT VIOLATION THEREOF; PROVIDE RULES CONSTRUCTION SHALL PROVIDE BROAD PROTECTION PARENT'S FUNDAMENTAL RIGHTS INALIENABLE UNLESS RIGHTS LEGALLY WAIVED LEGALLY TERMINATED; PROVIDE SEVERABILITY PART ACT HELD INVALID; AMEND SECTION 37-3-49, MISSISSIPPI CODE 1972, PROVIDE PARENT PUBLIC SCHOOL STUDENT RIGHT RECEIVE EFFECTIVE COMMUNICATION SCHOOL PRINCIPAL MANNER INSTRUCTIONAL MATERIALS USED IMPLEMENT SCHOOL'S CURRICULAR OBJECTIVES; ENACTED LEGISLATURE STATE MISSISSIPPI: SECTION 1. act shall known may cited "Families' Rights Responsibilities Act 2023." SECTION 2. used act, following terms shall meaning ascribed section unless context usage requires otherwise: (a) "Child" means individual age eighteen (18). term include child adjudicated legally emancipated minor accordance state law court competent jurisdiction. (b) "Curriculum" includes textbooks, reading materials, handouts, videos, presentations, digital materials, websites, online applications, digital applications phone, laptop tablet, questionnaires, surveys, written electronic materials assigned, distributed otherwise presented physically virtually students class course. (c) "Educational records" includes attendance records, test scores school-administered tests state-wide assessments, grades, extracurricular activity club participation, e-mail accounts, online virtual accounts data, disciplinary records, counseling records, psychological records, applications admission, health immunization information including medical records maintained health clinic medical facility operated controlled school district located district property, teacher counselor evaluations, reports behavioral patterns. (d) "Parent" means biological parent child, adoptive parent child, individual granted exclusive right, guardianship authority welfare child state law. (e) "Substantial burden" means action directly indirectly constrains, inhibits, curtails, denies right parent direct upbringing, education, health care mental health parent's child, compels action contrary right parent direct upbringing, education, health care mental health parent's child. term includes, limited to, withholding benefits, assessing criminal, civil administrative penalties damages, exclusion governmental assistance programs. SECTION 3. Parental Rights Fundamental. (1) liberty parent direct upbringing, education, health care mental health parent's child fundamental right. (2) Except otherwise provided statute, state, political subdivision state governmental entity shall substantially burden fundamental right parent direct upbringing, education, health care mental health parent's child without demonstrating burden required compelling governmental interest highest order applied parent child least restrictive means furthering compelling governmental interest. SECTION 4. Rights Responsibilities. (1) parental rights exclusively reserved parent child without obstruction interference state, political subdivision state, governmental entity institution, including without limitation, following rights responsibilities: (a) direct education child, including right choose public, private, religious home schools, right make reasonable choices within public schools education child; (b) access review written electronic educational records relating child controlled possession school; (c) direct upbringing child; (d) direct moral religious training child; (e) make consent writing physical mental health care decisions child; (f) access review health medical records child; (g) consent writing biometric scan child made, shared stored; (h) consent writing record child's blood deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) created, stored shared, unless authorized pursuant court order; (i) consent writing governmental entity makes video voice recording child, unless video voice recording made part of: (i) court proceeding; (ii) law enforcement investigation; (iii) forensic interview criminal Department Child Protection Services investigation; (iv) security surveillance buildings grounds; (v) photo identification card; (j) notified promptly employee state, political subdivision state, governmental entity institution suspects abuse, neglect criminal offense committed child; (k) opt child personal analysis, evaluation, survey data collection school district would capture data inclusion state longitudinal student data system except necessary essential establish student's educational record; (l) right child excused school attendance religious purposes; (m) right participate parent-teacher associations school organizations sanctioned board education school district. (2) section authorize allow parent abuse neglect child defined Section 43-21-105. section apply parental action decision would end life. section prohibit court issuing order otherwise permitted law. SECTION 6. Medical Mental Health Care. (1) Except otherwise provided law court order, person, corporation, association, organization, state-supported institution individual employed entities must obtain consent parent child taking following actions: (a) Procuring, soliciting perform, arranging performance of, providing referral for, performing surgical procedures upon child; (b) Procuring, soliciting perform, arranging performance of, providing referral for, performing physical examination upon child; (c) Prescribing dispensing medication prescription drugs child; (d) Procuring, soliciting perform, arranging performance of, providing referral for, performing mental health evaluation clinical nonclinical setting, mental health treatment child. (3) provisions section shall apply determined physician that: (a) emergency exists; (b) Either following conditions true: (i) necessary perform activity listed subsection (1) order prevent death imminent irreparable physical injury child; (ii) parent child cannot located contacted reasonably diligent effort. (4) provisions section apply abortion, shall governed Chapter 41, Title 41, Mississippi Code 1972, shall section apply services treatments provided facilitate gender transition performance gender transition procedures defined Section 2, House Bill 1125, 2023 Regular Session. SECTION 7. Cause Action. (1) parent may bring suit violation act may raise act defense judicial administrative proceeding without regard whether proceeding brought name state government, private person party. (2) Notwithstanding provision law, action act may commenced, relief may granted, without regard whether person commencing action sought exhausted available administrative remedies. (3) person successfully asserts claim defense act may recover declaratory relief, injunctive relief, compensatory damages, reasonable attorneys' fees costs, appropriate relief. (4) Sovereign, governmental qualified immunities suit liability waived abolished extent liability created act. SECTION 8. Rules Construction. (1) Unless rights legally waived legally terminated, parents inalienable rights comprehensive listed section. protections fundamental right parents direct upbringing, education, health care mental health child afforded act addition protections provided federal law, state law, state federal constitutions. (2) act shall construed favor broad protection fundamental right parents direct upbringing, education, health care mental health child. (3) Nothing act shall construed authorize government burden fundamental right parents direct upbringing, education, health care mental health child. (4) child affirmative right access particular medical mental health procedure service, nothing act shall construed grant child's parent affirmative right access procedure service child's behalf. (5) State statutory law adopted date enactment act subject act unless law explicitly excludes application reference act. SECTION 9. (b) "Judge" means judge Youth Court Division. (m) "Abused child" means child whose parent, guardian custodian person responsible care support, whether legally obligated not, caused allowed caused, upon child, sexual abuse, sexual exploitation, commercial sexual exploitation, emotional abuse, mental injury, nonaccidental physical injury maltreatment. (o) "A child need special care" means child mental physical illness cannot treated dispositional alternatives ordinarily available youth court. (p) "dependent child" means child child need supervision, delinquent child, abused child neglected child, child voluntarily placed custody Department Child Protection Services parent, guardian custodian. (q) "Custody" means physical possession child person. (s) "Detention" means care children physically restrictive facilities. (t) "Shelter" means care children physically nonrestrictive facilities. (w) singular includes plural, plural singular masculine feminine consistent intent chapter. (x) "Out-of-home" setting means temporary supervision care children staff licensed day care centers, staff public, private state schools, staff juvenile detention facilities, staff unlicensed residential care facilities group homes staff of, individuals representing, churches, civic social organizations. SECTION 14. act shall take effect force July 1, 2023. 2023-2024 Bill 424 Text Previous Version (Jan. 19, 2023) - South Carolina Legislature Online South Carolina General Assembly125th Session, 2023-2024Bill 424Indicates Matter StrickenIndicates New Matter(Text matches printed bills. Document reformatted meet World Wide Web specifications.) bill AMEND SOUTH CAROLINA CODE LAWS ADDING SECTION 59-29-12 PROVIDE STUDENTS STATE-FUNDED PLACES LEARNING EDUCATION FOCUSED EXCELLENCE INTEGRITY, EQUIP THINK INDEPENDENTLY CRITICALLY, SUPPORT EDUCATORS MAINTAINING LEARNING WORK ENVIRONMENT UNENCUMBERED SOCIAL POLITICAL ACTIVISM, TREAT STUDENTS EMPLOYEES SCHOOLS DIGNITY UNIQUE INDIVIDUALS WITHOUT STEREOTYPING SCAPEGOATING, PROVIDE INSTRUCTION FREE IDEOLOGICAL INDOCTRINATION COERCION, FOSTER DEFEND INTELLECTUAL INQUIRY FREEDOM SPEECH WELL FREEDOM COMPELLED SPEECH, REQUIRE CLEAR DISTINCTIONS TEACHING THEORY FACT, REQUIRE FULL TRANSPARENCY CURRICULA, PROTECT PRIVACY INNOCENCE CHILDREN GUARD OBSCENE MATURE MATERIALS, RESPECT RIGHTS PARENTS child's DECISION-MAKERS HEALTH WELL-BEING INCLUDING EMOTIONAL SEXUAL DEVELOPMENT, DEFER PARENTS child's PRIMARY SOURCE MORAL SOCIAL VALUES, ALLOW PARENTS OPT ACTIVITIES VIOLATE ACT, ESTABLISH CLEAR PROTOCOL REPORTING VIOLATIONS ALLOWING LOCAL ENTITIES ADDRESS CORRECT ISSUES, REQUIRE PRIVACY NONDISCLOSURE INVESTIGATION PROCESS. enacted General Assembly State South Carolina: SECTION 1. Chapter 29, Title 59 S.C. Code amended adding: Section 59-29-12. (A) intent General Assembly State-funded education entities, including places learning, state local agencies, accreditation entities, overseeing authorities, instructional content providers, educators, faculty, administrators, staff: (1) strive provide every student well-rounded, rigorous, high-quality education positive focus excellence high expectations; (2) support allow educators focus effectively teaching subjects content maintaining learning work environment unencumbered social political activism; (3) treat students, parents, colleagues respectfully equally unique individuals, refraining stereotyping scapegoating others based personal group characteristics political religious beliefs; (4) encourage equip students, without employing ideological coercion indoctrination, think critically, creatively, independently; (5) foster defend freedom intellectual inquiry, freedom speech, freedom compelled speech, freedom association; (6) respect students' freedom express differing viewpoints without penalty marginalization, especially controversial topics; (7) provide instruction intellectually honest, placed historical context, grounded verifiable facts; (8) provide full transparency parents, legal custodians, public teaching subjects instructional materials used educate students; (9) respect innocence children guarding obscene age-inappropriate topics content, protecting right privacy; (10) respect right of, defer to, parents legal custodians primary decision-makers source children's education regard learning morals, ethics, civic responsibilities, social values, political religious beliefs, emotional sexual development, health medical decisions, sexual gender beliefs. (B) purposes section: (1) "Place learning" means public, charter, private childcare facility, preschool, elementary, middle, secondary, postsecondary school, institution higher learning receives funds grants originate State South Carolina, whether whole part, directly State agencies indirectly intermediary entity. (2) "State-funded education entity" (SFEE) means entity receives funds grants originate State South Carolina, whether whole part, directly State agencies indirectly intermediary entity, includes: (a) place learning; (b) public private institution, organization, business engaged providing accreditation, licensing, professional development, training services, instructional reading materials, surveys, questionnaires, screenings, supplemental resources school class library content format place learning employees; (c) "overseeing authority," includes state local agency, school board, school authorizer sponsor, board directors, similar entity administrative oversight duties entities (a) (b) above. (3) "State Board" means South Carolina State Board Education. (4) "Harmful minors" "sexual activity" meanings defined Title 16, Chapter 15, Article 3, particular Section 16-15-375 except modified purposes Act subsection (D)(5)(a) below. (C) General Assembly hereby affirms principles enshrined Declaration Independence, United States Constitution, Civil Rights Act 1964, Constitution South Carolina, South Carolina Human Affairs Law found Chapter 13, Title 1, following concepts discriminatory, violate Constitutional statutory rights individuals, contrary inimical intentions enumerated subsection (A)(1): (1) one race biological sex inherently superior inferior another race biological sex; (2) group individual, virtue race, ethnicity, color, biological sex, sexual orientation, national origin, heritage, culture, religion, political belief inherently racist, sexist, bigoted, ignorant, biased, fragile, privileged, oppressive, contributive oppression, whether consciously unconsciously; (3) individual group receive adverse favorable treatment, discriminated solely partly race, ethnicity, color, biological sex, sexual orientation, national origin, heritage, culture, religion, political belief; (4) members one race, biological sex, color, ethnicity cannot attempt treat, relate to, advise, instruct others without respect race, biological sex, color, ethnicity, culture, individuals separated accordance race, color, ethnicity purposes employment, instruction, training, living arrangements, activities; (5) individual's moral character, value, status, whether wholly partly, necessarily determined race, ethnicity, color, biological sex, national origin, heritage, culture, religion, political belief; (6) individual, virtue race, biological sex, color, ethnicity, heritage, bears responsibility, must confess atone actions committed past members race, biological sex, ethnic group; (7) individual made feel shame, guilt, anguish, form psychological distress race, color, ethnicity, biological sex, national origin, heritage, culture, religion, political belief; (8) traits, behaviors, concepts meritocracy, hard work ethic, punctuality, use standard English language, sense urgency, pursuit excellence, valuing written word, individualism, logic, objectivity racist sexist, created particular race group oppress another race group; (9) individual must compelled affirm, accept, adopt, profess, adhere concepts, forms language, definitions firmly widely established, empirically scientifically accurate, controversial theoretical, as: (a) gender theory, including nonbinary pronouns honorifics; (b) unconscious implicit bias; (c) race biological sex social constructs; (D) state-funded education entity, including employees volunteers, shall not: (1) promote, engage in, treat individuals accordance with, discriminatory concepts subsection (C); (2) direct otherwise compel individuals personally affirm, accept, adopt, profess, adhere discriminatory concepts subsection (C); (3) conduct, sponsor, encourage, require individuals participate instruction, presentations, discussions, trainings, questionnaires, surveys, clubs, counseling, activities affirm promote discriminatory concepts subsection (C), whether part lesson, assigned suggested materials made available format setting, conducted premises, remotely, third party; (d) offers course credit, incentives, favorable consideration participating social political activism; (e) advertises, promotes, endorses social political ideologies, causes, movements, organizations, political candidates; (f) creates atmosphere hostile open respectful inquiry discussion, demeans, marginalizes, penalizes individuals expressing differing viewpoints, especially controversial issues; (g) promotes endorses concept "equity," defined treating different individuals groups unequally achieve equal similar outcomes, concept violates nondiscriminatory statutes contrary America's foundational underpinnings equality, equality law, role equality United States Constitution; (h) promotes endorses narratives that: (i) United States founded purpose oppression, American Revolution fought purpose protecting oppression, United States history story defined oppression; (ii) respect relationship American values, slavery racism anything deviations from, betrayals of, failures live to, authentic founding principles United States, include liberty equality; No. 1155 BILL ENTITLED ACT relating parental rights public education prohibiting instruction regarding sexual orientation gender identity certain public school students. ENACTED LEGISLATURE STATE TEXAS: SECTION 1. Chapter 26, Education Code, amended adding Section 26.0083 read follows: Sec. 26.0083. RIGHT INFORMATION REGARDING MENTAL, EMOTIONAL, PHYSICAL HEALTH HEALTH-RELATED SERVICES. (a) school district shall adopt procedure notifying parent student enrolled district regarding change in: (1) services provided monitoring student related student's mental, emotional, physical health well-being; (2) district's ability provide safe supportive learning environment student. (b) procedure adopted Subsection (a) must reinforce fundamental right parent make decisions regarding upbringing control parent's child requiring school district personnel to: (1) encourage student discuss issues relating student's well-being student's parent; (2) facilitate discussion described Subdivision (1). (c) school district may adopt procedure student support form, including student well-being questionnaire health screening form, that: (1) prohibits district employee notifying parent student regarding: (A) information student's mental, emotional, physical health well-being; (B) change services provided monitoring student related student's mental, emotional, physical health well-being; (2) encourages effect encouraging student withhold student's parent information described Subdivision (1)(A); (3) prevents parent accessing education health records concerning parent's child. (d) Subsections (a) (c) require disclosure information parent reasonably prudent person would believe disclosure likely result student suffering abuse neglect, terms defined Section 261.001, Family Code. (e) school district employee may discourage prohibit parental knowledge involvement critical decisions affecting student's mental, emotional, physical health well-being. (f) student support services training developed provided school district district employees must comply student services guidelines, standards, frameworks established State Board Education agency. Document reformatted meet World Wide Web specifications.) bill AMEND SOUTH CAROLINA CODE LAWS AMENDING SECTION 44-63-100, RELATING PROCESS PERSON MAY MAKE CHANGES BIRTH CERTIFICATE, PROVIDE GENDER CHANGES PERSON'S BIRTH CERTIFICATE MAY CHANGE MALE FEMALE FEMALE MALE PROVIDE AFFIDAVITS MUST ACCOMPANY PETITION MAKE GENDER CHANGE PERSON'S BIRTH CERTIFICATE. enacted General Assembly State South Carolina: SECTION 1. Section 44-63-100 S.C. Code amended read: Section 44-63-100. (A) purposes section: (1) "Biological sex" means biological indication male female context reproductive potential capacity sex chromosomes, naturally occurring sex hormones, gonads, nonambiguous internal external genitalia present birth, without regard individual's psychological, chosen, subjective experience gender. (2) "Gender" means psychological, behavioral, social, cultural aspects male female. Gender may male female. (3) "Gender change" means change gender gender corresponding one's biological sex gender corresponding opposite biological sex following gender change procedure. (4) "Gender change procedure" means medical surgical service, including, limited to, physician's services, inpatient outpatient hospital services, prescribed drugs seeks to: (a) alter remove physical anatomical characteristics features typical person's biological sex; (b) instill create anatomical characteristics resemble sex different individual's biological sex, including, limited to, medical services provide puberty blocking drugs, cross-sex hormones, mechanisms promote development masculinizing feminizing features opposite biological sex, genital non-genital change surgery performed purpose assisting individual gender change. (B) petition may filed South Carolina family court petitioner's residence, petitioner longer resides South Carolina, court competent jurisdiction state petitioner's residence, order establishing record name birth, subsequent name changes, gender birth, gender changes, date birth, county birth, full name mother prior marriages, full name biological father person whose birth sought registered way Delayed Certificate Birth Established Court Order. (B)(C) petition must allege person delayed certificate birth sought born State, record birth exists, petitioner failed produce minimum required documentation State Registrar Vital Statistics administrative establishment delayed birth certificate. certification State Registrar Vital Statistics must attached petition stating birth record located records State. certification must dated less two years petitions' filing date. (C)(D) petitioner shall serve certified copy filed petition State Registrar Vital Statistics least thirty days scheduled hearing. court shall fix time place hearing petition establishment birth registration, least ten days' notice writing must given State Registrar Vital Statistics. (D)(E) court shall determine, order must include, registrant's name birth, subsequent name changes, gender birth, gender changes, date birth, county birth, full name mother prior marriages, full name biological father, additional findings court considers necessary. order also must include description evidence presented court. order must forwarded clerk court State Registrar later thirty days following month order entered court. (F) petition gender change must accompanied affidavit form prepared Department Health Environmental Control petitioner affidavit licensed physician attesting petitioner undergone gender change procedure. affidavits must state that, result gender change procedure: (1) physical change person's biological sex corresponds opposite biological sex; (2) medical treatment necessary complete gender change complete except ongoing procedures treatments necessary maintain gender change; (3) gender change permanent. SECTION 2. Department Health Environmental Control shall promulgate regulations concerning affidavit referred Section 44-63-100(F) added act.
